comments.author: @vcwloves9864
comments.text: I had a really violent seizure a few years back. I was hospitalized for a night and released the next morning. Coincidentally, I was scheduled to take my teacher's certification exam that morning, too. I showed up because I figured that a fail was better than a no-show. My mind hadn't recovered yet, I was sleepy, a bit dazed, and still somewhat confused. My husband waited for me in the car. I was the first to finish--45 minutes for a 5 hour exam. Three weeks later, I got my results. I aced the exam!!! I could hardly form sentences while speaking, but somehow, I aced it. I know that seizures can spark creativity because I have lived it. FYI, it was an English/Composition exam.

He produced¬†more than 900 paintings¬†and many more drawings and sketches, which works out at nearly a new artworks every 36 hours , that can be only explained by his compulsive drawing and painting .

comments.author: @johnstrong9744
comments.text: It's impossible to determine exactly what did his mind in- But contemporary speculation reveals he was most likely autistic (which accounts for his eccentricities in the social world) and also very apparent that he had bipolar disorder. Every psych community can claim his character because he had symptoms of almost everything they display. And the distortion you mention could also be a side effect of synesthesia (which is common among autism.) It's clear that he experienced psychotic breaks that were fueled by anxiety and depression. This was most likely bipolar, but could have also stemmed from schizophrenia- as he was very detached from conventional structure (which is also a symptom of ASD.) But we know from his life that there is hope for people who suffer. That we are gifted.

replies.author: @bridgettmahoney1390
replies.text:
I completely agree, but it is common for people who are very creative to also have a higher rate of depression, anxiety, psychosis and so forth that can cripple them and make them miserable -- sometimes even halting ability to express themselves creatively.  Often meds don't alter creative abilities if you are lucky enough to find one that helps without dulling the mind or creative abilities.  

But I think it should be the individual's choice, regardless of whether they are "genius" or not, and really only suggested if the person is experiencing severe torment/a medication could help them cope with life more easily and they consent.  There would be some cases where this may be over-ridden, I admit (I have family, for instance, prone to violence tied to their addictions and also inability to regulate emotions, even well before substance abuse started.  There are always exceptions...  (And of course I know most mentally ill people are not dangerous -- I qualify as mentally ill and so do probably the majority of my friends).  

And, of course, in Van Gogh's day people were locked up and "tortured" in the name of "helping" in all kinds of ways.  No one deserves that, genius or otherwise.

I have talked too much on this thread....

replies.author: @bridgettmahoney1390
replies.text: Well, I experience both what is described in this video and what you describe.  I am diagnosed TLE based on "numerous" TLE seizures in 24 hour eeg.  I was never told where they were located specifically in the Temporal Lobes.  Even if the location of certain events reported tends to be found on tests in certain parts of the temporal lobes, it doesn't mean someone can't experience one set of symptoms, the other, both, or neither, and have either form of TLE...  I don't know why you want to see a neurosurgeon directly, while still self-diagnosed (if they don't instantly refer or dismiss you, they will probably just insist on a bunch of tests a neurologist can do).  I mean...  do you actually want surgery?  Without viable proof?  Or is it because you think neurosurgeons will know more...?  It depends more on the doctor's preferences for diagnoses and personal biases and knowledge, most of all, which i have not found to be synonymous with title.

replies.author: @216trixie
replies.text: Bridgett Mahoney I don't think I'd want surgery, but I'd like to be a little more informed than my own diagnosis. Any medical confirmation would be nice. Neurologist? Okay, is that who I see. .............And nice to talk with someone who shares this.

replies.author: @KolorfulDreamsArtKda
replies.text:
I have epilepsy, and believe me, epilepsy is not something you self-diagnose, you really need to see a neurologist.
I can understand that you might believe that you are having some symptoms that point to TLE, if that's the case go see a neurologist.
Having epilepsy is not something that makes you go: yay, I have TLE, I'm like Van Gogh, cool! If you have epilepsy you NEED to be treated!
I began having extreme mood changes and violence problems as well as visual and auditory hallucinations when I was 11, and people thought I had a mental disorder or something; when I was 18 a neurologist thought that I might have epilepsy and at age 30 I began to have full-blown seizures all the time that made me go back to the neurologist and yeah, it was epilepsy, from the beginning, and it hadn't been treated for years and now I'm finally being treated for it and I keep on having seizures because my epilepsy has evolved.
So yeah, just go see a neurologist.

replies.author: @bridgettmahoney1390
replies.text:
First off, I didn't even know his name was pronounced differently; this is how we are taught to pronounce it in school, in America (not saying it is good this is the case, but if someone legitimately was never told to pronounce it differently, what do you expect?  I don't know what a "Ductch G" sounds like (will have to look it up) -- no idea such a thing existed.  A lot of people in East Asian countries have problems with the fact English doesn't usually put lots of vowels between consonants, and I'm not used to English speakers putting down the alteration of pronunciation down of English words (be it pronouncing in any native-speaking English country).  I find knowing how to speak/read/pronounce foreign languages very impressive (and I took Spanish extensively, I am terrible at it, and I have worked with a number of non-Native English speakers -- some knowing basically not knowing anything at all at first, or perhaps, ever, if they are there temporarily and not as a refugee/immigrant/student).  

If an English speaker went all nuts over a Dutch person not pronouncing a letter or sound the same way we do, wherever we are from that happens to speak English, only the complete jerks would even bring it up!  Seriously, I don't understand why you don't simply *teach* the proper pronunciation if you are that concerned?  Not all native-English speakers have a superiority complex...

comments.text: Almost certainly he had Bipolar Disorder 1. He had moments of severe depression and major periods of mania. Bipolar psychosis is very real. My aunt is bipolar and has auditory hallucinations and had delusions prior to her treatment. Hallucinations are most likely to cycle with extreme moods, which better fits Van Gogh who could, at times, appear "normal". He didn't seem to fit the confusion of schizophrenia that would have certain been present in a time before medications for these illnesses. His episodic periods suggest bipolar and not schizophrenia.

replies.author: @srutipriyaradhadevidasi8976
replies.text: Schizophrenia is a mental form of morphing realities, including visuals, thoughts etc. the process of art is creating by interpreting realities as well. Ive heard an interpretation that schizophrenia is simply the inability to filter and block the influx of input into your psychi/third eye during the episodes and that it is a complete bombarded creation from the subtle, or gross energies surrounding us constantly. So schizo anything , is already the inability to avoid a wild interpretation of reality. It‚Äôs a creating disease of the brain. It is the inability to avoid building things in your mind off of other things. Doesn‚Äôt matter the vibration, it‚Äôs the creation process. Also life is the process of creating and creativity. Everything you see is because someone created what was in their mental eye. Even a toothbrush. Even when you write a note. Your penmanship is an expression of your creativity even. People just don‚Äôt realize. The degree to which I choose to express that, is solely based on effort. When I was young, one of my things was that people would literally turn into a 2-d Picasso interpretation of their face. No dimensions. flat. their mouths would speak sideways. Or another example is no matter what environment for 4-5years, any surface with texture my brain would turn everything into hundred of tiny demoniac faces  covering walls, forests, cars, anything and whatever I was surrounded by. and they would whisper. I‚Äôm an artist and I could‚Äôve really profited off that. I couldn‚Äôt turn it off even if I wanted to. But, I am an artist who purposefully did NOT create what my episodes would create, in hopes to stop the creations. And to some degree- it did work. and now I‚Äôm able to more purposefully navigate it. Just because it is sometimes negative, doesn‚Äôt mean it is not creation. For reference, the definition of creativity is: ‚Äúthe characteristic of a person to generate new ideas, alternatives, solutions, and possibilities in a unique and different way. Creativity is the ability to conceive something unpredictable, original and unique. It must be expressive, exciting and imaginative.‚Äù Hopefully this helps to understand!

comments.author: @carlinthomas9482
comments.text: Schizophrenia is known to elevate creativity in people, a lot of artists and actors often fall on the schizophrenic spectrum, but usually tend to have a very mild form of it.  The benefits of schizophrenia are obvious, but the draw back is that people often suffer from apophenia (make connections were none exist) and have a poorer grasp of reality, to the point where they may have difficulty with concept of objective truth and may believe that truth is actually someone's way of obtaining power of others.

replies.author: @carlinthomas9482
replies.text:
Here is the research behind creativity and schizophrenia:
According to one theory, both people with schizophrenia and their non-affected relatives lack lateralization of function in the brain. While this tends to handicap the former, it tends to benefit the latter, who gain creativity from increased use of the right hemisphere and increased communication between the right and left hemispheres. This increased inter-hemispheric communication also occurs in schizophrenia sufferers, but their cognitive processes tend to be too disorganized for them to make productive use of it.

Some healthy relatives of schizophrenia sufferers may be so close to schizophrenia on the spectrum of normality as to meet the diagnostic criteria for schizotypal personality disorder. Many more relatives who do not meet the threshold for schizotypal disorder may nonetheless have mild schizo-typal traits, such as divergent or idiosyncratic thinking, which are linked with creativity."
Source: Neel Burton M.D. Mad Genius: Schizophrenia and Creativity

comments.author: @KateMalden-f1r
comments.text: Van Gogh has always been a special historical figure and inspiring artist to me, especially in the doctor who episode Vincent and the doctor. I'm currently fundraising for Mind playing 100 pianos. Have reached 80. I too have suffered in similar ways not just in similar life challenges e.g. work feeling of not being accepted,  but from many of what he described, server anxiety, deep depression, migraines, incurable arthritis. All these I battle with.  My remedy is music as well as Art. They are my souls wings.  It was his birthday yesterday. 30th March 1853,  I remember seeing starry Night over the Rhone at the Tate modern. So blessed and pictures don't do it justice.

comments.author: @Anonymous-h2y
comments.text: Putting aside the absinthe and lead poisoning from ingesting his paints, which obviously assume a severe health problem, his childhood and early adulthood and its struggles can almost certainly be put down to his parents. Their high and narrow expectations of him just seemed permanently unattainable. He just wanted to be understood, and as a response his father wanted to have him confined to an asylum - not because of Vincent's health, but because theodorus feared that the family reputation would be tarnished if Vincent wasn't "hidden away"

comments.author: @williamrabon8839
comments.text:
Let‚Äôs get this settled once and for all: Vincent Van Gogh DID NOT COMMIT SUICIDE.

The narrator begins the film with ‚Äú...Vincent Van Gogh‚Äôs suicide...‚Äù THIS IS A MYTH.

It has finally been revealed that several French boys, who were avid fans of the 

‚ÄúBuffalo Bill‚Äôs Wild West Show,‚Äù which was sweeping through Europe to packed

auditoriums, encountered Van Gogh outside of town while on an outing. One of

the boys had his father‚Äôs rifle and decided to ‚Äútake a shot‚Äù at the painter and he

wounded him. The gang of boys went to Van Gogh‚Äôs aid feeling terrible remorse

as reality crept back into their thinking. Van Gogh knew that the boys would be

in a lot of trouble, which would possibly effect the rest of their lives, and he told

them not to worry, but to keep quiet about the entire incident. Van Gogh made it

back to town (Arles, if I‚Äôm not mistaken), where the townspeople naturally assumed 

the artist had attempted suicide again. Not long before, Van Gogh had nearly sliced 

off an ear in a dramatic attempt to show a prostitute how devoted he was to her, and

so his mental state was already in question. Long story short: Brother Theo rushed to

his side where he lay in bed for, I believe, approximately five to seven days and nights

before succumbing to his bullet wound, most likely blood poisoning.

Many years later one of the boys, a remaining survivor of those who were along that 

fateful day, wanted to clear his conscience once and for all before he died, and came

forward with a full confession. Very admirable! Especially to restoring the reputation of

one of the world‚Äôs greatest artists.

If you are interested, you may be able to find an account of the entire incident in an

episode of ‚Äò60 Minutes,‚Äô a popular TV news investigation ‚Äúmagazine‚Äù in the U.S.

comments.author: @lunasanja4574
comments.text:
Not diagnosing, only speculating, but it sounds like he might have suffered from schizoaffective disorder, what with the ¬´¬†hearing and seeing things¬†¬ª. Reality separates from itself and becomes a new perceived one. If it is not treated the two realities cannot be separated anymore from truth and imagination and just occur more and more often. And those voices/sounds/visions are usually anything but friendly, otherwise people wouldn‚Äôt suffer so terribly (or would be mystics). Also, they mention lows and passion which might hint to manic-depressive episodes which are common with schizoaffective disorder. The advancements in psychiatry are one of the greatest achievements of medicine üíõ
Now, what the video tried to say was, I think, to not reduce Van Gogh only to his mental illness. Most of the time and especially when he painted, he was not ¬´¬†ill¬†¬ª. I see his genius not coming out primarily due to the mental disorders - but he had developed and progresses his art and technique over time. He had the brillant idea to express mood with color - rather than using color to paint as realistically as possible, as was the common thing to do in Van Gogh‚Äôs time. This did not come from a place of madness but from a highly artistic, perceptive, intelligent and sensitive mind.

He couldn‚Äôt hold down a job, he was fired from every one he had. He first became a religious fanatic and then threw himself as fanatically into art, he never got over getting turned down by a woman when he was a younger man and repeatedly mentioned it to his brother in letter after letter. I read his letters to his brother (with the gift of hindsight) and thought ‚Äòoh dear, hear we go‚Äô and low and behold the seeds of mental illness grew, and I watched/read them grow. It was a terrible shame that there may have been a medical reason for his illness that now could have been treated but alas we will never know. He was absolutely a ‚Äòtortured genuine‚Äô and I don‚Äôt understand the reasoning behind debating this.

comments.author: @pyobin
comments.text:
How exactly does this video¬†dispel the tortured genius "myth"? He was tortured and he was a genius. His suffering and struggle was linked to his art. This video is the neutral, cold institutional world of contemporary art speaking. They don't like the tortured genius "myth" because its so far out of line with the art world today so they try to rewrite the narrative.¬†

The point the video makes is a contradiction. Since he was relieved by his work in painting, he surely wouldn't have worked so intensely, some might even say manically to keep the episodes at bay. An artist's mental state and their work are inseparable. 

Here is a letter Theo wrote about van Gogh's death. - He himself wanted to die, when I sat at his bedside and said that we would try to get him better and that we hoped that he would then be spared this kind of despair, he said, ‚ÄúLa tristesse durera toujours‚Äù [The sadness will last forever]. I understood what he wanted to say with those words.

A few moments later he felt suffocated and within one minute he closed his eyes. A great rest came over him from which he did not come to life again.

replies.author: @hansolo2121
replies.text: Actually Theo and Vincent spoke Dutch together during those final moment of Vincent's life. It would have een weird anyway if two Dutch brothers would choose to speak in a froreign language together instead of their own native language. Vincent also said to his brother that he wanted him to take him home to the Netherlands. The quote you gave is the French translation of what he said in Dutch to his brother. As is often the case with history many things get lost in translation... Just like Vincent's suicide story. We will never know exactly what happened that day. But it seems bizarre that anyone would even consider giving a gun to the local 'mad'foreigner who had cut off his own ear in a spell of madness and had only just come to live in their village. If a total stranger with a reputation like that would ask you if he could lend your gun would you give it to him? Also it was not common to even own a gun in Auvers at that time. Where could Vincent have even gotten the gun from? Nobody owned one. Except one boy who was known to bully Vincent 'the foreigner madman who was easy to startle' from the day he arrived in Auvers. Could there have been a tragic accident? And Vincent covering up to protect the boy?

comments.author: @casteretpollux
comments.text: Why the bland graphics and mawkish music ?   Neither in any way conveying the force, energy and materiality of Van Gogh's paintings.  John Ratcliffe used to suggest that the suicide was because Van Gogh's brother had just informed him of his forthcoming marriage, which meant that he would no longer be able to provide Vincent with the basic income on which he depended. Perhaps that contributed, perhaps also he was experiencing a period of relative emotional stability and of high achievement in his painting and made a rational decision to end his life at a high point. The question of whether his emtional or neurological condition in any way affected the appearance of his paintings is not addressed here by the Tate.

comments.text:
I don't think it's a myth. Anyone who is sensitive and hyper-aware knows that it's the source of a lot of torment. I don't think anyone unfamiliar with deep despair can make any art with existential depth and meaning. 
Ever noticed that all the people you come across and REALLY admire, or courageous or kind-hearted are people who are or have been through very hard things? Everything of value, everything meaningful is made through struggle. And the greater the struggle, the greater the art. 
I don't think that reduces him to his illness. I think it tells a story of the triumph of meaning and beauty through overcoming tragedy. That's the story of the whole world. That is what justifies life, art and love.

replies.author: @88feji
replies.text:
I would blame Vincent's depression and anxiety on his brother Theo ... 

How can Theo, a highly successful and influential art dealer who was instrumental in popularising Monet, fail to sell any of Vincent's over 900 artworks ? How is that even possible ?

And why did no one ask this question in documentaries and online discussions ?

Am I the only one to suspect Theo was actively suppressing Vincent's art's exposure to the world ?

Do note that the few times Vincent's paintings were exhibited in his lifetime, it was mostly by invitation from people who knew Vincent ... His brother Theo had never bothered to give him a solo exhibition like he did for Monet even though Theo was sitting on about 900 of Vincent's paintings...

And Vincent's art style is not even that different from other famed artists of his time, he frequently tried to incorporate styles of artists he admires like Seurat, Millet etc and his color palette was every bit as vibrant as Monet's ... What stood out in Vincent's paintings was the unmistakable emotional undercurrent of his paintings..

Its ironical that its Theo's wife did what Theo never did for Vincent, she organised solo post-humous exhibitions for Vincent and toured the paintings all over europe ... and she's not even professionally trained as an art dealer like Theo !

replies.text: @@88feji Triggers are a big part of what can set a person with mental illness into crisis. However, it is well established that most mental health disorders are heavily linked to a number of genetic markers. You can't blame anyone for his suffering but that the world is cruel and chaotic and people with mental health disorders feel that extremely deeply and struggle to make any sense of it to the point of completely losing their sanity.

The same is true now (I read): many obviously neurological illness/injury/disease are STILL said to be 'mental health problems' = because of doctors' ignorance, that it's easy to 'diagnose' instead of doing expensive tests which many don't have insurance cover for - but also if insured the insurers prefer these 'diagnoses' = cheaper - and I think some policies don't cover 'mental health' - though how on earth you can (and why would you want to) separate mental and physical health must be impossible because the brain controls not only the whole body but also our thoughts and feelings. Some people become 'savants' (genius) after a brain injury (and illness/disease), some people discover/achieve unusual strengths in art, music , maths etc. after a stroke or other brain injury = maybe Vincent had one of these things happen to his brain but at that time no understanding of how eg viruses can affect the brain and no MRIs and just said to be 'mad'. His great art was a product of him and his brain, result: genius! Got to stop: getting scrambled due to my brain injury!

replies.author: @JohnnyArtPavlou

replies.author: @singlespies
replies.text: @@JohnnyArtPavlou I disagree.  His artworks express, more than anyone else's, in my opinion, the beauty and also the suffering and the pain of passing through life.  There is great joy and there is pain.  Vincent felt both of these acutely.  Even superficially, Vincent's works share certain characteristics with the art of "insane" people - I mean the dots and dashes that fill the pictures.  Oftentimes, it feels less decorative and tends toward maniacal / obsessive - even oppressive (on his "bad" days).

But to say you shouldn‚Äôt acknowledge he‚Äôs illness, is putting shame back on people with mental illness, when for me personally, knowing that he struggled the way I and many others have, it‚Äôs a comfort, I feel not alone. This video avoids that, and doesn‚Äôt really explain his label to be a myth, more that they don‚Äôt want people to use it, we should never glorify having mental illness, but to not acknowledge that it was a large part of him and his work is not acknowledging the emotional context of the pieces.

comments.author: @Loxias321
comments.text:
I think he was autistic. One of the most common misdiagnoses for autists is bi-polar and his obsessive personality fits perfectly with autism. As someone with autism who only realsied at the age of 37, I've been plagued with horrendous mental health issues. But my love of writing (among other things) has kept me alive. 

I have an artist friend who is also autistic, and her art has lots in common with his. She says she paints in this style because it soothes her anxiety.

While not all savants are autistic, per person, far more savants are autistic. I think he was an autistic savant dealing with huge sensory and cognitive issues. His temper makes perfect sense with autism too as irritability is a big part of being overstimulated. There is also a much higher rate of addiction with autistics. We're also 5x more likely to unalive ourselves. He suffered, but in much of his art we see someone enjoying a temporary break from his pain. This is the solace all autistic people take in their special interests.

Also, the quote ‚Äùje me suis bless√©‚Äù can also translate to ‚ÄùMy [bodily] self has been wounded‚Äù. ‚ÄùJe me suis‚Äù doesn‚Äôt neccessarily have to mean ‚ÄùI have, by myself, done unto myself‚Äù but rather ‚Äùon this body of mine‚Äù, turning the listener onto the speaker‚Äôs own body rather than the speaker‚Äôs own actions. comments.author: @mourningdewey
comments.text: i've always been drawn to the works of van gogh. i received a print of the starry night for christmas and i plan to ask for more for coming christmases. before i knew about his history of mental illness, his art spoke to me in a way no other artist i've encountered has achieved. his story reminds me a lot of myself and knowing it has strengthened my love for his work. i experience psychosis and episodes of severe depression, as well as the many inconveniences and upsets brought on by ADHD, OCD, and anxiety. van gogh is a man i would have been friends with had we existed at the same time, or at least i could have understood him and he could have understood me. i look upon his work with a fondness similar to the way i look at my siblings or close friends. he was a tormented soul who deserved to heal, but never got the chance. i want to view some of his works in person someday, i want to stand in places he stood with the knowledge that i have felt the way he has. mental illness is no joke, please show your loved ones that you care.

comments.text:
I've studied Van Gogh since I was a young Cherokee boy. 
Art plays a huge part in our lives, beadwork designs, painting, and clothing too.
I've battled depression since my teen years as so many of the people who showed me such kindness as a boy were crossing over. I thought everyone got so down after losing the people close to them, but discovered that wasn't the case. I eventually was put on antidepressants after serving in the military for 15 years. I was 32 when that happened. 
At first, I improved greatly, though eventually the treatment lost its appeal. 
I have always questioned Van Gough's suicide. If you want to kill yourself the stomach makes a poor target, much pain, and does not guarantee the desired result. 
I've had friends who have crossed over from suicide as one of the 22 per-day military veterans. 
My wife is a mental health counselor who tries to assist those feeling suicidal, especially veterans like me. 
I'm glad more people are questioning Van Gogh's "suicide."
Sgi, my friend, excellent video.

comments.author: @scott_hunts
comments.text:
I disagree on the point about the revolver.  

I am an arms collector with an emphasis on 1870-1945, and although some of my pieces go outside that range, it is generally when most of my collection was made and used.  

A pertinent example from my collection is a Belgian pinfire revolver made in the liege gun works, a sort of confederation of most of the city‚Äôs arms manufacturers.  The liege gun works exploited Belgium‚Äôs very weak intellectual property laws to manufacture designs invented elsewhere, and they copied designs from the US, UK, and France.  

The example in question was made several years before Vincent‚Äôs death.  It is a a copy of the French lefechoux design and was very common throughout Europe at the time.  It was inexpensive to manufacture and buy even at the time, it utilized very low pressure cartridges that did not require particularly strong steel.  As a result any wounds caused by these guns were quite small compared to earlier cap and ball revolvers or later centerfire revolvers.  They had calibers as small as 7mm, and could easily fit in a medium sized pocket without notice, or a rather small pocket if nobody was explicitly looking for the outline of a gun in a persons clothing.  
These revolvers were exported all over the place, and generally cost a third or half as much as contemporary British designs.  

It would not be particularly hard for Vincent or anyone else to get one of these revolvers. Or for it to be lost on a field.  Moreover it‚Äôs lack of firepower  meant that any gunshot would would transfer very little kinetic energy, and would instead be like simply having a hole poked in you.  The long time for Vincent to die likely indicates a punctured organ as a result of the gunshot being the reason he died.  

Ah, should have kept watching, you directly mention the same gun and caliber lol.  But one thing of note is that pinfire ammo is very unreliable, it is entirely possible that not all the powder burned.  It is definitely worth considering.

comments.author: @capitao9603
comments.text:
One thing that bothers me about the love people have for Vincent Van Gogh is that they only focus on his suffering, romanticizing the idea of him, his life and his condition, the appreciation that his art gets seems to be conditional to his state and tragedy, ignoring all the work he put into his skill, while dealing with his illness. A lot of people only seen him as a ‚Äúicon‚Äù of the miserable artist stereotype, not taking in consideration the skills he had to learn, by himself, to paint what he did. He wanted to do something to be remembered, but it seems people only remember his tragedy, something he had no power in, and I don‚Äôt blame that, it is a depressing story, I can‚Äôt imagine his suffering, but I can‚Äôt help but think how strong he was to still make beautiful coherent and deep artworks. His mental state did obviously affect the way he painted and the consistency, but he did not paint the masterful way he did because of his mental illness. He practiced for years, he suffered through it, but he did, all while managing to express his tumultuous state in his style, but was it his mental state that made him paint the way that it did? The coats and coats of paint, the spirals, the lines and dynamism of his paintings.. was it just because he was sick? I don‚Äôt think so
I‚Äôm only writing this, because I‚Äôve seen so many people talk about him and his story, because obviously it resonates with us, but so many seem to attribute his skill to his mental illness.. I don‚Äôt think he would like to be remembered like that..

comments.author: @tractorhead971
comments.text: An old painter that I knew told how when he was a very young man, tall and energetic with backpack, he explored those parts of France significant to the story of Van Gogh, Arles etc.  He had great interest in VG because he observed many painters handle their paint in a VG manner toward the end of their careers at the height of their powers whereas VG started out that way.  My friend sought insights, he found the light to be wonderful there, he walked locations in hope of catching something in the air, a wisp of a feeling drifting past like a curl of smoke, a glimpsed ghost.  He spoke with older people, many of whom had known VG as a man not merely a myth. My friend was told VG shot himself in the genitals, that this was known at the time but politely and discreetly kept quiet.  If that was just village gossip or the unglamorous unvarnished truth we cannot now know but my friend believed it to his dying day and I can only do likewise in his honour.

comments.text: just from personal experience and accumulated relevant knowledge it it extremely unlikely that he did that himself, aside from all concrete evidence that already points to that. first of all when one uses a gun to resign themselves it's highly unlikely to point anywhere else but the head, anything else would be agonizing and in that age would doom you whether you regretted it afterwards or not and you'd have to slip slowly and painfully into the long night while stewing in regret and guilt. also if someone has a preferred method then they will do that if possible and if not they're more likely to postpone it until they can do it that way rather than doing something they'd rather not do. the act of resigning yourself is a deeply personal and intimate one thus they don't want something that feels uncomfortable (if that makes sense). psychologically speaking I don't see a man that would most rather drown shoot himself in the stomach unless he was forced to, those two methods are just way too different.

comments.author: @minomushi_hitogata
comments.text: I remember my art teacher from college telling us about the misconceptions surrounding Van Gogh, like the exaggeration of the story about his manic induced self-mutilation to woo his latest unrequited crush. She also talked at length about how she firmly believed he was covering for someone wrt his death, bc she was obsessed with him and his art. She was the same teacher who told me I should stop confining my work to small pages/canvases, and said I was much more suited for large expressive strokes on 8-12ft large mediums and was going to assign that to me as a year long project for Art 2. Unfortunately, her class filled up before I could register and I ended up dropping out not long after. Never got the chance to work on such a big canvas or sit with her after class and talk about art and its history again, but hopefully one day I will.

comments.author: @mart-greciaOdalyz
comments.text: For a long time now, I have had the feeling that Vincent did not commit suicide. And, that no one killed him. If it is recalled, around the time of his death, he was working on paintings of landscapes showing so many crows accentuating some hidden statement, (or, so I imagine). Perhaps, the flock of crows became too many to work with. And, Vincent in his frustration and despair, withdrew the gun he must have always carried, and accidentally it went off and fatally wounded him. I say this because where he shot himself, on his side, close to his abdomen, is such an unlikely place to shoot oneself, hoping to end one's life. Dramatically, it is said that his death was a suicide, or, that someone had killed him. But I think the reality of his death was less sensational.

I put my heart and soul into my work 
And i have lost my mind in the process
I often think the night is more richly colored than the day
What am I in the eyes of most people?
A non entity, an eccentric or an unpleasant person
Somebody who has no position in society and will never have
In short, the lowest of the low.

Alright, then.

Even if that were absolutely true
Then i should one day to show by my work
What such an eccentric 
Such a nobody
Has in his heart.

That is my ambition.

Based less on resentment than on love
In spite of everything.
Based more on a feeling of serenity than on passion
Though I am often in the depths of misery
There is still calmness, pure harmony, and music inside me.
I see paintings or drawings in the poorest cottages
In the dirtiest corners
And my mind is driven towards these things
With an irresistible momentum

Vincent Van Gogh

comments.author: @speeeee35
comments.text:
I always wondered, being that he was Christian, self-aware, sober and trying to straighten his life out‚Ä¶ if perhaps someone he wronged in an undeniable way shot him‚Ä¶ and he felt he did it to himself as it was deserved. Like, if he had slept with someone‚Äôs wife (100% making these examples up to be clear) or did something undeniably inappropriate or cruel to someone during a bad moment‚Ä¶.
The children fits too, imo, if they were teasing him (as ppl did- god imagine? Ppl mock artists as odd even today- imagine then? Unmarried and covered in paint, also mentally off? They must‚Äôve thought he was a freak & most were probably unkind to him) or threatening him with the gun, and then accidentally shot him‚Ä¶ I could understand why, especially if they seemed remorseful. Sincerely, he may make a secret of that.
The other option I thought of would be if it were something that he didn‚Äôt want attached to his name like if he had been shot by a gay lover, or something like that. This seems unlikely (that if he were gay, he would meet another gay man hundreds of years ago in a very small town that he just arrived in two months before), but you never know.
Whatever the case, I just really feel like he felt the person either had the right to be this angry at him, or that it was sincerely an accident like in the case with if it were kids.
It seems odd if he shot himself that he would go back to the house and try to get help‚Ä¶ Why not just lay in the field there? Of course, he could‚Äôve changed his mind once he was wounded. 

Whatever the case, I‚Äôve always been drawn to van Gogh, and his story is so very sad. I saw all his works in an exhibit‚Ä¶ Well, not literally all of them, but you know what I mean‚Ä¶ I was shocked by how emotional it made me. I always thought they were cool paintings, but it‚Äôs like they had a magic spell on them or something. he was so talented. Obviously. lol 
At the very least, I‚Äôm glad that it seems like he was happy, and a peaceful place during the last month of his life. And that he was with his brother. Both of those things make the situation much better. Or at least are a small bit of light in a very dark situation. 

Great video 
RIP Vincent- ty for your art  ‚ù§ü•≤

comments.author: @davidgjam7600
comments.text:
All of these conspiracy theories show a lack of understanding about how depression works as a mood disorder. It's less like a tide where weeks or months can be more or less depressed, and can be a lot more rapid, especially for someone whos comorbid with psychosis. Our pattern seeking brains like to weave narritive consistency through someones mental state, but the truth is that most suicides happen in the spur of the moment. Just because someone seemed to be "coming out of it" weeks or days before doesn't mean there's not still a risk of suicide every day for a person who suffers with depression. There are no high ideals when you're alone with unbearable mental pain. Of course this is anecdotal, but honestly so are all of the arguments in this video. These are my 2 cents from a person who's tired of seeing bad hypotheses come from people who can't know what it's like to have a mental illness.

The Van Gogh Museum can say it better than I can: "The recently raised theory that he had been shot by schoolboys is entirely unfounded and can be dismissed."
https://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/en/art-and-stories/stories/the-last-days-of-vincent-van-gogh

replies.author: @ontologicalornithology
replies.text: I've been feeling the same way recently. It's oddly comforting to realize that a huge majority of brilliant, tragic figures labeled 'crazy' in the past were likely just autistic and deeply traumatized. Though their stories often end in suicide, somehow it helps me feel less alone, cradled in the knowledge that others with minds like mine have always existed and will always exist. I'm also deeply grateful to live in a time where autistic minds are becoming more understood, and less vilified.

comments.author: @MuseBitesDog
comments.text:
I went to the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam a few months ago with my mother's childhood best friend for my birthday. I like art. I find a certain calmness and familiarity in it that helps me figure out my thoughts. I went to the Van Gogh Museum knowing very little about Vincen van Gogh. Obviously I knew who he was, because he is a world-famous Dutch artist and he was spoken of frequently in my school, but I never knew his life story. I'm so glad I want to that museum. First of all, his art is beautiful to me. It's so raw, in a way‚Äîthe messy brush strokes, slight imperfections here and there... I could relate to it, on a personal level but also on an artistic level. But I think what really brought me down to my knees and to tears was the story behind all his art. Before he moved to Paris, his art was dark, gloomy, and overall just depressing. (Take 'De Aardappeleters / The Potato Eaters' for example). But then he found France and his art just... lit up. Literally. Vibrant colours, beautiful landscapes... it was all there. And to know he was suffering and struggling so greatly at that time makes me really melancholic. His life story is so deeply sad, I cried in the car ride home, which was also a result of my mother's friend playing 'Vincent' by Don McLean, which to this day is still a song that can bring me to tears with only the first few notes.

Vincent van Gogh was so misunderstood, and it genuinely makes my heart ache. I don't suffer from the mental problems he suffers from, but I do suffer from other mental illness. I wish he could've gotten the help he needed. I wish he was loved by more than just his brother. I wish someone bothered to see him, hear him, understand him. I could talk about Vincent van Gogh for hours on end (if that wasn't clear yet by now), but I won't bother anyone with that. This video was beautiful, and I hope more people will get to see all sides of Vincent.

comments.text: Interesting how much information you've got about him on that day, circumstantial or factual and how his story is being split in two, homicide vs suicide. ü§î I believe Vincent was never as sane and as clear as he was in the moment of his death. Maybe it was just a stupid accident, a child's play in which he protected himself or attacked someone, as usual. Its been established he had a pattern of arguing with other men with physical altercations. Paterns dont stop if we change people or houses. Maybe he, himself was caught off guard in the face of his imminent death. Thats quite a shock to the body and, in trauma mode, the blood takes quick shelter in internal organs. He seemed to have had self injurious behaviors before but never went over the threshold to self anihilate. He sounded quite serene in his statements and, even if suicide was punished by the law, who cares about that when you know you're dying. Gemini people are the type that often appear split, "skizo" or "bipolar", as they look for joy and are usually very social, flirty, have briliant ideas, but when one twin is evil and one is good, the union of opposits turns into a Castor and Pollux story. Take, lets say, his sympathetic bro, portrayed as kind, supportive, a caretaker. Its very hard to care for a mentally ill sibling, but sibling rivalry is often overlooked as is the caretaker's resentment. If his bro was dealing art, Vincent was creating it. You cant have one without the other, Vincent appears to resent his bro. Bro doesn't try to sell his paintings even if he is counscious of Vincent's creative fler. Vincent cant fit in big or small cities, develops alcoholism. Who pays his bills?! The good sibling is not always the sane one, but he might be considered socially sane because he makes money. Mental issues are rather a combination of nurturing styles and environmental struggles. Creative, spiritual people dont actually care about money, and maybe that was considered as unacceptable, to leave life vicariously and just do what makes you üòä happy, Gemini style. Well, I wrote too much üòÖ. Thank you for your work.

comments.text: The story of Van Gogh reminds me of another artist who also suffered from untreated mental health issues named Nekojiru (that was her artist name, not her real one). She was a Japanese mangaka in the 90s, whose works revolved around cartoon cats that would go on weird adventures. They usually featured a lot of dark humor and trippy imagery that were influenced by hallucinations she‚Äôd experience from both popping drugs and untreated schizophrenia. She also suffered from manic depression, had undiagnosed autism, and a severe eating disorder. She would also overwork herself and barely sleep, leading her to suffer numerous breakdowns and eventually take her own life. Her husband continued drawing her works but grieved over her a lot.

comments.author: @creativecatalyst777
comments.text:
In addition to eveything in life very few of you cavalier geniuses miss are simple poisons such as Cadmium (lethal in oil paints especially back then ). Don't feel too bad though because turpentine and various solvents made things far worse and even today many are clueless to such things nor factor it in. Many make it worse, while some make it better. 

Point is there are many factors not being considered which really chaps my ass sometimes, but in reality there is not much that can be done.

This is one reason I factor things into my sales prices. The current negotiating strategies (some cultures thrive on deal making in one way or another ) that create a reaction in me that makes me want to just shoot the cheap tard in the head (not literally, it's figurative to convey a point of anger response the cheap or frugal cultures that are clueless to their cultural destructiveness ). I usually just shutdown and want nothing to do with them. I digress.

Vincent Van Go had many factors, including being a "ginger" (nephillim/Elom/Esau blood liable conspiracies ) which I sure he was well aware of which assisted in self-loathing and concern that he shared with no one. I garauntee he was well aware of it because it reflects in much of his work if you know what to look  at. He was not a big conversationlist. One big irony (having spoken to several Vincent scholars/experts and novices). Very few pick up on it, or blow it off because they think they know better. Same with H. Bosch whose life was not well documented creating so much room for speculation which has also been weaponized by many manipulating values for work. weaponization of everything for artists creates lethal competition by "inspired" artists of then and today.

Another fascinating artist was El Greco who was addicted to his own works to the point that he would break into monasteries/churches or homes of those who aqquired his works to continue working on them to the point of ruining them and he wasn't a popular artist then so his motive wasn't financial. I liken him to the Winchester Mystery House Syndrome üòÇüòÇ‚ù§). My big point is the cadmium, solvents and other possible poisons were not well understood in various eras but still it's rarely discussed or factored in which is yet another reason I shudder when the term "expert" gets tossed around in the artworld.

Being an artist has always been a blessing and a curse, like most life is.

One of the best and most informative movies based on Vincent was "Lust For Life" and even that was seriously lacking but it is still the best Hollywood ever made about him with availiable information.

For my first year college humanities project i chose Van Gogh's, The Starry Night and Sylvia Plath's, Stars Over the Dordogne to compare and contrast. I thought i was takimg an easy route because there is so much information on the painting and the poem was short and straightforward.

Van Gogh's depression became intolerable because he couldn't see the stars. He painted The Starry Night to quell his longing and loneliness for them.

The same thing for Sylvia Plath. After losing her husband to another woman, who he also stole her country home to keep his young hoe comfy in, not seeing the stars as she knew them was the final nail in her coffin. That and to spite her hubby and his mistress. They never knew another carefree moment together. Sylvia's ghost may have only existed in their guilt but she was at every turn and in every breath.
Why do you think people who live in big cities and cannot see the stars are so restless, we can't do without them or the peace felt by looking up to the night sky.

comments.author: @mercy3219
comments.text:
It is interesting to consider the options.  We do try to frame things through logic, but it is surprising how often a strange happenstance interferes with the rational.  I recognized this when a friend of the family, a young mercurial type with a lot of pent up creativity looking for an outlet, told of his adventure.

One day, our friend and his companion discovered a box of 22 shells in the boy's father's garage and stole away with it. When sharing the this find with our family friend, they somehow got the idea that smacking the bullets between two rocks would be fun, or at least a creative distraction to another otherwise dull afternoon. Within minutes, the bullet fired lodging itself deeply into the palm and forearm of his hand.  The boys ran for help and an ambulance arrived in short dispatch where our friend's hand was treated and he was taken to the hospital.  Of course, this story went through about 5 or 6 iterations as our combined families, law enforcement, and the town insurance agent attempted to find how this injury happened. 

The other boy in the story went home and said nothing to anyone per their agreement!  It was curious how a solitary individual might come to the act of exploding a bullet into his own hand which created a town mystery of sorts.  I believe there are often stories like this one that could be discovered given there were proper assurances that there wouldn't be trouble awaiting those involved.  Weird things happen and you are right to be suspicious about Vincent.  His death, like his life, is so much the story of those who don't mesh well with the time and place they lived.

comments.author: @willieluncheonette5843
comments.text:
"Vincent Van Gogh, one of the Dutch painters, could not sell a single painting in his whole life. Now only two hundred paintings have survived out of thousands that he painted, because nobody took care of them. He was simply distributing them to friends; nobody would purchase them. People were afraid even to hang his paintings in their sitting rooms because whoever would see them would think that they were crazy: what kind of painting are you hanging here? People were taking them ‚Äî not to hurt him ‚Äî thanking him, and throwing his paintings into their basements so nobody would see. Now each of his paintings is worth a million dollars. What happened in one hundred years? The man himself was forced into a mad asylum when he was only thirty-two. And he was forced because of his painting ‚Äî he was not harmful, he was not violent, he was not doing anything to anybody. But anybody who looked at his paintings was absolutely certain that this man was mad and unreliable. He should be put in a madhouse. If he could paint these things, he might do anything‚Ä¶.‚Äù For example, he always painted stars as spirals. Even other painters told him, ‚ÄúStars are not spirals!‚Äù

He said, ‚ÄúI also see the stars. I see that they are not spirals, but the moment I start painting them something in me says so strongly that they are spirals. The distance is so vast‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs why your eyes cannot see exactly what their shape is. And the voice is so strong. I am simply unable to do anything else but what my inner being says to do.‚Äù

And now physicists have discovered that stars are spirals. It has gone like a shock throughout the world of painters, that only one painter in the whole history of man had some inner contact and communication with the stars ‚Äî and that was a man who was thought to be mad. And because he was thought to be mad, nobody was ready to give him any service. Every week, his brother used to give him enough money to last for seven days. And he was fasting three days in a week and eating four days ‚Äî because that was the only way to purchase canvas and colors and brushes to paint. Painting was more important than life. He committed suicide at the age of thirty -three. Just after his release from the madhouse, he painted only one painting, which they had prevented him from painting in the madhouse. He wanted to paint the sun. It took him one year. He lost his eyes‚Ä¶ the burning sun, the hot sun, and the whole day long he would be watching all the colors, from the morning till the evening, from the sunrise to the sunset. He wanted the painting to contain everything about the sun, the whole biography of the sun. Everybody who was sympathetic to him told him, ‚ÄúThis is too much. Just studying it one day is enough; it is the same sun.‚Äù

Van Gogh said, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know. It is never the same. You have never looked at it. I have never seen the same sunrise twice, never seen the same sunset again. And I want my painting to be a biography.‚Äù One year‚Ä¶ the whole day watching the sun‚Ä¶ He lost his eyes, but he painted. And when the painting was complete, he wrote a small letter to his brother: ‚ÄúI am not committing suicide out of any despair ‚Äî because I am one of the most successful men in the world. I have done whatever I wanted to do in spite of the whole world condemning me. But this was my last wish, to paint the whole biography of the sun in one painting. It is completed today. I am immensely joyful, and now there is no need to live. I was living to paint; painting was my life, not breathing.‚Äù And he shot himself dead. You cannot categorize him with ordinary suicides. It is not a suicide ‚Äî out of despair, out of sadness, out of failure ‚Äî no. Out of immense success, out of total fulfillment, seeing that now, why unnecessarily go on living and waiting for death?‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI have done the work that I wanted to do.‚Äù Every creative artist has to understand this: the moment people start thinking about him that he is a little bit off center, that something is loose in his head, he should rejoice that he has crossed the boundary of the mundane and the mediocre. Now he has grown the wings which others don‚Äôt have."

comments.author: @pissqueendanniella4688
comments.text:
I'm not taking sides in this statement (i do have my own opinion) however i call into serious question the accuracy of medical reports from the time because: 
1) dude was the town bellacose, no one liked dude and I'm sure authorities particularly disliked the guy
2) his medical examiner refused to let dude get potentially life saving surgery despite the outcome likely being the same either way (he's ded, jim) instead letting him suffer for 30 hours which even by medicinal standards is sadistic 
2a) that being said, if that guy had anything to do with the final reports i cannot imagine he would be overly interested in getting "all the details right" and rather concerned with "ahh let's just toss the body in a hole, kick some dirt over it, and have a laugh at the pub"
3) and this is admittedly pretty minor but worth a mention but as someone one who suffers from: general anxiety, PTSD, bipolar, schizophrenic tendencies (among other things) whenever you're in a heightened state (panic, episode, extreme pain, a combination of all 3) your eyes and brain don't work so good and to me it's extremely likely that in the panic of being shot, failing suicide, and in extreme pain that'd he would have trouble finding his own nose much less a gun at his feet (probably, again dude could have tossed it after shooting for a number of reasons)
4) last point and it's just based on memories from reading about the guy but dude also had failing vision starting in his 20's so by the time he painted start night, the reason it looks so impressionistic is because this is literally all he is able to see anymore, so again bad vision coupled with existential stress, extreme pain, and possibly episodic behavior i can TOTALLY see dude not being able to find a gun at his feet

Great video for sure!! Just wanted to lay out some counter points not addressed

comments.text:
A few years ago I found myself on a bit of a Van Gogh pilgrimage. I was visiting a friend in the Netherlands and spent an afternoon at the Van Gogh museum‚Äî I had already been a great lover of his work, but found myself in tears as I went from room to room, following his life from beginning to end. I was going through Paris on my way home and ended up throwing out all the plans I had and going to Auvers-sur-Oise instead. Spending the time with his work and immediately following it with standing in the room he died in, standing over his grave‚Äî i cannot describe the feeling. 

I‚Äôve struggled with my mental health for a long time‚Äî I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs part of why I feel the way I do about the man. This video was beautiful. Thank you.

comments.author: @Yesica1993
comments.text:
I don't understand why all of this is blamed on "mental illness." It starts off that he was depressed because of a failed love interest. That's a normal reaction. Then, whatever church he was involved with rejected him. He became depressed over that. Another normal response to such a rejection. Then another failed romance. More depression. Again, a normal reaction. Who wouldn't be depressed over all of this? Why is this "mental illness"? 

Then, if he supposedly was religious of some sort, why was he living with a prostitute? Was he simply staying there, or was there a relationship? If there was fornicating with a prostitute, who knows what diseases she may have had? Could that have been a factor? Whatever the relationship, it was his choice to live with this woman. Then he started drinking absinthe. Whose fault is that? He CHOSE to do that. Obviously, that's going to mess with your mind. 

Again, why is any of this  "mental illness"? Seems like he created some of his own problems. But his life is romanticized in this way. What is the evidence that he "found the peace he longed for" after he died? The Bible teaches we die once and then comes judgment. Is there any evidence he had ever repented and received Christ as savior? If not, dead is not rest. It's everlasting damnation. I find that horrifying. 

People need to stop making him into a completely helpless victim. He was not. He may have had his problems, like everyone else does. Maybe some were physical. But he also made CHOICES. And he will be held accountable for them before Christ one day. If someone did murder him, then so will they.

Poor Theo van Gogh. He should be the real hero here. He supported this brother who couldn't get along with anyone and who apparently didn't want to work. But, of course, no one cares about him.

comments.text: Beautiful and painfully sad. He was brilliant like a meteorite burning across the sort of night sky he painted - and as short-lived. His inability to find female love, other than that rented from a professional has always felt so tragic. His mental illness, not understood or effectively treated is another tragedy of his life - and I would never wish such suffering on any person, but part of me wonders: would he have been the brilliant, iconoclastic painter he was, without the loneliness, illness, failures? Would his paintings fetch some of the highest prices ever paid, if not for having suffered through the life he did? Would he be the towering unique genius without all that created & twisted him? Would we talk about Vincent Van Gogh at all, if he'd been better adjusted - more like Theo?

comments.author: @TechTehScience
comments.text:
It's hard to say if Van Gogh killed himself or if it was an accident he tried to shield his accidental killers of, but I have to say it's hard to trust after-the-fact ballistics. Most cases involve people that do not believe Van Gogh killed himself trying to prove prior held bias. It's difficult for some people to believe that a talented individual would suddenly commit to such a deed with little early warning and when things were calming down, or that he would experience regret after the fact. As someone who lost a friend to this, and from accounts I've heard or read of it, typically people do not plan their suicide, it's a sudden decision typically brought on by extreme emotion.

His things getting lost isn't that difficult to explain, nor the gun. This wasn't modern day Europe, it was 1800s France in a small town. It was several miles of unkempt wilderness and fields. If there wasn't a large, dedicated search set up, it would take at most a few weeks for his possessions to become permanently lost and the same goes for any blood. Even nowadays, with far better equipment, understanding, and a far larger population and thus more manpower for searches, we can struggle to find what otherwise might appear obvious in smaller areas.

If the bullet got stuck inside of him, it'd point to it likely having been a flintlock, so the account of a revolver may have just been misconception. A flintlock pistol wouldn't have been very hard to get your hands on in 1800s France, and Van Gogh might've gotten it while he was in Paris. It could've also have been an accidental shooting, not a suicide attempt. He may have prepped it and, without thinking, attempted to holster it or draw it and accidentally discharged it - this happens even today. Even if you were to point to the lack of a powder burn, this could've merely been human error. It would not be far out to suggest the doctor may have merely forgotten; or that it could also be the reddened skin that he mentioned; alternatively he may have not mentioned it purely because of Van Gogh admitting to having shot himself, why state the obvious?

Ultimately, it's impossible to say what really happened, but I feel like this tight grip on the 'it couldn't have been suicide' is a general fear of how unpredictable people can ultimately be. I really do not think there's more here than people wanting to believe there to be more.

It's probably important to note that these people weren't villains. In another life they would have hooned over Van Goghs paintings. It's just that they knew Van Gogh for the person he was. If you were crazy back then, then you were simply that: Crazy. If they had decided to conspire to kill him, it wouldn't have been because they didn't understand him, it would've been because Van Gogh crossed a line.

Sympathizing with Mental illness is great progress on our part. But that doesn't change that sometimes people who are mentally ill can do unpleasant things around people.

comments.author: @jivanvasant
comments.text:
Until this thoroughly researched video, I did not know that Theo van Gogh, an art dealer in Paris, had introduced Paul Gaugin to Vincent. Theo gave Vincent everything he could ask for including unconditional, loving-kindness, total acceptance and deep understanding. Vincent van Gogh and Paul Gaugin were lovers during the years that they cohabited. 
     The forensic ballistics testing of bullets, trajectories and lack of powder burn tattoos, of Vincent's time is the same that was used to investigate the assassinations of JFK and RFK in the 1960s, resulting in the best-evidence conclusions that Lee Harvey Oswald and Sirhan Sirhan did not shoot JFK and RFK, respectively.  
     The third bullet to hit JFK was the kill shot fired at a long range by a French mercenary who was considered to be the best shooter in the world at the time, according to French intelligence services. The bullet that killed RFK was fired by a security guard who had been hired one day earlier. Most people still are being told otherwise by the U.S. government.

comments.author: @herecomemacOnTT
comments.text: Back nearly a decade ago, the Art Institute of Chicago held a Van Gogh exhibit, including the three versions of The Room side by side. But the thing that struck me most was a self-portrait he did; the way the impasto of the paint fell made it look three-dimensional and like the man himself was looking into your soul. Seeing any of his paintings in person is incredible, and he truly died the way he lived: tragically.

comments.author: @Badficwriter
comments.text: I wonder who was the person who was missing their expensive revolver. Why was it left, if the found one was the murder weapon? Van Gogh's whole manner suggests an emotional confrontation with someone he wanted to protect.   The taking of the canvas might have been vengefully destructive.  Or it could simply have been a poor person, slightly deranged, who stole a gun and a canvas, and shot a victim.  Van Gogh's charitable heart might have sympathized and he did not want this poor crazy person hurt by authorities.

comments.author: @JimmyJAKosman
comments.text:
Looking into the eyes of Vicent's infinitely open, vivacious and sensitive portrait filled me with such sadness as can only be manifested by art. Vincent's inner life was in essence a treasure for its esthetic potential it brought out in to the world and minds of many people willing to experience it. He has shared with and is shared by so many. In moments of elation in relationship to his work I am God grateful for bringing forth such life as was given in the form of van Gogh. Perhaps at a quick glance one could call him a martyr of art, though in reality no martyr need truly suffer, even though there seems no other way. If only things had been different for him. I just hope he knew that no virtue goes truely unrewarded even after what one calls death. 
A beautiful video once again Horses, thank you.

At the time of recording this video I was trying out 3 different Bipolar medications - Latuda, Rexulti & Abilify. The diagnosis was brand new for me & I wanted to make a video to help myself not feel so alone, and maybe provide some value to others who were going through the same thing.

ADHD, Bipolar, Autism - all of these symptoms overlap each other. There is no one specific case for everyone & everyone‚Äôs experience with these disorders are different.

Please do not watch this video & say ‚Äúoh I guess I‚Äôm bipolar now‚Äù - that was not my intention. My intention was to express what I was feeling when I got the diagnosis & to see if other people may have been experiencing the same thing.

Yes, these could be symptoms, but it all depends on you and your life. I was at a place where these things were heavily affecting my everyday life to the point where I was not able to function. If that is not you, then you‚Äôre good! üòä

replies.author: @paige_is_a_psychic
replies.text: I was in abilify for four years, starting in middle school. I was severely depressed and was sent to a mental hospital who put me on abilify without consulting my parents and when my mom tried to talk to the doctor he wouldn‚Äôt tell her anything, just that i would be starting some new medications and that i was doing a lot better. 4 years and 150 lbs later I was diagnosed as pre diabetic because for some individuals who take abilify, the Ghrelin and Leptin in their stomach stops working and stops being created. This is not talked about enough! I was 15 years old and pre diabetic because of abilify because i was always hungry (no leptin or ghrelin) and i thought i was doing something wrong. i didn‚Äôt realize it was because of my medication. before starting or stopping any medications do your research!!! abilify changed my life for the worse and caused so many more mental health issues than i started with. (also side note that mental hospital was ass and because of their actions i could be dead if i dint persistently tell my mom that something wasn‚Äôt right, also i am not bipolar and didn‚Äôt need to be on abilify in the first place)

Hey, my name is Jayna Marie Arsenault 42-year-old Bostonian Pansexual Scorpio  Hippie Nudist Buddhist gamer entrepreneur gardener happily married for 13 years. I am currently living sober at my parents house with ADHD, PTSD and Bipolar II and my doctor is still tweaking my medicine a little bit because I was in crisis 3 weeks ago. I didn't know which way was üëÜ, but the increase in my Lamictal 200mgs bid, Wellbutrin 200mgs bid, Lexapro 30mgs in morning, Gabba Penton 300mgs bid, Tizazidine 4mgs every 6 hours as needed, and Prasosin 2mgs 3 bedtime and take that with the Trasidone bid at bedtime. I have been trying out medications since I was 16 honestly most of my 20s/30s I don't remember because of how meditated I was and now my medication is starting to help me be myself without the side effects feels a lot better than I was younger.

comments.author: @Mosfer_aldoseri
comments.text:
This makes about 0 sense, you know why? 
Bipolar is characterized by 2 poles, 2 states, depressive episodes and manic/hypomanic episodes. Most people with actual bipolar have periods of stability, and they tend to have longer periods of stability or depression compared to mania/hypomania. Mania is very apparent and isn't very sustainable, while hypomania can be less obvious to others, but not necessarily less destructive. 

The shit he has in the video are personality traits and that's according to the DSM-V not to me. 

Having more than 4 episodes a year is called rapid cycling, which isn't that common. So if someone's mood changes throughout the day, it's not really indicative of bipolar disorder. They must be distinctive episodes, not happening at the same time or based on how your day is going so far lol.

Uf your psychiatrist diagnosed you with bipolar disorder when you don't have this episodic pattern, then I recommend you get a second opinion. If you, like the guy in the video, was told that those are symptoms of bipolar disorder, then you're really should get a second opinion. 

I always say shitty behavior because of wrong personal beliefs or bad habits, isn't really a sign of mental illness, or personality disorder either, in many cases. You should definitely get checked out by a professional still and not self-diagnose from TikTok videos. 

It's wild that you were led to belive these are symptoms of bipolar disorder. I hope you're doing well now, and that your psychiatrist took into account more than what you mentioned here to diagnose you

replies.author: @Mosfer_aldoseri
replies.text:
Also highs are highs and lows are lows when they happen in episodes, not changing according to something you heard said about you or you read on Twitter. This must lead to a change in functioning which is uncharacteristic of the person when stable. 
"Highs" means mania, in bipolar 1, for at least 7 days or hypomania, in BD 2 or 1, for at least 4 days. 
While "lows" means episodes of depression with symptoms similar to those with major depression.

comments.author: @shirley_graves1138
comments.text: Hi, my name is Shirley Graves. I was diagnosed with childhood  bipolar disorder almost 3 years ago. Im not here to say I know EXACTLY how you feel because bipoler disorder impacts others differently. But I thought I should shear my story with you.  I have been struggling with bipoler disorder my whole life and I know this because I was originally diagnosed with childhood bipolar disorder when I was 3 years old and i was put on Lithium  it made me hallucinat so my mom had them take me off Lithium and got a second opinion on my diagnosis and of course diagnosing childhood bipolar disorder is rather difficult so the second doctor told my mom I didn't have bipolar disorder and that I was just "a typical kid" who had behavior problems..so for 16 years I've been living with childhood bipolar disorder untreated until I had my first massive manic episode at 18 but wasn't officially diagnosed until 19 because I ran away from home during my manic episode and didn't come back for 6 months...when I finally returned home my mom took me to a psychiatrist after my 19th birthday and they first tested me for schizophrenia because bipolar disorder and schizophrenia link together along with autism which I also have mild autism...I'm now taking abilify and it has been the best medication for me so far but like most meds it has its limits I still struggle with mood fluctuations but not as bad as it used to be. But as far as how I felt when I was officially diagnosed at 19 I felt so low of myself worried about what other people would think..my self-esteem was extremely low for the longest time and im still stuggling with my self-esteem but I try to keep in mind that it doesn't matter what other people think..because this is who i am and who I will forever be and there is nothing I or anyone can do to change it and if there are people who don't accept me because I'm labeled "crazy" then that's their problem because I can't help being bipolar no one can help it it's something you are born with. So you are not alone and I hope you find the right medication for you that will best benefit you in the long run being bipolar is no joke and it is hard to live with.

comments.author: @CthulhuJax
comments.text: I literally have every single one of these traits--except for the profound mood shifts/cycling; and I do not have bipolar disorder. As a health care provider, with the passage of time, social anxiety, generalized anxiety, and self-esteem issues are becoming less and less specific to mental health conditions and more and more typical of human nature--unfortunately. What separates bipolar disorder from these things is the significant up and down swings in emotional lability, and the length of time spent dwelling in those highs and lows. In today's world, we have much more specific diagnostic criteria...though, arguably, the DSM V is outdated and could definitely use a nice update.

comments.author: @KathrynJ
comments.text: It's high sensitivity. And it can also be trauma symptoms. Bipolar is a good label for it as well but stay away from pharmaceutical medications!! They do more harm than good and are a scam from pharmaceutical companies trying to trick people into becoming addicted to the meds so they can profit billions of money. It's the TRUTH. They've brainwashed well-meaning talented psychiatrists (and other health workers) with false unethical guidelines. The mental health meds can be amazing sometimes as well, I know someone who has severe psychosis (hearing voices) and he said his medication reduced the voices so it's helped him so much. But they're way over-prescribed. Anti-depressants are a scam and so are 'mood stabilizers'. You can't fix high-sensitivity and bipolar. There are usually other more effective and less risky ways to manage symptoms.

comments.author: @jenifernadeau
comments.text:
Chasing diagnosis are a distraction to purposely avoid looking and beginning the true healing. no need to label someone as schizophrenic or bipolar or anything in that regard, all of that is just maladaptive responses to Childhood trauma and neglect. Something as simple as a parent not defending you consistently creates trauma in a child and that gets carried into adulthood and morphs us into being that we were not intended to be. If a parent cannot provide a solid stable consistent emotionally balanced Foundation within themselves, within the home and outside the home for the child to thrive and feel safe, we have experienced emotional neglect. People have no idea how deep that goes and how it has shaped us into who we are. We are accountable for providing ourselves with whatever our parents could not provide us because they themselves have not done their healing from their childhood neglect and Trauma and wounding. If we have low self-esteem it's because our parents did not provide a solid example that was consistent, parents have no idea that the energy they give off is what the child responds to, not their words but definitely also their actions. The energy of all that is hidden within a parent who has their own internal issues is what that child is sensitive to.‚ù§ stay out of big farm in the medical system because all the side effects of those pills will create exactly what you are taking them initially for. The answers are not in big pharma. The body needs to heal itself and dealing with the repressed emotions and wounding is how you can eradicate and heal the illnesses in the body including physical illness., children are extremely intuitive High vibrational light beings, and they sense things parents could have no idea about. parents put on a wonderful show because typically they are not often completely authentic genuine and transparently honest at all times. That will fragment any child.üò¢ no matter how good their intentions are, if they had not done their own inner healing and Shadow work , the next generation is impacted. 

The term bipolar is utilized just like any other label in the medical field to slap different drugs into people. Because the side effects are what the medical system is designed to actually promote, to keep you in that system and making the system money. The goal is not to eradicate the root cause. Then they lose customers. The more we look for care and concern or a validation or accolades or unconditional love outside of our self, the more we have outsourced our power, and we already have all of it.... Within us.üòä look within versus externally and focus on the self because it is self-preservation and the most healing thing you could do for the World by putting yourself first, becoming your own best friend, loving alone time with yourself and healthy ways, and providing daily self-care and self-love routines by following what you love to do as a child, that is where your abundance lies. Can only work from the inside out.‚ù§

So you've identified all these issues in this video and ask why they're there? They're not supposed to be there because the body is designed to be in the moment and at peace. How can you create balance in your life? How can you practice cultivating and honing trust in yourself, your intuition and your sense of self that was never allowed to be created properly in childhood, perhaps you were parentified, had immature parents or ones that inappropriately spoke about things that never should be spoken about in front of a child. When we can see our parents as the truly flawed individuals that they are and the family system as dysfunctional as we didn't realize it was, which does not negate any of the other things that we wanted to focus on that appeared to be good or happy or healthy..... then you are seeing the whole picture. But first and foremost, we must Unconditionally Love all the parts of ourselves without judgment. What you are experiencing externally is a reflection of what's going on internally. Everything is projected and is a mirror back to us as to what we can heal within ourselves.‚ù§ if you are not being hated and you don't have to tractors and you are doing something wrong. But being overly focused on the world around you is a distraction from doing that inner healing.
