comments.text:
Have it too!!! With my right meds finally after 20 years of trying every phyc med there was. Now I‚Äôm stable more often than not and I still get episodes but not to the extremes we normally feel them. 
More ppl have bi polar than you know. It‚Äôs hard to get properly diagnosed with bipolar. Most times if you actually go to the phyc ward you are having a break of some sort or I had to go while switching between meds a couple times. But most of the time most docs there basically abt 2 hr max. Depending on how many patients they have. You don‚Äôt get more than 10 min if you‚Äôre lucky with him/her.
There are many things that go into getting the proper diagnosis. Most of the time a lot of ppl come out with a diagnosis of depression. Well from what I understand to put a person with bipolar on just an antidepressant it makes our mania worse. Then it starts a nasty cycle. Your meds will make you feel like crap (side effects) sometimes but plz talk to your doc about changing it. But whatever you do DO NOT stop taking your meds. Even when you feel better. You feel better cuz of the meds. And every time you stop you have to start ALL over as though from the beginning.  If you feel that you or someone you know have these symptoms contact the local hospital for a directory of the phyc docs in the area.

comments.author: @leslierae6416
comments.text:
I got diagnosed with bipolar 2 back in 2009. I had been misdiagnosed with anxiety and severe depression by my GP and was prescribed medications to treat those conditions, which made my bipolar disorder SIGNIFICANTLY worse. I had been on a wait list to see a psychiatrist for over a year at that point, my mental health kept declining until I woke up one day and just decided ‚ÄúI‚Äôm done‚Äù. I cleaned my room top to bottom, removed all the art from my walls, I packed all my clothes from my dresser and closet into black trash bags, I packed all the books on my shelves into boxes along with everything else. I took the sheets and blankets and pillow cases off my bed and washed them, dried them and folded them and put them in the trash bags too. I stacked all the boxes and bags in my closet. My Dad thought maybe I was just reorganizing my bedroom, as he was leaving the house to run an errand I hugged him and told him I loved him, and then I went to the upstairs bathroom, locked the door, I took a large quantity of a specific substance and took a bath, it was 3 pm. 

I‚Äôm not going to go into all the details, but my Dad got hit with ‚Äúa really bad feeling‚Äù when he was about two blocks away from the house, he turned around and came home. I woke up in a hospital about two weeks later, I had been in a medically induced coma. I was finally moved up the waiting list and was paired with a psychiatrist, and after some testing I was diagnosed with type 2 bipolar disorder. It took a long time to figure out the right meds and the correct dosages, and I had slip ups, and some in patient stays, but I haven‚Äôt had a significant manic or depressive episode(or even really mood swings) since 2012. It took allot of work, allot of patience, allot of consistency, allot of trust, allot of love, allot of sheer will to get to where I am today, but it was worth it.

comments.author: @Imalecchambers
comments.text:
I think this needs to be said..

At the time of recording this video I was trying out 3 different Bipolar medications - Latuda, Rexulti & Abilify. The diagnosis was brand new for me & I wanted to make a video to help myself not feel so alone, and maybe provide some value to others who were going through the same thing.

ADHD, Bipolar, Autism - all of these symptoms overlap each other. There is no one specific case for everyone & everyone‚Äôs experience with these disorders are different.

Please do not watch this video & say ‚Äúoh I guess I‚Äôm bipolar now‚Äù - that was not my intention. My intention was to express what I was feeling when I got the diagnosis & to see if other people may have been experiencing the same thing.

Yes, these could be symptoms, but it all depends on you and your life. I was at a place where these things were heavily affecting my everyday life to the point where I was not able to function. If that is not you, then you‚Äôre good! üòä

replies.text: I was in abilify for four years, starting in middle school. I was severely depressed and was sent to a mental hospital who put me on abilify without consulting my parents and when my mom tried to talk to the doctor he wouldn‚Äôt tell her anything, just that i would be starting some new medications and that i was doing a lot better. 4 years and 150 lbs later I was diagnosed as pre diabetic because for some individuals who take abilify, the Ghrelin and Leptin in their stomach stops working and stops being created. This is not talked about enough! I was 15 years old and pre diabetic because of abilify because i was always hungry (no leptin or ghrelin) and i thought i was doing something wrong. i didn‚Äôt realize it was because of my medication. before starting or stopping any medications do your research!!! abilify changed my life for the worse and caused so many more mental health issues than i started with. (also side note that mental hospital was ass and because of their actions i could be dead if i dint persistently tell my mom that something wasn‚Äôt right, also i am not bipolar and didn‚Äôt need to be on abilify in the first place)

replies.text:
Bipolar isn't like a blood test. 'Testing negatively' isn't quite how it works. She could still be bipolar, and the doctor could've just got it wrong. And yes, the antidepressants should absolutely be taken into account when diagnosing

My mom has it. It wouldn't surprise me if I did.

Unfortunately that spot happens to be my frontal lobe. I'm able to do stuff and think but I struggle with analytical thinking multi step processing  my reasoning center& memory because I have epilepsy on top of it.  I forget things alot. Its frustrating. I think that's  probably whats going on with me. Mental illnesses in general make you prone to a host of other symptoms that are similar despite the disorders being separate entities. 


Other people in the comments are right a lot of other things can mirror each other its best to let a qualified medical professional diagnose & figure out whats going on & how to help.

replies.text: @@ankaisdead again... it does not just "go away."  It can only be MANAGED and/or MAINTAINED.  With LIFELONG therapy and medication.  Its not as if you do a few rounds of some therapy, take a round of anti depressants, and then youre cured and can stop.  It's a lifelong illness, that requires a lifetime of treatment.   I'm not trying to be offensive- just truthful. üëç.     (My mother is severely bipolar, my brother was schizophrenic. So. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è.)  It's nothing personal against you!!üëçü´∂.   It's dangerous to say that it can "go away"...... because it's very common for people with bipolar to stop taking their meds when they "feel a little better", and then they spiral again. They think they don't need the meds anymore- but they really do.    So.  I'm just sayin!!!!  It is VERY dangerous for them, and for the people around them, to say that it "goes away"... bc it can encourage them that theyre fine now, and dont need anymore help. Its incredibly dangerous.  So. comments.author: @PokemonGoViolette
comments.text:
Honestly, people have to realize that any symptom or personality traits, as much as they might relate to everyone, THEY HAVE TO HAVE ONE EXTREME OR ANOTHER to be worrisome. If you have any symptoms like these at an extreme form, that‚Äôs when there is cause for concern. And if a person thinks that they have a mental illness, even if they don‚Äôt have symptoms at an extreme, it‚Äôs best to talk to an actual psychiatrist about this to see if there is anything unusual going on or if they are not mentally ill.

Ps. I have MANY diagnoses including bipolar disorder, which is why I‚Äôm speaking up. I want people to be aware of these mental illnesses and learn that they are not something to take lightly.

Mental illness is very crippling for many people with actual anxiety, bipolar disorder, adhd, depression, ptsd, ocd, did, autism, etc. It is not a joke and should stop being thrown around like a joke. It is very angering to see that people are using these terms so lightly, making it seem like it‚Äôs nothing while we actually suffer badly.

replies.author: @elwoodenchanted
replies.text: He is saying they are his symptoms, yes. However, we have seen this type of content on TikTok again and again being used as grounds for having tons of people self diagnose with serious disorders. By this point, content creators need to take into consideration how their content will be interpreted. If someone wants to make content like this they need to include either more specific disclaimers to discourage self diagnoses based on short clips about personal experience OR they need to give the content additional time & info to make it actually educational...

comments.author: @lacil8895
comments.text:
As someone with adhd, who has lived with someone with bipolar ...these symtpoms are really vague and can be applied to many other disorders. The most telling sign ( in my most unprofessional opinion) is how others around a bipolar person are treated...especially those closest  to them.  They're always deflecting and feeling shame and tend to direct it at anyone close. 
They can't can't control their rage at a particular person (even when they're clearly in the wrong). That's the big one. Being on the other end of this deflection and rage really hurts.. if anyone's noticing that others are scared of them or tired around them...that could be more helpful in beginning to recognise other symptoms. The guilt and rage gwt worse and worse if unmanaged.  Never base your diagnosis on advice online though..always go to a doctor. Always get professional and medical opinions. All best.

replies.author: @Genni4862
replies.text:
Gotta be honest, rage part fits more in line with borderline. Many borderlines are misdiagnosed as bipolar, unfortunately- or as cptsd in men- which is a whole other sexist rant I could get into, but I digress.
As someone with bpd, the rage is more intense than other people realize. It burns you from the inside out- it consumes you. And it is taken out on those closest to us. Generally our fp, or favorite person. We put them on a pedestal, and when they inevitably fall from it in our eyes (who wouldn't, it's not fair to expect perfection of course!), we switch completely to anger at them. It very much sounds like you were dealing with a borderline.
Just want to add that we are demonized online and in rhe mental health community in many ways, so I hope no one takes this comment as more of that. We can be incredible humans, we love deeply and its far more common for bpd people to be abused, than to be abusive. But, we can absolutely be terrible at times, and its our responsibility to recognize and work on this.

I never really thought about wether I could be bipolar because the symptoms I have line up with my other diagnose, so I never questioned it. I just been bouncing from one anti depressant to another, trying all sorts of med changes because every one im switched to just always make things 100x worse. Dude seriously, thank you. Maybe I can get things under control now after I bring this up to my doctor.

replies.author: @AbbyLaporte
replies.text:
yeah, actually, bipolar is very serious and it's definitely worth asking based on what you've described. a big sign, for me from what you said, is your paradoxical reaction to anti-depressants. Most people with bipolar cannot take any SSRI because it makes us manic. So like, yeah. bipolar is almost more medical than other disorders, in a way, if that makes sense.

Good luck. It's a horrific roller-coaster, but it's better to know earlier and learn how to manage it. Also, luckily, not a choice or a fine line. It's a much more clear cut thing generally, but type I the most. So yeah. Wishing you well, be safe, and take good care.

comments.text: Sounds more like bpd to me personally. I have bipolar and events don‚Äôt ruin my ‚Äúweek‚Äù. Not how brain chemistry works but a personality problem . Nothing has to happen and usually doesn‚Äôt , for me to lay in bed for WEEKS to months . The worst things could happen and I‚Äôll be giggling through them feeling like a superhero. Also I‚Äôve noticed many people with PDs call themselves empaths or says they feel others emotions. Do you really or are you projecting what you think they feel ? Many ppl with Bipolar are misdiagnosed ~ rapid cycling is another name for ‚Äú you prob have  bpd‚Äù. All my bipolar folks here can relate to going to bed after a week of being productive, social, hyper, paranoid, reckless and impulsive and waking up depressed as fuck and unable to exist for weeeeeks-months, forgetting all the times they felt happy, ghosting their friends, laying in bed , crying without reason-literally just crying when things are objectively good or fine, and feeling as though the pressure of the world is immobilizing their body. Sooo, with that being said, I don‚Äôt know you , I just want people to get proper help. It‚Äôs always best to have a psychiatrist diagnose you .. log your moods as well. If you see a long trend of the same highs and lows , weeks - months of being normal with no symptoms, you‚Äôre prob bipolar.

It's very important  to get diagnosed properly...most won't. Why do I have this opinion? Being with someone with unmanaged bipolar was utterly life destroying. The right diagnosis, as early as possible...is the only way to get through it.

comments.author: @4RRevVen0m_KawaGingaSaki
comments.text:
Lol for people saying ‚Äú99 percent of people feel this as well‚Äù or also ‚Äútrue for normal people‚Äù is yes most mental disorders the general public experience. Take happiness and sadness for example: everyone does at time feel one or the other of this feeling. When you have bipolar it is way out of proportion it is a chemical imbalance in the brain and when your ‚Äúhappy‚Äù it is SO intense. Like you may as well be on meth or cocaine bc your really talkative and excited and so much motivation, barely sleeping no need to eat food. However, on the flip side‚Ä¶ when you are sad‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not just feeling a bit hurt or crying. It feels like yo u just found out your whole family has been mass murdered, like your chest is being concaved in and your heart physically hurts. The smallest bits of criticism you hear will send you deeper and darker into an unwanted place. Maybe you will start fantasizing about all the ways you could off yourself. And sure maybe other disorders (major depressive disorder) has this. But the difference from different disorders and bipolar is literally that ‚Äúbipolar‚Äù meaning TWO polar opposites. You have EXTREME highs (mania/hyper mania) and EXTREME lows (depressive). There is two different types of it as well type 1 and type 2. You can feel the extreme highs for a day to months at a time and then have extreme lows right after. 

Sure, some might be a little vague and for anyone reading this never self-diagnose. Do your own research though and do tests and if you really feel like a disorder is impacting your daily life and affecting your work or relationships, please go visit your family doctor and literally give them situations that have happened, symptoms and proof on why you think you may have something and they will guide you in the right direction.

replies.author: @benplayz7694
replies.text: Yes, you can have other comorbidities (more than one illness or disease at the same time). I'm diagnosed with bipolar II, adhd, severe anxiety/panic disorder, ocd, insomnia and c-ptsd. Life is a struggle every damn day, even with meds. Some don't work well and others have really bad side effects and it complicates it, all the more. I'm finally on a somewhat stable med regimen...alprazolam, lamotrigine, and adderall. It's trial and error with the meds and there's other things alongside the meds that may help (exercising, therapy, etc). It was hell going through college and even harder holding jobs...especially, as I got older, relationship difficulties, drug and alcohol abuse,etc. Personally, the times that I feel best are when I'm hypomanic and/or hyperfocused.

replies.author: @essennagerry
replies.text:
There's the spirit and the spiritual things, but there's also the flesh, and the flesh is both the quasi strictly physical things and also the mind. Our thoughts have a literal physical expression in our physical brains. It's not ALL spiritual.

Also, if you think it is, how do you know what? Please introspect. This is not what the bible teaches. The bible doesn't teach that every mental thing is a spiritual thing. Infact it teaches there's both spiritual reasons and "the flesh" as a reason.

I've been Christian my whole life. The world is comlex, life is complex, and the enemy in the spiritual is trying to make things even more complex and confusing than they already are. We experience physical mental illness and the enemy uses that as a vulnerability and attacks us spiritually too so we deal with both. But when you take care of the spiritual you still have the physical to deal with. And sometimes it's only the physical and sometimes it's only the spiritual.

For about a year I struggled with depressive phases which only got more frequent, longer and more intense overtime. I completely got rid of those and very quickly at that through just solely spiritual warfare. So that was only spiritual. I have ADHD, ADHD is not inherently an illness or "bad" but it can cause a lot of issues if a person doesn't know they have it, doesn't understand it, doesn't manage it appropriately. All of the ADHD issues I had and still have are just physical. There's nothing spiritual about it. Yes, God still helps with those things which are only physical and He's helped me with ADHD issues too. He's a God of the physical and of the spiritual, not just one or the other. But it's important to know there is a distinction between the two. They can br connected and they are connected but they are still distinct and failing to recognize thay and built a basic understanding of that is highly likely to cause you to mismange your own health or harm others, or even abuse others. And fail to solve problems, both problems based in the physical and in the spiritual.

I would say my issues with stress are an example of the physical and the spiritual mixing.

So I dare say I've experienced all three versions - something that was quasi only spiritual, something that was only physical and something that was mixed.

There is an entire book in the bible dedicated to wisdom. God definitely values wisdom and emphasizes how important wisdom is for us humans. I believe God delights in the work all types of doctors do because it's a work of love.

I stopped smoking and I drink less coffee. I feel more controlled now, but I still get really depressed with panic attacks and then I will also feel really happy. The information I find is so confusing. Sometimes I‚Äôm not sure if I was misdiagnosed and I‚Äôm really just going through a hard time or I am bipolar and it‚Äôs just normal to me.

replies.author: @AGsosa
replies.text: How did you get diagnosed? Do you have to pay to find these things out?

replies.author: @ringaboo549
replies.text:
I had to have a few visits with a psychologist. Originally it was to see if had adhd. Which I do. He also stated that I had a mood disorder. 
Each season costed around $100. It‚Äôs best to call your insurance company and see who‚Äôs in their network. It can be tricky because me and my psychologist thought the appointments were insured, but then when the bill came, I had to pay the full price.

replies.author: @iwonderwhatmydognamedme4000
replies.text: @@DimitrisK_1924 He did not mention anything in his video about having any kind of hypomania or extreme mania hence why I‚Äôm assuming he‚Äôs being misdiagnosed because the main signs of bipolar are the manias‚Ä¶.he would have definitely mentioned that because it‚Äôs definitely not normal. Without them you do not have bipolar. You must experience atleast one mania to be properly diagnosed with bipolar. (This is a fact you can look it up) A lot of people think ‚Äúoh no I‚Äôm experiencing being happy and then sad through out the day I must be bipolar!‚Äù They have no idea how truly bad it is and what other symptoms come with it. It frustrates me that this mental illness isn‚Äôt taught or focused on more. Everyone is accepting and understands depression and anxiety but when it comes to bipolar people don‚Äôt realize it‚Äôs just as bad as schizophrenia (when you have bipolar type 1 in some cases) it‚Äôs such an awful mental disorder that you cannot just live with. So a lot of ppl self diagnose or get misdiagnosed and it‚Äôs frustrating!!!

comments.text:
Most artists do not have mental disorders but can suffer days, weeks and months of minor depression. Human emotions do not live in the common 3d world.They live in a world much harder to express to our common 3d world than just simple thought.Thought has been created by society over thousands of years in order to better survive, reproduce and make pleasures. It is no more our reality than our emotions. Thus, always the struggle to create the emotional world reflected into the 3d world so others may find the same pleasures or sometimes abominations.

 It is a complicated crossover to try and communicate a world that society created into the minds to be more simplified world and existence. "Seeing" in the arts, has greater meaning than simple visual. The art of communicating greater values and information that the socially created world left out for simplicity purposes and of coarse capital gain on others.

comments.author: @returnoftheromans6726
comments.text:
Honestly, the obsessed artist trope is my favorite. Creative people are some of the most depressed and self-tortured souls I know. I should know. I am one of them. Vincent Van Gogh was one. Christina Rosetti, the poet, used scissors to cut. We are filled with the pain that perhaps others feel but can't express. 
I can't hear about people getting hurt. I literally feel the pain as if it were my own. The nail pierced my own flesh. I hit my own head on the table. My imagination is just too strong. I can't help but imagine it. Then I grow faint. Some may call it a weakness, but it is really a strength. Empathy is so sorely needed today.

I would like to share me experience.

replies.author: @daniellebrown1597
replies.text: You have so much time. Don't worry about it too much. I have known since I was in high school that I wanted to pursue art, but due to parental influences and other things, I chose to pursue an undergrad in the sciences. Well, it's been a hard few years doing something I didn't enjoy. School has always taken such a big toll on my mental health. I am graduating in a month with this degree I could care less about, but I am finally pursuing art. This is something that often feels so impossible, even to those of us doing it. I still constantly doubt myself, but I know that I am doing what makes me happy. If art is what makes you happy, then go for it when you feel that the time is right. Don't feel like you are wasting your life away. It will come when it is meant to come to you <3 Take care of yourself :)

comments.author: @jairolondono6824
comments.text: In schizophrenia and bipolar disorders, we have damage in the frontal cortext, making it really hard to plan, make decisions, pay attention, among other things, so the brain rewires itself in a pathway that it's seen in highly creative individuals and cause out of the box thinking and a flown of ideas. That's why we've seen many poets and writers; musicians and painters with this disorder throught history. Mental illness is not always a condition for being creative, but madness and brilliance always go hand in hand since ancient times. Actually, I read that even good writers that are not mentally ill, enter temporary manic states when they're writing a novel. I find this subject truly fascinating and I'm very happy that arts have always been there to comfort sad and solitary souls.

comments.author: @LivingDead53
comments.text: I'm not good at art.  My icon represents my struggle with impressions.  My brain sees reality as something different, something that can be more than one and ordered incorrectly.  I painted it to try to explain what was happening. I'm diagnosed schizophrenic.  I bought paint and canvases and tried to explain it to other people, mostly my grandma.  Words fail sometimes.  My painting (icon) is called, "Religion."  It can be a caveman,  Plato's Cave, Jewish, Pagan, waves or birds, eternity or lies, the apple of Eden, and, when turned upside down becomes the devil with the fruit of an evil womb.  The yellow sun looks up or down.  Please excuse my poor art skills.

comments.author: @bluemusej
comments.text: I think we are all drawn to people we either do not understand at all, or those that we can understand b/c all of us have every potential within us save some depending on the human being.  Today I think art is used in nefarious ways, though, with hidden meanings and, well, the paramount being largely on the monetary.  We no longer just love paintings, etc. b/c of what we see, but what we are told to see and how to interpret it.  For some, performance art is also a huge super ego function, whereby they believe they are a conduit for mediums or other things, but I'm suggesting it comes from a selfish intention if you have power and from a caged one (being controlled) if not.  Art neither the artist is something to be worshipped neither to be indistinguishable from objectivity or to serve a specific cause, but that is what it seems to have turned into - both to society and the underpinnings of it.  It's harder to trust, therefore, harder to appreciat.

I feel like so many famous artists have works from when they were dad because sadness and depression is such a deep, cutting emotion. It's easy to depict and show because you feel it so strongly. I find it easier to create when I'm emotional and typically, I can only show sadness because I have the time and the emotions right there. When I'm depressed, I retreat away from people give me time and space to make something. When I'm happy I want to spread my happiness with others quickly, before it passes, so I don't create anything.

comments.text:
Not all artists have mental illness, not all those with mental illness are artists. 

What I think is most interesting is that as an audience, the most emotional pieces (especially with  "negative" emotions) often speak to us at a deep level and we remember them differently....

I have PTSD and major depression and a good amount of my art is about these feelings. When you deal with these feelings daily, possibly for your entire life, you have a lot of time to ponder negative thoughts. At times, they are consuming, so of course my art would reflect that. Also, painting is my way of releasing these feelings. It feels easier than doing so in words or conversation (usually, lol!)

comments.author: @AelitaUndomiel
comments.text: This is not a stereotype at all. It's obvious that artists are people with a lot of imagination, but those who had suffer in their life, have a further view. They can use it in art and express their feelings through it, even as a therapy to overcome bad things. If you look closely, in the paintings you can see some details that reveal "disturbing" things in the artist's mind. Van Gogh is a perfect example. In other cases, it's very explicit, like Frida Kahlo. In music, you can notice it in the lyrics or the sound. Something alike happens with literature, or even scenic arts; the body language. Every artist's mind is a maze, basically. Sometimes they find the exit easily, sometimes not.

comments.text: What a load of rubbish. Complete and utter nonsense. So you're telling the world that the process of creation is related to "Mental Illness". In terms of the gamut of human cognition, this is that far from normality that it doesn't even rate a mention in the scope of creative reality. And I am prone to thinking now, that the poster of this video may have some connection to the mental health industry and or the drug companies that espouse a "Proverbial" cure. comments.author: @Magdalenasfears
comments.text:
I have bipolar 1 and used to sleep around a lot. Crazy thing is I'm asexual. I didn't even enjoy it. No idea why I did it. Also used to get into fights with strangers, would go days without sleeping, drank and took mdma all the time, worked 5 jobs and went to school... than I'd crash into my depression. And it was bad. 

I was misdiagnosed and incorrectly medicated. I stopped taking the meds they gave me, dropped out of college and became an otr trucker. Long hours, unpredictable conditions, and it forced me away from people, drugs, and alcohol. About 15 years after these cycles started I was correctly diagnosed and it was one of those moments where you felt like an idiot for not seeing it sooner. Once I knew what was going on I was able to implement safety nets in my head (I know this isn't how most people are. It's my personality. I'm a very tackle things head on person. Like I was phobic of needles, so I went and got my phlebotomy license lol).

I'm now in my masters program to be a mental health counselor.

comments.text:
Bipolar Stats:

If you have Bipolar your risk of STDs and pregneacy increase greatly due to hypersexuality

50% of people with Bipolar 2 have a substance use disorder, and 60% of people with Bipolar 1 have 60%. Usually to either calm down or disinhibition.

70% of people with Bipolar 1 experience psychosis at least once in their life and its rare that someone with Bipolar 1 will never get admitted to a hospital.

They are three different types of mania, hypomania (mild mania), mania (severe mania) and mixed mania (depression and mania mix together)

Bipolar 2 episodes have less severe mania but TEND to happen more. Bipolar 1 episodes trnd to happen less often, but are more severe.

Its mainly a genetic disorder and onset for bipolar 1 is 18 - 22, Bipolar 2 is usually diagnosed later in life due to it being not as obvious.

This is why I am actually greatful that I spent my 20's in denial about my Bipolar diagnosis I recieved at age 15. I actually forgot about it until a couple years ago. I'm 33 now and was just rediagnosed, along with CPTSD. Not having something to blame my struggles on forced me to have to work on the way I was showing up in the world. The ways I was hurting myself and others. Forced me to go inward and I was able to realise a lot and become someone who takes accountability for my actions and the effect they have. It was when I began to realise that no matter what I did, I was not well mentally. I was, in truth, mentally ill. So I sought help. 
Mental illness explains why a person acts a certain way, but it is not an excuse for hurting others carelessly.

replies.author: @fighterflight
replies.text:
That‚Äôs like saying you‚Äôre glad you didn‚Äôt accept your cancer diagnosis early on because otherwise you wouldn‚Äôt have learned to work out and eat healthy when you were younger. Babe, you can and should do both at the same time. 

Mental illness is a physical brain imbalance requiring treatment and medication, not a personality trait. You can accept your diagnosis without using it as an excuse to hurt people. Also, newsflash: until you accept your diagnosis and start treating it, you are going to keep hurting people. And not on purpose. It‚Äôs involuntary. 

No one should be setting the precedent that people with untreated mental illness have the ability to control their thinking and behaviors. You control it through treatment and developing insight. Some would argue the only way to take full responsibility and prevent hurting other people is to get on board with treating your illness ASAP. 

People who accepted their mental illness early on and started treating it are typically further along in that process, not falling behind. Speaking from experience.

comments.author: @christinehodges6
comments.text: I am so sick of this over generalized concept of bipolar disorder when probably 60% of those diagnosed really have borderline personality disorder, which can have a lot of overlap. If you haven't experienced at LEAST a full consecutive 7 days of mania that wasn't drug induced, then it's not type 1. Bipolar II is frequently diagnosed in people who actually have BPD,  because of the impulsivity, shifts in mood/irritability and up and down energy. The difference is that a hypomanic episode is a consistent episode for at least 4 days, while BPD are the folks who seem to change every hour. Please stop using bipolar (and self diagnosed PTSD) as some way to justify your selfishness, overall instability, mood swings, self harm and self destructive behaviors.

replies.author: @LaBamba871

@@jenniferporter6466 I have Bipolar Type 2. I have experienced extreme states of euphoria, but never full-blown mania. I wish bipolar 2 was a more widely known thing 10 or 20 years ago, because it would have given me so many more answers to my past behaviors. 

Also, in the free & low income clinics with inexperienced therapists, some of them STILL have not been educated that there is more than one type of bipolar. So part of the problem is also that our mental healthcare system is still completely incompetent and underfunded.

comments.author: @AgxntAqua
comments.text:
It sounds like she is talking about a manic episode. She should really be more specific about this. 

A lack of remorse and empathy is not a diagnostic symptom of mania. We experience a delusional ignorance of the suffering we are causing. I think people who become legitimately sadistic or malevolent are that way by nature, and the mania removes their inhibitions,  so they act the way they do. The statistics bear this out. 

People like me who have this disorder have a responsibility to educate themselves and speak candidly but carefully in public. Be a representative, not a stigamtizer.

It absolutely is though. During mania it is very common for emotions to sort of take the back seat. Let‚Äôs not act like when you‚Äôre manic you are the most considerate person on earth‚Ä¶.. 

Literally 3 years ago and I still can‚Äôt believe the shit I said and did when I was manic. Lol. In that state it‚Äôs easy to be agitated over small things‚Ä¶ and your judgment and conscience are also hampered so your reactions are generally more extreme. It‚Äôs easy to just dismiss these things as shitty behaviors‚Ä¶ which they undoubtedly are,,, but the person in the drivers seat is very not mentally well. You literally lose your mind for a little while. It‚Äôs pretty harrowing and I tell you living with the regrets is pretty painful. All the more of an uneasy feeling looking back when you know in your heart that person that did them was just not you. Not the real you. You feel miffed or something? Idk it‚Äôs hard to explain but it‚Äôs very unpleasant

comments.author: @PioneerOceanÂçÅ
comments.text:
It's hard not to succumb into the overwhelming force your bipolar mind/body makes you go through. I was a ticking time bomb and always questioned why in rage/frustration, now that I know what to watch out for, I take steps when the highs and lows hit. Sometimes, I want to scream and rip myself out of my body during my lows but I soldier through it until it passes... while I spend my excessive energy on my highs but makes sure to keep myself in check. It's severely exhausting mentally, physically and spiritually. There's no way I can keep this up till old age, all this stress and active fight or flight will kill me before I hit 60. I'm not sure if I should be glad I've got type 2, since I went through a full blown psychosis like type 1... I really feel for people with type 1. 

Update: To all my sisters and brothers, turn to Christ and He will give you rest. [Matthew 11:28-30 NIV] "Come to me, all who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light." Look at the creatures and even the stones all around you, they seem to know what to do and live but why are we lost? They all praise GOD, turn to Christ and He will give you foundation. [John 14:6 NIV] "I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me."

replies.author: @lilyjane1011
replies.text: Could you please give me exampleq of highs in bp type 2? I 'ever found a consensus on what I have. They've all disagreed. Leaning towards type 2. I've Never had mania. Not sure I ever had hypomania. I am sensible to certains kind of stresses. Suffer from d√©pression and anxiety since I 've been a teenager. Thank you!

replies.author: @AletterofImportance
replies.text:
I am diagnosed type 2, I thought people couldn't have psychosis if they have type 2? I mean I'll have rapid cycling mania and depression that lasts for a week depression, week mania, etc. but if I don't stay on top of my sleep schedule, I can become really crazy. Like I can't even recognize myself. One time I thought my best friend was stalking me, but she literally wasn't. Another time I thought animal abuse was an orange. Like really freaky stuff. Is this really type 2 or is it type 1?

I am diagnosed type 2.
Anyways my experience with the highs is, Sometimes, I think I can do anything, I talk to everyone in sight, my heart beats a mile a minute, I think I am invincible, make a lot of friends, create a whole bunch of stuff with my hands, take on way too many things to do. It's not that I'm incapable of shame during this faze, but rather that my brain can't focus enough to process, it's whirring a mile a minute. 

 IF it goes on too long, I get paranoid, and explode to everyone around me, preaching, screaming, crying, etc. I'll get the restlessness and unable to think like euphoric mania. I'll also get shivers, rant at everyone even blank walls, and have paranoid emotional explosions. Usually they're directed about something. I've had one where it was about nothing at all, and I couldn't stop, and I didn't understand why it was happening. So I would say the explosions are a combination of what I am afraid of happening, and mania, and depression at the same time. Usually when this happens I can't speak normally, words don't form correctly. 
I think this stage is like a nightmare where all of the logic is gone from your brain, all that's left is just the fear and pain. Because the euphoria has left, but everything else from mania is still there. 

 Then my lows look like catatonic major depression where I can't move.

The thing is though all of this can be manageable, the most important thing is me recognizing that I am manic before I cause damage. I made a personalized quiz for myself that I take every day, to tell if I'm manic. I also take it if I'm wondering if I'm manic or the second stage. If I am manic, I take a trazodone and sleep it off, and avoid people so that I don't react paranoid to a "fear" or something, or explode at someone and regret it. Exercise, avoiding caffeine, and eating regularly is something you should do all of the time to prevent mania. Anyways, yes I am manic, I looked this vid up to get tips for it. hehe I type a lot when I'm manic. 

I'm getting better at managing it, but yeah it sucks. :)

I can't tell you since mental conditions are complex and many people often get misdiagnosed, but I do know BP2 gets more depressive cycles... which is what I'm dealing with. Sorry I can't make things any better for you, but I can at least tell you that you're not alone in this hell and you're not some psycho

replies.author: @AletterofImportance
replies.text: I mean comorbidities though? Peeps with Bipolar are very likely to have other coexisting disorders. A lot of the time those go undiagnosed, because it takes multiple times of knowing someone to diagnose it. For example, when schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are combined, it becomes schizoaffective disorder, but so many people only get one diagnosis or the other.

replies.author: @JenniferHales
replies.text: @AletterofImportance¬† Could be. My ex had schizoaffective bipolar disorder but was only recently diagnosed with the schizo part. Then again, his psychiatrist didn't think that that sort of behaviour was connected to his schizophrenia but only his bipolar disorder. It's not a bipolar trait, though, as medical professionals never say this. It's just some patients who do this. Perhaps patients who exhibit these behaviours have other disorders, but we don't know. As for what I saw, when he was having a manic episode, he would steal or break the law almost on a "high" and didn't really understand how or why I was horrified by it. He'd make purchases or do things that was not like him at all.

replies.author: @AgxntAqua
replies.text:
‚Äã@lilgreenjellybean You are specifying that you were manic. As a good faith measure we can assume this lady just failed to mention that she was specifically talking about mania but that is a big distinction.  

I can only speak for myself but when I was manic I was only vaguely aware that people might not approve of my actions. I would justify things so strongly in my head that anybody who disagrees with me must have ulterior motives. So actions I took that looked calloused were often done out of a delusional ignorance. I was never being purposefully malevolent, and if i was doing something unsavory, I would always convince myself that it was actually in the victims best interest. 

I do believe that intent matters. Otherwise  I would be a pretty terrible person about a 1/3rd of the time. And that doesn't really make sense to me.

comments.text: I‚Äôm late diagnosed Autistic, and for years I‚Äôve said I can understand his words and paintings. His immense connection to religion and the poor, combined with reverence for nature. Meltdowns and angry outbursts, followed by philosophical and intense  moments of awe.  Highly focused work sessions followed by exhaustion. Not to mention the trauma of being rejected, ridiculed, and in survival mode. I‚Äôm 53, and I can tell you the longer I‚Äôve gone unsupported, the more intense my burnouts and grief have become. So very glad for this documentary.  (I do suspect there were other issues, but fully support the autism theory.)

This guy seems driven to label all brilliant and/or creative people as insane when in most cases those he so labels were victims of alcoholism or syphilis or drug abuse of some kind. Syphilis  was extremely common before the discovery of antibiotics, alcoholism common in the art and literary worlds and drugs quite common in the theatrical and film worlds. Not that mental illness does not exist, but he seems to want to put it forward as the root of creativity. Hardly. 
Most artistic people are born  artistically gifted and such people live for their art - they care little  for society‚Äôs pomposity or its silly standards and norms  I‚Äôd suggest he study art history, starting with cave paintings.

comments.author: @lornahuddleston1453
comments.text:
Yes, a combination of things rather than one diagnosis. His diet sucked. He did seem to be extreme.  His utterly clutsy pursuit of women who found him abhorrent makes me laugh. But it's obsessive, and has no basis in reality. His objects (and I do mean "objects") of poor Vincent's ardour are more like projected upon statues, not actual people. 
And his parents treated him like shit. And yes, this is about a wildly dysfunctional family! Vincent was made the identified patient, or scapegoat who carried the family shame. And yes, if Theo (pronounced "Tay-o" drives me nuts when everyone mispronounces the name ü§™), if Theo did not exist, nobody would have ever heard of Vincent van Gogh. Theo was Vincent's bridge to interacting in this society. Judgmentalism was  rife, and especially prevalent in  Protestant Dutch Reform. Sensitive children were likely to be destroyed by the puritanical and evangelical missionizing and pontificating that were the norm.

replies.author: @professorgraemeyorston
replies.text: I agree, rigid communities don't do well with people who are different.

comments.author: @lornahuddleston1453
comments.text: Vincent's father tried to have him committed. His father was constantly lecturing him. I'm reminded of the Underground Man in Dostoyevsky's Notes From Underground, He's  never good enough, and simultaneously, he is right about everything. There's an internal battle raging.

replies.author: @professorgraemeyorston
replies.text: I'm sure his father thought he was doing the right thing in trying to get him into the Gheel Asylum.

comments.author: @lornahuddleston1453
comments.text: Very interesting that maybe Vincent had syphilis. That could explain a thing or two. I find myself wanting to know more about Vincent's minister father. That the van Gogh's settled in a historically Catholic part of Holland strikes me as audacious.

replies.author: @professorgraemeyorston
replies.text: Syphilis can cause almost any symptom or combination of symptoms.

comments.author: @chrisleblanc581
comments.text: His color choices and texture fixation are common with certain types of schizophrenia, or at least that is what was taught to me in a course where I had to learn to score art being used to asses psychological conditions and state of mind. I did not follow a clinical path, so I‚Äôm not sure how valid it is. But I do know that several times I have seen art on colleagues office walls that struck me because if color and textural peculiarities. When I asked about the artist, it was always a family member who had experienced psychotics breaks.

replies.author: @professorgraemeyorston
replies.text: There is no association of particular colours and textures with schizophrenia, I'm afraid that was just wrong - but there has always been a lot of speculation about schizophrenia and it remains poorly understood.

comments.author: @lawrencecataldo7397
comments.text: Thank you, Dr. Yorston, for the empathy I've been blessed to witness in the four or five documentaries I've watched so far. Living with major depressive disorder and generalized anxiety disorder has been challenging at times but never to the point where I felt I should complain. My situation is well managed by medications monitored by a gifted person/psychiatrist. I am saddened and amazed at how people coped before the science caught up. Both of my children inherited from me, most likely, their own mental health challenges, but like you said in the Van Gogh episode, these do not define us, and I have preached that since we knew what was taking place. Bipolar 1 and BPD. They are doing well and havelarned the do's and dont's just as I have. There is life with mental illness...good lives are being experienced. I thought you might have a look at doing an episode on the tragic, brilliant, John Kennedy Toole, legendary author of the cult masterpiece "A Confederacy of Dunces". By far, the funniest and saddest book I've ever read. I believe that your treatment of Toole's short life which ended by suicide, would be celebrated by the countless people who never met him but love him just the same.

comments.author: @blogblogblog-dj5ed
comments.text: I think you are correct in putting the Gaugin walking out incident together with the letter from Theo. I think the double loss pushed Vincent over the edge but he mostly cut off his ear to get attention from Theo because it was Theo he needed the most and it was Theo's marriage he felt most threatened by. It worked because Theo came running. It shows a slightly cunning side to Vincent's desperation as he knew he had to do something drastic to drag Theo away from a woman he was about to marry and to keep the money coming. I believe he was still capable of calculating in this way even during episodes that he had no memory of the next day. Even serial killers, though seemingly incapable of stopping killing, can still demonstrate extreme cunning and caution even when leaving a body totally destroyed due to the frenzy of their mental state.

comments.author: @EggWomanInStrawberryFields
comments.text:
I LOVE your videos! Thank you, Professor. :) They're so well researched, delivered in a direct, calm and engaging way and seem far more documentary-like than so many other channels.I love how well thought out your diagnoses are - basically never committing to one alone and conveying how difficult it is to diagnose when not in person. I feel like so many love to jump on a diagnosis and then block out all other options - I find it infuriating! and can be so much hype to engage the audience (does the opposite for me). At the same time, your approach doesn't come across as wishy washy, but as an expert in their field.

Some artists I would be interested in include: Egon Schiele, Gustav Klimt, Yayoi Kusama, Hundertwasser, Vali Myers, Jim Morrison, Alexander McQueen. Whatever takes your fancy! Tell your son thanks for pushing you to make these! Jajaja. :)

This was the best documentary I've seen about Vincent. You really covered all the possible illnesses so well. I do also believe that he  was on the autism spectrum and that together with his other bad habits he got that ill. It's also possible for autistic people to get depressed because they feel like no one understands them. 

Vincent has left a legacy and I so wish he would know this. As I also have to deal with something, I know for sure that painting gave him relieve and joy. In the end this is what matters - how we focus on the things we love and also surround us with people who care without judging. And being grateful for every happy moment.

comments.text:
That was an excellent documentary, thoroughly absorbing.
I have been an amateur student of Vincent's life and work for about the last fifty years, have visited many of his painting locations including Arles which is still a beautiful city, he chose well to live there, I made those pilgrimages as themes for touring holidays.
One interesting coincidence is that I was born exactly 100 years after Vincent.
You showed me a lot of new material that I did not see or know of before, you must have been a very thorough researcher. I shall look for more videos by you Sir!

comments.author: @amitabh15
comments.text:
Van Gogh had Visual Snow syndrome. I suffer from the same condition. I see what he saw, the condition is all over his artwork including afterimages, flickering, palinopsia, visual snow, ghosting. The mental aspect of it comes in waves of hope and sadness. It‚Äôs a neurological disorder, not psychiatric. I‚Äôm surprised researchers haven‚Äôt figured it out. VSS comes with anxiety, depression and most importantly ‚Äúagoraphobia‚Äù, suicidality, rage, suicidality.

It‚Äôs a functional neurological disorder, which can come in waves or flare ups. With it, feelings of hopelessness and suicidality increase dramatically.

‚ÄúStarry Night‚Äù = Visual Snow + BFEP

Extremely rare condition, can be very difficult to live with. Madness and rage is characteristic of it. It comes with a condition called ‚Äúhyperacusis‚Äù and DP/DR (everything feels far away).

Periods of mania, is not bipolar. It‚Äôs bouts of rage from traumatic memories, and looping thoughts.

GERD is part of the condition.

All of this is one condition. Not a group of separate conditions. The underlying cause is childhood trauma, head injuries that incite danger, fear and terror.

https://www.visualsnowinitiative.org/diagnostic-criteria/

comments.author: @annaponting7693
comments.text:
I think  that his life would have run a similar course even if he sold 100 paintings. He was totally aware of how important his work was. In terms of it was like a story that HAD to be told. Selling paintings would have been gratifying in terms of his dependence on his brother. But would they ever have been free of the emotional tie? Would his disorders dissipate? I think it would have made them worse.
I am sure he was tormented by a number of disorders. But your description of Epilepsy as well as Autism Spectrum disorders both sound good candidates for the list. (only because they are the ones I have experience of) Especially the way he could launch from peace to apparent psychosis then return to painting as if nothing had happened. No expert and I can truly understand why nobody really is. Much respect for all your work here.

comments.author: @virginiasoskin9082
comments.text: Very well done. I have a BFA in Painting and M. Ed. in Art.  When I taught art, it was always difficult to try to explain Van Gogh's mental illness, especially to middle schoolers who always immediately wanted to know all about the ear removal ( I was teaching art 40 years ago).  Your autism spectrum speculation (not very familiar to the general public back when I was teaching) seems like a good one because it would explain his difficulty with establishing lasting social relationships, with family, colleagues in the work place, art professors, other painters.  When he was trying to be a missionary to the peasants he made more enemies than friends.  I think he was desperate to make friends and felt that hanging out in cafes or around brothels was one way to casually meet up with people, find sitters for portraits among the cafe workers and townspeople like the post master.  I think he was happiest when painting; he was able to forget himself and become one with the act of creation.  Hours pass when absorbed in art work.  I often wonder if Vincent had remained alive for another ten  years whether his work might have been noticed and BOUGHT by patrons.  But Theo died so shortly after Vincent did, that his money stream would have dried up.  I think Van Gogh is such an appealing art figure because of his brilliant use of color and the energy so evident in his work.  Just this evening my husband was reading a headline on his cell phone about the fact that in Starry Night Vincent was painting wind turbulence.  No other artist has done that that I can think of -- maybe in The Raft of the Medusa or some ocean disaster......others think he may have had imperfect eyesight which caused auras to appear around stars and interior lamps and lights, and that he painted those auras as he saw them.   In art classes in public school, we generally focused on four artists each year from grades 6-8.  So our students knew 12 artists in depth by the time they moved on to high school.  Van Gogh, Rembrandt, Andrew Wyeth (we were in the USA), Leonardo, Monet, Seurat, Michelangelo, and others.  I loved teaching those artists and the kids enjoyed it too.  I always hoped that in future years if and when they had the chance to go to Paris, London or Amsterdam, they could visit a world class museum and have some knowledge of what they were looking at.  Thanks again for this.

comments.author: @slowneutron6163
comments.text: The fact that he had issues did not make him a great artist. There is a myth that genius=pain. It doesn't. I love Van Gogh's work. I know his damned life story. What makes an artist is a compulsion to be one. Not insanity. Simply desire. SOMETIMES our issues serve as inspiration. But Van Gogh would have been a great artist with or without his crippling depression. I wish people would stop playing up to the mental illness angle of his work. And his painting were nowhere NEAR as 'DANGEROUS' as Goya's 'Black Paintings'. I am a rather accomplished artist. I've sold my work world-wide. I'm no Van Gogh. But I'm no slouch. I suffer from bi-polar depression. It has no effect on my work. Excuse, let me correct that...I actually DON'T like to work while in the midst of mania or profound sorrow. In my case, it's a hinderance. Just tired of listening to people yammer about tortured artists. There were plenty of completely sane ones whose work I'd rather own....like William Merritt Chase or John Singer Sargent. Van Gogh will ALWAYS have my admiration for his work. His colors and brushstroke are a staple when I reference the impressionists. I just don't care about his personal anguish. He would have painted the sunflowers even if he was the happiest guy on earth. The misunderstood angle is complete and total bullshit. GOOD DAY.

comments.author: @Foxiepawstotti
comments.text: I really feel badly for Van Gogh. He had an awful time of it, I think he may have been overly sensitive as he behaved as if things really haunted him. I was thinking about the causes for mania and the "supressed ulcer", I think you are taking this as being a stomach ulcer and in my opinion, they may well be talking about a skin ulcer like leg ulceration, which could, if not attended to, cause blood poisoning or at least a reaction to a septic ulcer which could cause delerium and other mental symptoms due to high fever and toxins in the system. I saw my sister have a terrible reaction to a vaccine before going on a trip with my marine engineer father, which required us to be vaccinated for Africa, South America and other places (we circumnavigated the world). Even though I was 15 at the time and ran away as soon as the GP next door took her in hand, she was screaming,  bashing her head off the wall, running around and talking to people who werent there. You could hear her from the bus stop up the road, it was the scariest thing I ever saw and most probably, in the early 70s, would have even then been called delerium or mania, I can imagine in Van Gogh's time there were many things that could trigger high fevers and the symptoms of such.  I have what used to be Aspergers and wondered if he had something along those lines as he seems not to read societal cues awfully well.  What you said about delerium was exactly what I was trying to explain about my sister's reaction to anti cholera or yellow fever vaccine (we both had both of these the same day but an hour apart, with me expecting the same to happen to me at any moment!).

comments.author: @patriceortovent3337
comments.text: It is very sad and most annoying to keep the story that Van Gogh did suicide by shooting himself with a pistol in the field where he was supposedly painting. Van Gogh did not shot himself, he was shot maliciously by one of the youth gathered as a small group not far from the place he was staying in. The altercation took place just at the outskirts of what was then the small provincial town of Auvers sur Oise. He was on his way to the field with all his equipment to paint. Van Gogh was constantly mock by the youth he would come across been understood by them as a mad man and a derelict . The youth of shot at him by bravado used the pistol taken secretly from his father who was working as a security gardian in circus. Van Gogh never had a firearm nor did he had any money to buy one. Furthermore, Van Gogh still had some energy left in him to return to his hotel which was a short distance from where the shooting took place. The story that he shoot himself in the field cannot stand since wounded as he was he wouldn't have the strength to come back with all his equipment to the hotel where he was staying. Van Gogh didn't talk to the police about it, he had his reason not doing  so, perhaps he reacted to the youth in such a way that it ended being shot more as an accident that a deliberate act of killings. The tragedy is that the art world stick to the story of suicide since it made the biography of the artist even more dramatic with a grand finale of a suicide. The youth who shot Van Gogh was well know in the village to be eccentric and showing off in the group. The best part of it is that when the man was on his death bed he confessed having shoot Van Gogh, although not intentionally but out of bravado and understood the all situation as an incident. The boy was just a teenager then. So, even that many people understood that Van Gogh did not shot himself and some very few biographies mention this fact, the story stuck officially since it made Van Gogh an even more tragic  figure. There was no need to hide this fact about Van Gogh but like many stories taken for true while they are not, the landing of men on the moon is one out of many, we are continuing to lie to ourselves and to others like politicians do around the world, and like it is said the bigger the lie the more probable it will be accepted and believed by the population at large. If one is to take time to read all the letters of Van Gogh and there are many, not once did he talked about suicide even in the darkest and most tragic moment of his life. Van Gogh was too much of a creative mind to think of death, he certainly didn't look after himself health wise due to his poverty and some ignorance about what drinking and smoking can do on one health, the end of the 19th century was not brilliant about such reality, that's said, Van Gogh used alcohol to numb the pain he was dealing with mentally an physically but this doesn't amount to a conscious drive to destroy himself. Once Hollywood took under his hat to make a film about the artist, things got even more out of reality, but what to expect from Hollywood one may ask.

If you take the different life outlook of autistics, compared with the apparently neurotypical, is there any truth in the notion that autism is better identified by clinical psychologists? comments.author: @robbiemitchell1601
comments.text: Thank you from South Africa for an interesting account. It is amazing that so great an artist lived a tortuous unrecognised life in his own time. Somehow one's heart goes out to him. There is an interesting link between the Artist and the Free State province of South Africa, where I live. I will just relate it from memory, but the facts can readily be googled. A younger brother of Van Gogh volunteered to fight on the side of the Boers in the Anglo Boer War. Van Gogh had given him a painting of the younger sibling and his sister playing in a barn. Cornelius carried the painting with him wherever he went when going to war. He was wounded near Brandfort (now named Winnie Mandela) which happens to be where I was born. He was nursed by a Boer family but was eventually sent to the British field hospital at Brandfort. The painting was kept in a coffin for some time, a convenient place of storage in common use by the Boers, its presence in an attic, or barn, being a common precaution in case of need in a country of vast distances and travel at the pace of an ox. Cornelius succumbed to his wounds and was buried in the military Cemetry at Brandfort. The painting was said to have been discovered and adorned the wall of a Free State farmhouse for years. It has since disappeared. With the passage of time, many farmhouses have become derelict, the owners being bought out by more prosperous neighbours. I often wonder what the fate of the painting was. No doubt, its value could support the purchase of a multitude of farms.

comments.author: @ZadenZane
comments.text:
Whatever else was bothering Vincent Van Gogh i think the core of his problems was some kind of psychotic mood disorder that nowadays would be labelled bipolar or schizoaffective disorder.
I know some people really hate his art but i think part of the problem is that his output was very uneven. He didn't seem to keep "sketchbooks" as such and there were no canvas boards back then, no acrylic gesso that you could slap over cardboard and paint oils or acrylics on top. He had to make a full oil painting on canvas or no painting at all. Some of his interior scenes like the picture of his bedroom and the one of a pipe on a chair look amateurish to me, but others like like the crows on the wheat field look like masterpieces. Also he died pretty young. If only he'd lived for longer we could have had even more masterpieces!

comments.author: @MsTaylorsArt
comments.text: This was very VERY interesting indeed!! I always thought that Van Gogh had Epilepsy. I have Epilepsy myself and have mental illness in my family. Mary Queen of Scots is my 11th great-aunt which makes me related to King George lll who was mentally ill. Not to mention Prince John who died from Epilepsy, which was the exact kind that I have. Anyway, Mental illness and Epilepsy are completely different. The only thing they have in common is that they both take place in the brain. Although I did love his paintings, Epilepsy is why I always found Van Gogh so interesting. The only time anything that is described here happened to me was years ago when I was on medications that came with those side-effects though. New medications had been made to try on me but sadly some did come with HUGELY life changing side-effects. It makes you realize the beauty of life itself. Still, I can honestly say that I can not relate to all of the things he did, etc. Epilepsy alone could not have created those behaviours. Being poisioned now that could create such behaviour. It's noted in this documentary (perfectly and very wisely I might add) that his acting like he did started before eating paints, etc. I've been through ALOT but I can't even IMAGINE! How horrible!  Have researchers studied this because it's kinda obvious to me that he probably didn't have Epilepsy. The ONLY thing that even points to convlusing seizures is when they put him on a bed in the hospital. Did his doctors actually put Epilepsy on his file? I always thought they did! Am I wrong there?! The other thing that kinda points to Temporal Lobe Epilepsy was his fascination with Religion. Temporal Lobe Epilepsy does open up the part of the brain that understands Spirituality. That creates an interest in things like Religion, Spirituality, etc. Did his doctors also note if he had any control when they had to tie him to a bed because that could have been a mental fit, which is completely different than a physical seizure. In most physical seizures you lose consciousness all together. Your body just continues to convulse without your approval.  Most of the things noted from him only come from a mental disorder and Epilepsy is a physical disorder. Epilepsy can cause a mental disorder but not one that creates those issues. It usually can just create Bipolar or a form of anxiety. It does happen in the brain but is not a mental disorder and people need to realize that. I know the difference because I have extreme mental disorders in my family. Obviously in my ancestors but also in my close family. How that sort of thing can travel for years and not just go away, I have no idea. Why it would choose my family out of I don't know how many related to the Royals is beyond me and also REALLY just bothers me to no end! Getting off topic, I apologize. Sadly though, I know exactly how some DO infact judge even today. It is often assumed that those with Epilepsy have some sort of huge mental disorder and aren't able to think correctly. That people need to stay away from them and that they're evil which is absolutely untrue! Not to mention just wrong and beyond hurtful. That's society though. Van Gogh no doubt had Bipolar but the fact is Bipolar doesn't come with all of the things Epilepsy comes with nor the things that happened to him. I'm no doctor but I don't believe that even the worst cases of Bipolar come with cutting your ear off, etc. Personally, I think he had a very very serious mental illness but as I said, I'm not a doctor so I can't claim to know what it was. I do know that this documentary is wonderful!!! Thank you for making it. I have to note one more thing. A theory made years after someones death is great but it's not proof of anything. Again, amazing documentary and thank you for it!

comments.text:
Poor Vincent !  My heart aches for him.
  I'd like to offer a possible explanation of some of Van Gogh's mental health issues. His mother's apparent critical rejection of him, and her finding fault with    everything he said and it sounds like, hating everything he did, would damage him from his early childhood on, and into adulthood. So I think he would  have learned confusing and negative  ideas about love. Or even about what love really meant.  No wonder  his adult relationships failed.  It seems as if she routinely treated him poorly . In my experience    Dutch Protestant family culture tends to be judgemental, cold and without compassion.

replies.text: We don't know if she treated him differently to her other children or if she was still grieving the loss of her first child.

Dear Sir, I would like to give you my compliments for this production. Next to all the known facts about Van Gogh your medical view gives a sober look on the person. Breaking the myth off the tormented painter, separating the ill from his work. Giving the work the value off its own. Living in Amsterdam, i am well known with the work, all tough the fare better works are exposed in the Kroller-Muller Museum near the town off Apeldoorn.
There he really masterd painting. As an Art Historian  i am familar with Van Gogh and indeed in literature it lacks a proper medical approach.  You filed in this gap. As mental ill painter am i lucky to live now and apply medicine.
Further mental ill artist i would like to suggest: Wilhelm Lehmbruck.
By the way, are you standing in front off the Kershaw edition off Hitler?

Best regards,  Drs. Y. Houttuin

comments.author: @sherkinbrain
comments.text: Autumn 2023 I visited Arles, Saintes  Maries-de-la-Mer, the asylum in Saint Remy, and Auvers-sur-Oise. Finally, I visited the exhibition of his 'final works' at Musee d'Orsay in Paris. All of this over a six-week period. For me, the overwhelming  experience was entering his reconstructed bedroom in the beauty of the asylum surroundings. When I visited the cemetery in Auvers, it was early morning - there wasn't another soul to be seen. I asked myself: 'where should the grave be situated? I saw the early morning sunshine point the way, and without hesitation, turned to my left. Within 30 seconds, I found the ivy-covered burial site.. I lay my hands on both headstones and shed tears. Tears of joy and gratitude.

comments.author: @claudiabothma
comments.text:
A totally engrossing documentary, thank you so much.
Being an artist myself, I have a love/hate relationship with my gift.
Although I have sold many including a tryptich in the ANC boardroom, peoples reactions to my work has after many years, eroded my love and passion for it- to the point that I don't put them on my walls or where I can see them.
They frustrate and anger me now.
Of course I understand that people want realistic artwork, and even though I understand the small mindedness, it still affects me.
Having temporal lobe epilepsy I have to fight depression and a loop tape of criticism in my mind and heart. My Psychiatrist is loathe to put me on too much meds as she says it will eradicate my creativity.
The irony is, my creativity has eradicated my creativity.

Funny analogy though, as a toddler and child I would be given hidings for drawing on my dolls and walls and ultimately, I would get paid for it.

comments.author: @martinkingston1498
comments.text: I chanced upon this study of Van Gogh's life, and it has definitely given me a far greater insight into the inner workings of this very brilliant, but tortured man, an artistic genius without whose wayward path those remarkable works may never have come into being. It does make one wonder if we would even know of him at all if his early trajectory had resulted instead in a happy marriage, or a more successful role in the church? He clearly was searching for the intimacy borne of physical union, a sense of connectedness, in addition to a deeper metaphysical transcendence, and the anguish of those early denials/ rejections must have weighed very heavily on both his heart and head.  Add to this the terribly chaotic nature of much of his adult life, and the sense of failure he felt. It must have been torment for someone with such an incredible artistic vision, the constant fear of poverty, loneliness and madness. This piece on Vincent was beautifully and sensitively done. It's the least he deserved.

Dr. Yorston;  I loved your thoughts about Vincent and Theo.  It was empathetic and filled with kindness.  The conference to establish what Vincent's illness was might have come to a solution if each participant had no ego. You were right, though,  what mattered was what Vincent accomplished despite his limitations and disabilities.   And looking at what he accomplished fills my heart with awe.  Vincent's paintings alone tell us the entire story of Vincent.  
    You told a very loving and beautiful story fairly portraying Vincent.   I sincerely appreciated your effort.

comments.text:
Was blessed enough to see the best exhibit of my life in Philadelphia many years ago. It was the long awaited exhibit of all of the Van Gogh memorabilia, letters, sketches, etc. All of which were held by the son of Dr Gachet, after his death. I never felt so close to VVG as I did, seeing so many personal effects. Even the white cap worn by Dr. Gachet in that very famous VG painting of him, seated at a table with sprigs of foxglove in his hand. 

Your documentary was wonderful. His life is like an onion with many hidden layers, twists and turns, and still coming to light.

Your documentary was wonderful. But I must ask you about something about Theo toward the end of the video. You mentioned Theo had neurosyphilis. Did I hear that correctly? I was positive Theo was a solid, dedicated and loyal husband.

comments.author: @janedoe5229
comments.text: Who kills themself by shooting themselves in the stomach? Everybody just says he killed himself, and so everybody believes it.  Van Gogh was writing happy letters to Theo and had ordered more paint. Van Gogh did not have a gun, and a gun was never found. He did not kill himself with the first bullet, then why did he stagger back to his place, over a mile, instead of shooting himself a second time?  Van Gogh was right-handed, and the wound was on the left side of the abdomen.  No powder burns were seen on his hands or his body, indicating that the gun was not close when it was fired. A prime suspect is Ren√© Secr√©tan.  He was a bully and liked to dress up like a cowboy and play with a pistol that frequently misfired. Vincent was already a social outcast. Rene and his friends were known to play pranks on Van Gogh. An eye-witness woman said that Van Gogh was not painting in the wheatfield that day, but walking on the road. When the people of the town were interviewed in later years, they said that young boys did it.  Van Gogh was too kind to rat them out.

replies.author: @professorgraemeyorston
replies.text: This is a popular theory, but far less likely in my opinion. And the gun was found, it is now in a museum.

comments.author: @tracya.schneider7698
comments.text:
I LOVE your summary...that an illness,  physical or mental, should NEVER define a person...

I have mental illness in my family...and I myself have anxiety and depression.  

I thank you for trying to debunk the art historians' saying his use of color, brush strokes and way of seeing his subjects/landscapes/rooms/still life are all due to his "insanity."  He seemed to me to be a VERY sensitive person who felt deeply,  whether feeling insufficient to his family, misunderstood by (ALMOST) everyone,  and unloved by the men and women he tried to love.  So sad...people who are constantly rejected can never find their center of confidence.  We all need to have reciprocal love.

replies.author: @Rebelartist83
replies.text:
@@professorgraemeyorston oh yes I agree with you and I don't work there anymore due to health reasons same reasons I don't do art as much as I used to..( dexterity things with my hands)..but my old boss Dr.Callahan at the University of North Texas autism center....van Goh was one of his favorite artists as well and some times we' d talk art ( other artists we'd like and their stories) and he always surmised Van Gogh was on the spectrum as well..but he thought too possibly OCD/ADD/ADHD..but he also knew given the horrible conditions of mental asylums and the horrible ways patients were treated..he thought van Goh had some personality changes from a few concussions and " psychiatric treatments" on top of ASD..and the led poisoning theory and alcoholic psychosis..but given the food hygiene practices of the victorian era which weren't good at all maybe he did have scurvy or jaundice or both but if he ate poor quality food maybe some of it had a mold that had him for better lack of words tripping all the time..and lets  not forget cannabis was often found in gardens and prescribed as a relaxer and as easy to get as tobacco..so not trying to fuel the stoned dutchman trope but maybe that sorta thing isn't as recent as we think..and if he stayed in lodgings with asbestos that certainly didn't help him..but it could be all of the above.. including french disease with the mercury medicine.
I wonder how van Goh feel if he was alive today knowing how much he's loved and admired it probably leave the guy speechless..or to know lot's of artists are inspired by him .
Please excuse my lack of punctuation my eyesights isn't the best and take care and God bless and have a wonderful day..
By the way professor..not a plug or 15 mins of whatever.. certainly not but if you care to see art by artists with autism feel free to look up that autism program they have alot of art  on their walls made by artists with it and a few you can tell aren't style copies of van Goh but definitely inspired by him..and should you get to an artist with the initials..LC..hope you like their work too..have a great day and as usual great video..ps please disregard my first comment I thought I deleted it..and this comment here is what I was going for...the one to why im replying to you now.. lol

replies.author: @cindyoverall8139
replies.text:
@@professorgraemeyorston  Of course, but people should be exposed to more than the Janson Bible and Kenneth Clarke.
There were many schools of painting at that time that were terrific. The Newlyn School, The Glasgow Boys, The Russian Naturalists, The Hague School, The American Tonalists, even The French Naturalists.. Most people know nothing about these painters. My eye doctor tried to talk to me about Monet, only artist he knew of.. because art historians just go over and over the same old names to the absurd.
What I am asking of you is to pull an unknown artist from history and educate the public further than, as I call, the tried, true and the banal. 
I recently saw an exhibit of Scandinavian women painters who lived in Paris in the 19c. Unbelievably good.
I hope you will consider and all of the best to you.
