comments.author: @willieluncheonette5843
comments.text:
"Vincent Van Gogh, one of the Dutch painters, could not sell a single painting in his whole life. Now only two hundred paintings have survived out of thousands that he painted, because nobody took care of them. He was simply distributing them to friends; nobody would purchase them. People were afraid even to hang his paintings in their sitting rooms because whoever would see them would think that they were crazy: what kind of painting are you hanging here? People were taking them ‚Äî not to hurt him ‚Äî thanking him, and throwing his paintings into their basements so nobody would see. Now each of his paintings is worth a million dollars. What happened in one hundred years? The man himself was forced into a mad asylum when he was only thirty-two. And he was forced because of his painting ‚Äî he was not harmful, he was not violent, he was not doing anything to anybody. But anybody who looked at his paintings was absolutely certain that this man was mad and unreliable. He should be put in a madhouse. If he could paint these things, he might do anything‚Ä¶.‚Äù For example, he always painted stars as spirals. Even other painters told him, ‚ÄúStars are not spirals!‚Äù

He said, ‚ÄúI also see the stars. I see that they are not spirals, but the moment I start painting them something in me says so strongly that they are spirals. The distance is so vast‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs why your eyes cannot see exactly what their shape is. And the voice is so strong. I am simply unable to do anything else but what my inner being says to do.‚Äù

And now physicists have discovered that stars are spirals. It has gone like a shock throughout the world of painters, that only one painter in the whole history of man had some inner contact and communication with the stars ‚Äî and that was a man who was thought to be mad. And because he was thought to be mad, nobody was ready to give him any service. Every week, his brother used to give him enough money to last for seven days. And he was fasting three days in a week and eating four days ‚Äî because that was the only way to purchase canvas and colors and brushes to paint. Painting was more important than life. He committed suicide at the age of thirty -three. Just after his release from the madhouse, he painted only one painting, which they had prevented him from painting in the madhouse. He wanted to paint the sun. It took him one year. He lost his eyes‚Ä¶ the burning sun, the hot sun, and the whole day long he would be watching all the colors, from the morning till the evening, from the sunrise to the sunset. He wanted the painting to contain everything about the sun, the whole biography of the sun. Everybody who was sympathetic to him told him, ‚ÄúThis is too much. Just studying it one day is enough; it is the same sun.‚Äù

Van Gogh said, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know. It is never the same. You have never looked at it. I have never seen the same sunrise twice, never seen the same sunset again. And I want my painting to be a biography.‚Äù One year‚Ä¶ the whole day watching the sun‚Ä¶ He lost his eyes, but he painted. And when the painting was complete, he wrote a small letter to his brother: ‚ÄúI am not committing suicide out of any despair ‚Äî because I am one of the most successful men in the world. I have done whatever I wanted to do in spite of the whole world condemning me. But this was my last wish, to paint the whole biography of the sun in one painting. It is completed today. I am immensely joyful, and now there is no need to live. I was living to paint; painting was my life, not breathing.‚Äù And he shot himself dead. You cannot categorize him with ordinary suicides. It is not a suicide ‚Äî out of despair, out of sadness, out of failure ‚Äî no. Out of immense success, out of total fulfillment, seeing that now, why unnecessarily go on living and waiting for death?‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI have done the work that I wanted to do.‚Äù Every creative artist has to understand this: the moment people start thinking about him that he is a little bit off center, that something is loose in his head, he should rejoice that he has crossed the boundary of the mundane and the mediocre. Now he has grown the wings which others don‚Äôt have."

comments.author: @monicacall7532
comments.text:
As a former grade school teacher my first thought was that Van Gogh was on the autism spectrum because of the difficulties he had with his basic interactions with other individuals.  He exhibited almost textbook neuro-divergent behavior.

Mental illness is such a scourge!  It robs a person of the ability to truly be themselves.  It‚Äôs a big issue on both sides of my family and I have seen and personally experienced it‚Äôs devastating effects.    I can‚Äôt imagine what it would‚Äôve been like to be so mentally ill and have no real medication or other treatments available to deal with the illness.  Even in these supposedly enlightened times too many people still believe that mental illness is a personal failure to deal with life and not the physical disease that it truly is.

Van Gogh has my love and admiration for bringing such truth and beauty to our world in spite of the physical and mental illness issues that plagued his sadly too short life.  Isn‚Äôt it ironic that the man who struggled to sell his paintings during his life is now internationally respected and loved the world over.  I have to hope that wherever and whatever sphere he now inhabits that he‚Äôs able to see how much beauty and joy his paintings have brought numberless people in the 133 years since his tragic death in 1890.

comments.text:
My grandson has autism and ADHD, and his behaviour mimics Vincent's, except it's more severe. He's an adult now. One thing that stood out to me is that he speaks proper English. we, being Scottish, have a very pronounced accent that he doesn't use. This makes me wonder if he hears differently from us.
Vincent, taking his own life, suggests to me that the pain he felt mentally was more than he could withstand, a breaking point as such. Only those who have had this kind of pain can truly understand it, and the need to shut it down.
Vincent had his brother, who sustained him through that pain for many years. Otherwise, I doubt he could have continued on for as long as he did

comments.author: @catherinepatterson4720
comments.text: Thank you. Very interesting üåªI believe Van Gogh presents with the red flags of Childhood Emotional Neglect (CEN) and that his adult behaviours are the result of this. Added to this he was the first born. It‚Äôs good to look into birth order. Often first borns are criticised more compared to, let‚Äôs say, the last born. Furthermore, based on our knowledge today of the brain-gut connection, Van Gogh‚Äôs poor diet must have impacted his mental health. Then we need to consider what, Ross Rosenberg (who has a YouTube channel), calls the self-love deficit disorder, a result of attachment issues in childhood. Ross also discusses the human magnet syndrome, which may also need to be considered in relation to the people Van Gogh attracted at work, while studying and in his personal life. He certainly displays a lot of self sabotaging behaviours in all areas of his life. Of course, there could be genetics, as well as generational behaviours passed down the family tree. I believe also, Van Gogh appeared to be the family scapegoat in his family, especially after hearing how his parents treated him. From my point of view, too many individuals who present with similar mental health issues as Van Gogh are labelled with Autism or Asperger‚Äôs, when in fact, they are likely the product of poor childhood attachment and/or growing up in a toxic family, with parents, who themselves are likely the product of poor attachment or family toxicity. All of which, can be a generational curse. It was nice to hear that Van Gogh had at least, and what appeared to be, a kind brother. I enjoyed this video. A thumbs up üëç

replies.author: @professorgraemeyorston
replies.text: Thank you, you make some very good points, and I agree autism can easily be over-diagnosed, which is why I raise it as a possibility rather than saying anything was certain.

replies.author: @catherinepatterson4720
replies.text: @@professorgraemeyorston Thank you for your reply and acknowledgement of the information provided. Yes, everything is a ‚Äòpossibility‚Äô until proven otherwise. In drawing a Venn diagram, one will find a similarity of traits between Autism and Trauma. Diagnosis‚Äôs (associated with human behaviour) need to be considered carefully and seriously, as labels can be hard to remove once given, especially if the label has led to injustices and prejudices. I suppose this is one of the challenges for those in professions associated with human behaviour and linguistics where a disability may be ‚Äòhidden‚Äô (requiring time to gather evidence) compared to a profession (e.g., an oncologist) where the evidence can be quicker to gather (e.g., on an x-ray). Though, I‚Äôm aware, there are exceptions to the rule in this statement. As always, I like the analysis of your videos : )

comments.text:
4:49 The guy was literally embodying the teachings of Jesus, by giving the ONLY thing he had - his HOUSE - to a poor, sick women in need. And the church FIRED him for it, because he wasn't living fancy enough to represent the church. üòîüòë
"The church had given him a comfortable house to live in, but there was a local women who was very sick and could no longer work. She could not afford her rent and had become homeless.
Vincent Van Gogh took pity on her and gave the women his house. He decided to go and live in one of the coal mining shacks instead. There was no furniture in the shacks and he was forced to sleep on the bare wooden floor with a blanket. The locals called him: "The Christ of the coal mines".
Even though the common people loved him, the church committee was humiliated. They did not want someone who was living in squalor to represent their religion, so they fired him."

comments.author: @willieluncheonette5843
comments.text:
"Vincent Van Gogh, one of the Dutch painters, could not sell a single painting in his whole life. Now only two hundred paintings have survived out of thousands that he painted, because nobody took care of them. He was simply distributing them to friends; nobody would purchase them. People were afraid even to hang his paintings in their sitting rooms because whoever would see them would think that they were crazy: what kind of painting are you hanging here? People were taking them ‚Äî not to hurt him ‚Äî thanking him, and throwing his paintings into their basements so nobody would see. Now each of his paintings is worth a million dollars. What happened in one hundred years? The man himself was forced into a mad asylum when he was only thirty-two. And he was forced because of his painting ‚Äî he was not harmful, he was not violent, he was not doing anything to anybody. But anybody who looked at his paintings was absolutely certain that this man was mad and unreliable. He should be put in a madhouse. If he could paint these things, he might do anything‚Ä¶.‚Äù For example, he always painted stars as spirals. Even other painters told him, ‚ÄúStars are not spirals!‚Äù

He said, ‚ÄúI also see the stars. I see that they are not spirals, but the moment I start painting them something in me says so strongly that they are spirals. The distance is so vast‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs why your eyes cannot see exactly what their shape is. And the voice is so strong. I am simply unable to do anything else but what my inner being says to do.‚Äù

And now physicists have discovered that stars are spirals. It has gone like a shock throughout the world of painters, that only one painter in the whole history of man had some inner contact and communication with the stars ‚Äî and that was a man who was thought to be mad. And because he was thought to be mad, nobody was ready to give him any service. Every week, his brother used to give him enough money to last for seven days. And he was fasting three days in a week and eating four days ‚Äî because that was the only way to purchase canvas and colors and brushes to paint. Painting was more important than life. He committed suicide at the age of thirty -three. Just after his release from the madhouse, he painted only one painting, which they had prevented him from painting in the madhouse. He wanted to paint the sun. It took him one year. He lost his eyes‚Ä¶ the burning sun, the hot sun, and the whole day long he would be watching all the colors, from the morning till the evening, from the sunrise to the sunset. He wanted the painting to contain everything about the sun, the whole biography of the sun. Everybody who was sympathetic to him told him, ‚ÄúThis is too much. Just studying it one day is enough; it is the same sun.‚Äù

Van Gogh said, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know. It is never the same. You have never looked at it. I have never seen the same sunrise twice, never seen the same sunset again. And I want my painting to be a biography.‚Äù One year‚Ä¶ the whole day watching the sun‚Ä¶ He lost his eyes, but he painted. And when the painting was complete, he wrote a small letter to his brother: ‚ÄúI am not committing suicide out of any despair ‚Äî because I am one of the most successful men in the world. I have done whatever I wanted to do in spite of the whole world condemning me. But this was my last wish, to paint the whole biography of the sun in one painting. It is completed today. I am immensely joyful, and now there is no need to live. I was living to paint; painting was my life, not breathing.‚Äù And he shot himself dead. You cannot categorize him with ordinary suicides. It is not a suicide ‚Äî out of despair, out of sadness, out of failure ‚Äî no. Out of immense success, out of total fulfillment, seeing that now, why unnecessarily go on living and waiting for death?‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI have done the work that I wanted to do.‚Äù Every creative artist has to understand this: the moment people start thinking about him that he is a little bit off center, that something is loose in his head, he should rejoice that he has crossed the boundary of the mundane and the mediocre. Now he has grown the wings which others don‚Äôt have."

The Van Gogh exhibit (I saw it October 2021) touches on how the latest belief is that he was shot by two people he had a drunken disagreement with at the bar he frequented. They talk about how his bipolar disorder, based on the paintings he was working on at that time, don‚Äôt give any impressions of him being suicidal and that they were brighter than his ‚Äúdark times‚Äù. 

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32732590/

We will almost certainly never know for sure whether he did take his own life or if he was the victim of a drunken disagreement and murdered; however, I don‚Äôt think I can be convinced otherwise that he was taken from us by someone else‚Äôs hand and not his own.

comments.author: @colchestergallery
comments.text:
I want to say a couple of things here- 
at 9:15     The French Impressionists did not hire or paint from models. They prided themselves on painting real life.   That means that they painted portraits of people that they knew, and often located them in daily settings, such as their garden, or at the table. They also painted people in street scenes, at entertainments, and so on.  

at 9:40    "Most of the Impressionists only painted on days when the weather was beautiful.  This is a serious misinterpretation of what the Impressionists were about.  "Impressionism" refers to capturing fleeting impressions. - i.e. they typically painted in all weathers, and without regard to finding "the perfect light". The light that they painted was whatever light was available-  dawn, morning, noonday sun, hot afternoon, snow storms, rain, drizzle, fog, dusk on the river, night in the street, and the coal dust and smoke of a railway station.    THIS is primarily what Impressionism was about. 

at 9:50  The picture of the Impressionists as knowing the market, only selling a painting once in a while and finding time to party does not ring true. 
Some of the Impressionists, Monet in particular, were enormously productive.  
Occasionally some, Renoir in particular, would get a commission that brought in a good deal of money. These were generally family portraits.  But  mostly their works were small landscapes that were not going to make them rich.  Monet did not get BIG commissions until late in his life, after Vincent's death. Henri Toulouse-Lautrec painted most of his pictures on cardboard, and designed posters.

comments.text: I read a few books about Vincent Van Gogh. I really agree that he was humble. Maybe he had some outbursts, but he was mostly a nice sweet man. The voice was scary. He asked to be taken out. I don't believe in hell, but this would be great for Halloween. I get off the topic because I suffer from bipolar disorder. There is a theory that Vincent Van Gogh didn't kill himself because it debunked that he could get the bullet where it came into him. Another theory was that he was shot by a teenager. My theory is that I believe that he didn't want the teenager to get the death penalty. He didn't say that he shot himself. He said that this is the way it was meant to be as I remember. I believe that he wanted to be an author. There's an autobiography by Vincent Van Gogh. It has to do with himself writing to his brother, Theo. But it is a possibility that Theo killed himself over grief. The painter was highly against suicide. I guess that he rather die than be rescued and be a medical patient and have his murderer not executed. That I guess he suffered from borderline personality. I never heard of people with his diagnosis doing what he did.  I like Edvard Munch. I can't identify with anyone. I am an individual like everyone else.

Brilliant!!!!!! I learned so much and am so inspired, thank you so much!!!!! I am a muti-talented artist. I make music, write; stories, poetry and just miscellaneous subjects I find interesting, I paint; watercolor, oil and acrylic, I've sold one painting so far. A huge oil painting i did for my neighbor for $200 it brought me joy not just because I made money off my art but mostly because it brought someone else so much joy. My niche is watercolor and calligraphy. I feel I truly resonate with van gogh, his struggles with mental illness and pain but also his HUGE heart. I am so loving and kind but that often gets me taken advantage of. The town I live in is small-minded and full of negativity but thats why my light is needed most here. People laugh at me and think I'm crazy because I am free and live to the toot of my own horn. But maybe I am a humble genius too. Never wanting to be cocky about it but also being so brilliant other people hate me for it and misunderstand me for a fool. I don't care though, I know I'm here to do good things and that's all that matters. I am brilliant and I believe in what I do (most of the time.) So I'm not going to stop for nothing. Just that one neighbour telling me to "paint with presence" and saying I have a true gift and to never stop, really changed me. So take it from me, just because everyone thinks you're crazy doesn't mean what you're doing isn't needed in the world. You are so needed, your work is valuable. comments.author: @Planxty96
comments.text:
Imagine Van Gogh


‚Äúa nobody
a non-entity
. . . the lowest of the low‚Äù


at the cafe
or brasserie, always present
. . . never seen

Van Gogh
familiar, intimate
. . . yet so distant

failed dealer
failed preacher
failed lover

his sad eyes
piercing, burdened by genius
mad for beauty

for the truth he seeks
with every brushstroke
craving honesty

devoid of vanity
his painted pain exquisite
doomed to penury

coffee, bread, absinthe
no diet for his melancholy
nor turpentine nor paint

empty chairs
echoing abandonment
again and again

eating potatoes
with his peasants
lost to art

or lost in trees
twisted ‚Äòtween heaven and earth
tormented

            why were they
            so blind to your brilliance
            so deaf to your voice

. . . ignorant of your pain
 
. . . disdainful of your love

in your bedroom serene
‚Äúunshakeable repose . . .
fresh butter yellow‚Äù

yet, above the wheat field, 
skies of inner turmoil
exploding

your sunflowers
intensely living, wilting, 
dying, dead

at the asylum‚Äôs edge
your wild, wavy irises
a sanctuary 

a couple's repose
at harvest come siesta time
until finally

at terrasse du cafe
‚ÄúI shake your hand firmly.
Ever yours,‚Äù

Vincent
among the stars
. . . transcendent



Copyright of Padraic Slater
Bard from Kitsilano
Vancouver, B.C., Canadaq


(Inspired by a June 2021 visit to ‚ÄòImagine Van Gogh: An Immersive Experience‚Äô at the Vancouver Convention Centre in Vancouver, B.C., Canada).

comments.author: @guslevy3506
comments.text:
There are several discrepancies in this video that I would challenge, but the one that is perhaps most personal to Vincent would be the suggestion that he was distraught or jealous about Theo‚Äôs new life with Jo - that it would cause negative effects upon his life. 

This is wrong: Vincent was happy for Theo and loved the new family - what he concluded was that he didn‚Äôt wish to be a burden upon Theo and the new family. He was an intelligent and sensitive man who understood the situation. It is likely that his decision to commit suicide was partly to ensure that he would no longer become a burden to Theo who was having his own anxieties and pain from the complexities of both personal and professional reasons during the time of Vincent‚Äôs death.

comments.author: @masterofThardus
comments.text: "Well...big question, but ah...to me Van Gogh is the finest painter of them all. Certainly the most popular Great Painter of all time; the most beloved, his command of color the most magnificent. He transformed the pain of his tormented life into ecstatic beauty. Pain is easy to portray, but to use your passion and pain to portray the ecstasy and joy and magnificence of our world...no one had ever done it before. Perhaps no one ever will again. To my mind that strange, wild man wandering the fields of Provence was not only the world's greatest artist, but also one of the greatest men who ever lived."

comments.text:
I have a hard time believing Van Gogh ate paint. Tube paints were kind of a new invention. Part of the reason art changed so drastically is because of tube paints. An artist could take his paint kit on location and paint en plien aire. Art supplies are expensive now, they must have been expensive then. I'm an artist. I have a small tube of red oil paint that costs more than twenty loaves of Martin's Potato Bread, the good stuff. I lived on Martin's Potato Bread, toasted with butter and marmalade. Vinny isn't the only starving artist in history. At least his brother helped him. I've been on my own forever. If an artist is supposed to suffer I win that contest with a brother that is nothing but grief. I don't know where the idea that Vinny (he lets me call him Vinny) ate his paint comes from, but I swear it's bs. He might have been crazy, but he wasn't stupid.
     Too bad about his mother. I read she patched a hole in her chicken coop with one of his paintings. She burned a crate of his paintings! What a loss. Up there with the woman who burned a stash of the Dead Sea Scrolls. 
     Cool video. Vinny is The Legend. Go Van Gogh!

comments.author: @bejeweledpro
comments.text:
I've always loved Van Gogh and his countless works. I don't cry much due to my antidepressants, but I teared up at this video. His short life inspires the deepest of my beliefs on how a true artist operates. His continued struggles with his sanity also speak to his work ethic and determination regarding his artwork, as despite all that was on his plate, he never abandoned his philosophy on life and his creative visions.
 I was a classically trained trombonist of 7 years when I was 16, and I had a huge passion for music. Three quarters through high school, my mental health issues came to the surface pretty rapidly. I quit band, started isolating and seeing a counselor. I began using drugs and alcohol to cope with my own mental health struggles because I was impatient with waiting for the benefits of counseling, and although it was a short two and a half years, my negative relationship with them had gotten to a breaking point. I had stopped attending lectures, started isolating alone in my dorm and was very undernourished. I got sober at 18, and I'm now just shy of two years of continued sobriety. I reignited my passion for music in rehab, and began playing my favorite melodies by ear on the piano. I've now found a different calling in the musical sphere: composing. 
Van Gogh's philosophy on human empathy and the true nature of artistry are some of the main influences that drive me to create, while also inspiring me to do so. I care more about creating things that I recognize as beautiful than conforming to the standards of the public at large, and it's infinitely rewarding. 
Great video as always. I love your channel, and learning about past figures in different areas of expertise will never bore me. 

Thanks, Decker

comments.text:
A few points:
1. He studied Delacroix and color theory,  which was highly influential to his use of bright colors as well, it was not solely Monet's influence.
2. There is more evidence that he was actually murdered, rather than suicide. He told people he did it himself, though a gun was never found. Many speculate he said he did it as not to get the youbg boy who shot him in trouble. And also, he was shot in the stomach, not the chest. The angle of the gunshot could not have been self-inflicted.
Otherwise, wonderful video!

comments.text: The effects of Absinthe have been greatly exaggerated due to trace amounts of Thujone contained in wormwood, which acts as a stimulate at low levels, hence its popularity. Anyone wanted to argue this mythology needs to explain why the same isn‚Äôt true of Vermouth, which is French for the German word ‚ÄúWermut‚Äù which is wormwood, Vermouth is wormwood wine. Traditionally, it could not be called Vermouth without containing wormwood. Wormwood was also used as a substitute for hops in beer. To ingest enough thujone to make you hallucinate, would probably also make you convulse. The real danger in drinking absinthe is that it is normally 90-135 proof.

comments.author: @midnightchannel111
comments.text: Please consider a video on Theo: it is not well known that Theo literally supported all the Post Impressionsits, loaning them money an he knew he would never get back, buying art supplies, all in addition to tirelessly trying to sell their work. Gaugin is an example,  benefitting from Theo's handouts on several occations. It is really largely to Theo's efforts, in addition to the later popularity of Vincent's work, as mentioned here, that Post Impressionism went on to be so helpful to the artists of the 20th century.

comments.author: @midnightchannel111
comments.text: Gaugin was a great artist. He was also a bully, a liar and a coward.

comments.author: @midnightchannel111
comments.text:
This man does not mention that the only person making the claims of Vincent's actions in  Arles was Gaugin...The "friend" who got outta Dodge as soon as he could in reaction to his "friend's" breakdown: now, wjat kind of friend would do that? ..  Other research, sadly not presented here, makes a profoundly good case for Gaugin being the one who started and fueled arguments, insisting that Vincent paint like he painted (ie, NOT to to outside to paint,l as Vin entry preferred to do, but to paint from memory like Gaugin did), and Gaugin who cut off Vincent's ear in a rage , and for a local kid/bully for being the one who shot Vincent.

 Vincent was just a decent guy who wanted to be an artist and a good friend, but who did not understand how to filter those around him: I think he must have made a point to learn to screen those he allowed I to his life, to set  psychological "boundaries" in his next lifetime.

comments.author: @midnightchannel111
comments.text: He learned several foreign languages while at shool, NOT as depicted here, beginning those studies as an adult at Groupil...

comments.author: @midnightchannel111
comments.text: This history is rather one sided : Vincent was a family name and while true Vincent had a still born elder brother with that name,  he also  had a father, an uncle and  one other relative, living, with his name when he was a little boy. It was tradition to pass this name down before Vincent was born, so the emphasis on his dead brother is, I believe, over emphasized as a formative factor in his life.

replies.author: @douglipman5731
replies.text:
One thing to consider, especially for those of us living in the US: living in Europe meant (and still does to a large extent today) exposure to many languages. The Netherlands is about twice the size of New Jersey, yet it is borders on French-speaking Belgium and German-speaking Germany. It also has "a maritime border" with England. Throughout history and throughout the world, people living near a border tend to speak the languages on both sides of the border. 

So, it's admirable that van Gogh spoke all those languages - but not remarkable, given the time and place. 

We in the US have the privilege (and the curse?) of living our lives without learning a second language. As a result, we often treat learning a second language as a difficult and rare skill. But when you're surrounded by multiple languages, learning them is not an extraordinary ability.

comments.author: @JLHunter61
comments.text:
I am reminded of the Doctor Who episode titled "Vincent and the Doctor". It is a poignant look at Vincent's life and struggles near the end of his life. The Doctor (Matt Smith) and Amy Pond visit Vincent to help him battle an invisible creature--but not invisible to Vincent due, probably, to his encroaching madness--called a "Krafayis." The monster-of-the-week is a bit silly, but the overall episode is one of the Whovian community's most beloved.

I won't spoil the episode for anyone who has not seen it, but see it you must. It is an uncharacteristically honest, caring portrayal of Van Gogh in all of his passion and suffering. And if you are not crying by the end of the episode, then YOU don't have a heart. It truly is moving. Even non-Doctor Who fans should find some true compassion and joy for Vincent Van Gogh, his suffering, his unrivaled genius, his small moments of hope, and, in this remarkable episode, a chance at redemption that is offered to Vincent...which, obviously, ultimately, he could not accept due to his unstoppable descent into depression.

This episode gets me every time. Give it a look. I don''t think that you will be disappointed. And you may even find yourself feeling even more compassion for such a true, unknown-in-his-own-time, unequalled genius who showed us the beauty and the passion that could reside even in a soul wracked by self-doubt, cruel, undeserved madness, and devastating bouts of depression. "Vincent and the Doctor" is a gem.

comments.text: Absinthe does NOT case hallucinations whatsoever.  Not only is that a myth, it was perpetuated due to the drink's association with Bohemian culture and was a tool of class separation.  Poets, writers, and artists often drank it because they often enjoyed rebelling against societal norms.  The only hallucinations you'll get from absinthe are the same ones you'll get from a bottle of Johnny Walker.

comments.text:
Hey Simon, there‚Äôs awful lot of misinformation about Absinthe. The active ingredient Thujone is not hallucinogenic although it is toxic in fairly low doses. The most obvious reasons for the drink‚Äôs popularity is the high alcohol content and low cost as well as the ritualised preparation of dripping ice cold water through a sugar cube balanced on a special slotted spoon causing the Absinthe to Louche a cloudy pale green.
Much like mulling up, packing and passing the bong, chasing the dragon or fixing up a hit it is the ritual that adds to the allure.

comments.text:
So van Gogh lives in an impoverished way, preaching to the most in need and helping those most in need, just like the person whom his religion is based upon yet his "superiors" sacked him. If jesus were alive today (I'm an atheist but this is a thought experiment) then I've no doubt church leaders would shun him
Edit-absinthe DOES NOT CAUSE HALLUCINATIONS!!! It's likely that it was just because absinthe is extremely strong and people dra k a lot of it that caused hallucinations but other drinks like vodka and whiskey could do the same. Similarly if someone is physically addicted to alcohol they sometimes hallucinate when in withdrawals so if that person is known for drinking absinthe and then they trip out from withdrawals people would put 2+2 together and get 5. Seems like van Gogh was physically addicted to alcohol since he was having seizures while in hospital for his ear as well as being delirious (presumably he couldn't get alcohol in hospital). Just had to clear that up lol

comments.author: @Kima-e1b
comments.text:
Truely a sad tale, newly found informations about Vincent death emerged. The latter being such a good hearted person, apparently did one last act of kindness even in his death. Reports of him being bullied by a young french boy who was obsessed with western movies and cowboy lifestyle who also carried a gun in a holster at all time, as part of his cowboy outfit. The little boy‚Äôs sibling, another boy who was fascinated by the art world and Vincent‚Äôs work, caused Vincent to built an amicable relationship with the latter. 

The ‚Äúcowboy wannabe‚Äù sibling was a little bit of a bully to Vincent, nonetheless Vincent still liked to hang out with the pair. Vincent also having a tendency to shoot back funny jokes and comebacks at the cowboy kid, back and forth and the other little boy (the art enthusiast) would learn and watch Vincent paint and will ask about life In Paris as he was in love with the art of painting. So Vincent had a prot√©ger with a brother that had no interest in the arts and was obsessed with westerns. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, he wasn‚Äôt a terrible kid but he couldn‚Äôt care any less about painting. Some researchers announced that after investigations about the death of Vincent it‚Äôs said that in that same field that Vincent was painting and supposedly shot himself, he wasn‚Äôt alone that day. He was believed to have been with the brothers. When he returned to his residence he supposedly walked back but at the time, the blood splat pattern, him having a strong stance against committing suicide, disappearance of his painting equipments, or even the gun has never been found. Just doesn‚Äôt add up to Vincent‚Äôs version of events. (Vincent‚Äôs account of the whole thing was that he shot himself, thrown the gun, he passed out for a while and when he woke up he couldn‚Äôt find the gun to finish off the job that‚Äôs when he walked back to his residence and died at home) 

what doesn‚Äôt add up is that, Vincent was seen leaving his house with painting equipments that were never found. Even more interesting is that evidence gathered by investigators point that he was covering up what really happened that day until his last breath. 

1. If he shot himself the wound would‚Äôve been in a self inflicted area, most likely a head-wound and that would‚Äôve been the most effective way. The wound was on his stomach.

2. Vincent lied about the throwing away of the gun after the alleged self inflicted stomach shot. Cause sure that whole part  make sense. 

3. His clothes looked like the wound was fresh as they weren‚Äôt drenched in blood, what would happen if someone shoots himself in the stomach and lose consciousness for sometime in the ground. His clothes weren‚Äôt. 

4. he insisted repeatedly and was adamant with the suicide theory that it was forcibly accepted as the real fate of this martyred genius. 

5. The two boys and their father left abruptly for another city the day or the day after Van Gogh‚Äôs death. And the young cowboy dude didn‚Äôt have his gun and never carried it in his holster ever again. 

Many more little little elements that don‚Äôt seem to fit Vincent‚Äôs events. 

After reading about all that it made me realise that he didn‚Äôt see any reason in saying that he was shot by children as it may have been an accident, the young boy messing with his gun, shot him by accident. He decided to not ruin the little boys‚Äô lives. Another side of the big hearted, tortured genius, that was in my opinion ahead of his time and while in bed dying he  said ‚Äúdo not accuse anyone.. it is I who wanted to kill myself‚Äù 

Again plenty to take from the new informations on the accounts of his death.

comments.text: I've known a good chunk of his bio for some time, but this is my first time visiting the material after my own bout with suicidal depression. I absolutely empathize with his mindset after hearing about his brother's financial troubles. It crossed my mind a few times before getting help after those caring for me experienced their own money troubles. I'd skip meals or ration out a meal to last me 2 days, just enough to keep the starvation pain to a minimum. I digress, his giving his church housing away strikes me as exactly the level of compassion and charity that should be something for the others in the church to aspire to, not shunning him.

comments.author: @hansolo2121
comments.text: Vincent shooting himself is only a theory. But it really does not make any sense at all. The bullit that killed Vincent did not 'nearly miss his heart'. Vincent was shot in the lower stomach from about a couple of meters distance. Why would anyone shoot himself in the guts if the objective is to kill oneself? And how could a man shoot himself while operating a gun from several meters away? And Vincent could not have just 'found a gun'. This was rural France in the 19th century. Basically no one owned a gun or had even seen a revolver in their lifetime. There is a far more convincing theory about what happened. Vincent was accidentally shot by the only boy in town who in fact did own a gun. A boy and his friends who had been bullying Vincent ever since he came to live in Auvers.

comments.author: @Controversial_Celebrity_Quotes
comments.text:
Vincent (Starry, Starry Night)
Don McLean

Starry starry night

Paint your palette blue and gray

Look out on a summer's day

With eyes that know the darkness in my soul

Shadows on the hills

Sketch the trees and the daffodils

Catch the breeze and the winter chills

In colors on the snowy linen land

Now I understand

What you tried to say to me

How you suffered for your sanity

How you tried to set them free

They would not listen they did not know how

Perhaps they'll listen now

Starry starry night

Flaming flowers that brightly blaze

Swirling clouds in violet haze

Reflect in Vincent's eyes of china blue

Colors changing hue

Morning fields of amber grain

Weathered faces lined in pain

Are soothed beneath the artist's loving hand

Now I understand

What you tried to say to me

How you suffered for your sanity

How you tried to set them free

They would not listen, they did not know how

Perhaps they'll listen now

For they could not love you

But still your love was true

And when no hope was left inside

On that starry starry night

You took your life as lovers often do

But I could have told you Vincent

This world was never meant for one as beautiful as you

Starry starry night

Portraits hung in empty halls

Frameless heads on nameless walls

With eyes that watch the world and can't forget

Like the strangers that you've met

The ragged men in ragged clothes

The silver thorn of bloody rose

Lie crushed and broken on the virgin snow

Now I think I know

What you tried to say to me

How you suffered for your sanity

How you tried to set them free

They did not listen, they're not listening still

Perhaps they never will

comments.text: I thought Julian Schnabel's film 'At Eternity's Gate' was the best film made about van Gogh I've seen.  He actually was shot in his stomach - not in his chest - and given his deep religious feeling, I've long doubted the whole suicide theory.  Not to mention, shooting oneself in the stomach is hardly the most efficient way to commit suicide.  But, that's just my opinion.  Also, given his affinity for the poor and the lower classes; I think he'd be shocked and not particularly pleased by what his paintings sell for now.  But, again; this is just my opinion.

Theodore Van Gogh and later his wife were wonderful people for being there for Vincent, their devotion and support was beautiful despite Vincent's difficult personality and struggle.

Vincent felt love and passion a thousand fold over what anyone else possibly could, and it showed in his art, I wonder what he would have gone on to create had his brother not sent that fateful letter, assuming that Syphilis hadn't taken him like it did his brother.

This video was by far yours and your teams best work so far on this channel, a moving and heart-wrenching tale that captivated me and gave me a new appreciation for Van Gogh and his art.

replies.author: @christineparis5607
replies.text:
@@bizinsky 
It is true that creative people are so sensitive to outside stimuli that it is almost painful for them to be in groups or even go anywhere.  A study found many people with diagnosable personality disorders are very artistic.  Artists really are often tortured by their painful inner selves, and yet have tremendous gifts.  I have learned that setting boundaries that people who care about you are willing to understand and honor helps so much.  Artists often need periods of downtime to recharge and be alone to shake off the debris of other people.  Its equally important for them to get out and occasionally be with others so they don't experience too many intrusive thoughts or worries. Some laughter and camaraderie blows away the mental cobwebs. 
Every person who finds people draining knows exactly what I mean.  It's a balancing act that is hard to get just right, but it's essential to try, so depression and loneliness don't get to be the dominant emotion....

replies.author: @gardensofthegods
replies.text:
@@whiskychops yes , thank you... a couple people here tried to act as if my mentioning it to various people here was such a terrible thorn in their side .
    I  repeated that statement because not everybody reads the comments . Some people will watch a vid and say what they have to say ... but not start reading the other comments .
   I was trying to reach those people to see if they had an interest... I have not seen the whole movie of loving Vincent yet.... but I did know that it brings up the question but because I hadn't seen the whole thing I didn't want to bring it up .
    I just think anybody who really loves Van Gogh would be interested in knowing . For some of us it is a real mind-blower and makes more sense . When I was three or four years old we had a book of some of the world's greatest artwork ... my older sister and I would look at that a lot.. . I knew his name and his artwork but not a lot about his life until second grade and when a teacher told us he killed himself I remember  feeling something was wrong with that story ... it was a feeling all through me .... not just viscerally but through my heart , mind and spirit .

replies.author: @hansolo2121
replies.text: Jane Ann Vincent did not kill himself. There were no guns to simply be 'found' in Auvers in France at that time. Even if there would have been someone with a gun: who in their right mind would give that gun to the local foreigner madman who had just cut off his own ear? Also he was not shot 'nearly missing his heart' like this man said but he was shot in his stomach from several meters distance. Why would anyone shoot himself in the guts if the intention would be to kill oneself? Check out uoutubbe or google. There is a far better theory about what actually happened that day. He was accidentally shot by a boy who bullied him a lot and actually did own a revolver.

replies.author: @janeann3331

I don't know if I would have rejected Van Gogh, but I strive to understand the human existence man or woman.

Starry starry night. Paint your pallet blue and grey. Look out on a summer's day. With eyes that know the darkness in my soul.
Shadows on the hills. Sketch the trees and the daffodils. Catch the breeze and the winter chills in colors on the snowy linen land.
Now I understand.  What you tried to say to me. And how you suffered for your sanity. And how you tried to set them free. They would not listen, they did not know how. Perhaps they'll listen now.
Skip.
For they could not love you. But still your live was true.
And when no hope was left in sight. On that starry starry night.  You took your life, as often lovers do. But I could have told you, Vincent. This world was never meant for one as beautiful as you

replies.author: @mikshinee87
replies.text: Ah Chopin... his brave sister smuggled his heart back to his homeland because that was his final wish. She didn't want Russian secret police to find it, that's why she had to hide it while traveling by train. She then took it to the church which the family attended. Then, over a century later, it had to be smuggled out again during the German occupation so that it wasn't destroyed in the bombings.  A good thing too since most of the building was  later destroyed by fire. Then it came back to the rebuilt church again. Some people have adventures long after they're dead.

comments.author: @aegisofhonor
comments.text: the circumstances of where Van Gogh was and even who shot him are not totally clear.  Another account says he was shot in town by a young boy who thought the gun was not loaded pulling the trigger as a joke and when Vincent was shot, took the gun away, told the boy to run back home, he took the gun back home.  The entire basis of his suicide is based on the answer to the question "who shot you" with Vincent's reply "no one".  Years later that same boy now a middle aged man recounted the events and stated he was in fact the one who shot Vincent Van Gogh.  But few believed him even though new evidence in recent years suggests the story told by the man who claimed to have shot him to be far more likely the the "more famous" recounting of events most people have come to believe despite no evidence that Vincent ever even left the town that day before his gunshot wound.

replies.author: @jamesh8654
replies.text: Agreed, Johanna was a hero, but I would say the real hero was Theo. When the world wished to turn their back on Vincent, Theo never did. He paid for his lodgings, his paint supplies, and even tried to sell his paintings to perspective buyers. He was his biggest supporter and introduced Vincent to her in such a way that she was enthralled by his work, and even after they had passed, she was the hero who brought him to the worlds attention. However, if it were not for Theo, there would be no Vincent.

replies.author: @itarry4
replies.text: What about Theo? How many brothers would have done what he did for an older brother. Its thanks to both we have what we have.

replies.author: @tomggabin5838
replies.text: Theo was the real hero. He believed in his brother, and that belief probably rubbed off on Johanna. Then when she was a single mother with no way to make a living, she did the right thing, from a business perspective, and collected Vincent's work. Thank Johanna for perpetuating Vincent in the future, but a bigger thanks to Theo for encouraging Vincent to paint and offering the much needed emotional and financial support. Without that encouragement, there would be no paintings.

comments.author: @willieluncheonette5843
comments.text:
"Vincent Van Gogh, one of the Dutch painters, could not sell a single painting in his whole life. Now only two hundred paintings have survived out of thousands that he painted, because nobody took care of them. He was simply distributing them to friends; nobody would purchase them. People were afraid even to hang his paintings in their sitting rooms because whoever would see them would think that they were crazy: what kind of painting are you hanging here? People were taking them ‚Äî not to hurt him ‚Äî thanking him, and throwing his paintings into their basements so nobody would see. Now each of his paintings is worth a million dollars. What happened in one hundred years? The man himself was forced into a mad asylum when he was only thirty-two. And he was forced because of his painting ‚Äî he was not harmful, he was not violent, he was not doing anything to anybody. But anybody who looked at his paintings was absolutely certain that this man was mad and unreliable. He should be put in a madhouse. If he could paint these things, he might do anything‚Ä¶.‚Äù For example, he always painted stars as spirals. Even other painters told him, ‚ÄúStars are not spirals!‚Äù

He said, ‚ÄúI also see the stars. I see that they are not spirals, but the moment I start painting them something in me says so strongly that they are spirals. The distance is so vast‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs why your eyes cannot see exactly what their shape is. And the voice is so strong. I am simply unable to do anything else but what my inner being says to do.‚Äù

And now physicists have discovered that stars are spirals. It has gone like a shock throughout the world of painters, that only one painter in the whole history of man had some inner contact and communication with the stars ‚Äî and that was a man who was thought to be mad. And because he was thought to be mad, nobody was ready to give him any service. Every week, his brother used to give him enough money to last for seven days. And he was fasting three days in a week and eating four days ‚Äî because that was the only way to purchase canvas and colors and brushes to paint. Painting was more important than life. He committed suicide at the age of thirty -three. Just after his release from the madhouse, he painted only one painting, which they had prevented him from painting in the madhouse. He wanted to paint the sun. It took him one year. He lost his eyes‚Ä¶ the burning sun, the hot sun, and the whole day long he would be watching all the colors, from the morning till the evening, from the sunrise to the sunset. He wanted the painting to contain everything about the sun, the whole biography of the sun. Everybody who was sympathetic to him told him, ‚ÄúThis is too much. Just studying it one day is enough; it is the same sun.‚Äù

Van Gogh said, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know. It is never the same. You have never looked at it. I have never seen the same sunrise twice, never seen the same sunset again. And I want my painting to be a biography.‚Äù One year‚Ä¶ the whole day watching the sun‚Ä¶ He lost his eyes, but he painted. And when the painting was complete, he wrote a small letter to his brother: ‚ÄúI am not committing suicide out of any despair ‚Äî because I am one of the most successful men in the world. I have done whatever I wanted to do in spite of the whole world condemning me. But this was my last wish, to paint the whole biography of the sun in one painting. It is completed today. I am immensely joyful, and now there is no need to live. I was living to paint; painting was my life, not breathing.‚Äù And he shot himself dead. You cannot categorize him with ordinary suicides. It is not a suicide ‚Äî out of despair, out of sadness, out of failure ‚Äî no. Out of immense success, out of total fulfillment, seeing that now, why unnecessarily go on living and waiting for death?‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI have done the work that I wanted to do.‚Äù Every creative artist has to understand this: the moment people start thinking about him that he is a little bit off center, that something is loose in his head, he should rejoice that he has crossed the boundary of the mundane and the mediocre. Now he has grown the wings which others don‚Äôt have."

comments.author: @lenaamartin36
comments.text:
I've been in love with Vincent's works for years, and as far as I've studied (I've even read some of his correspondence recently at his museum) is that there's no certainty that he tried to kill himself and it doesn't even make much sense for the moment he was living and that Theo did die of a sexually transmitted disease.
Wil, his sister, was a feminist writer and even participated in a feminist event that caused a great social upheaval here (Netherlands) and shortly after the event she was sent to a hospice.
There is no evidence that she actually had a mental illness, I just researched online sources in Dutch, but what we do know is that women who don't obey social rules often end up in mental institutions.

comments.author: @MsXxMellixX
comments.text: Since more of the letters have been published in the last years it is suggested (by Matthias Arnold) that Theo's engagement with Johanna triggered Vincent's first suicide attempt (he cut off a little part of his ear instead most likely due to his alcohol consumption during his attempt). After this incident letters show that Theo hasn't been sure what to do with his brother. He didn't really want to take care of him and hoped that Vincent will make the suggestion to go to a mental illness hospital. Theo seemed quite happy for his brother's decision because it meant less work for him who wanted to focus on his wedding. So much for the always supportive brother i guess. Vincent also fell in love with Dr Gachet's daughter who (according to a letter she sent her friend) loved him back. Unfortunately Dr Gachet didn't like this and forbid contacting each other. It is suggested that this situation was another factor that led to his suicide in the end (which Matthias Arnold thinks was his fourth attempt)

comments.text:
While living in Arles, he bought some paint supplies at an art store in town one day. The shop owner's niece, Jeanne Calment, would eventually be known as the longest-lived person in history, reaching 122 years and 164 days by the time she died in 1997. In 1988, 100 years after van Gogh's visit to Arles, she gained national attention when she recalled meeting him, calling him "dirty and disagreeable", and "reeking of alcohol".

van Gogh is easily my favourite artist. I've even been to the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, where I saw a good portion of his works. In high school, I chose to complete my art class project on him and painted one of his Sunflower paintings as part of it.

comments.author: @lindsayreeder9056
comments.text: He was shot in the stomach, not the chest. The angle of the bullet could not have been self inflicting. The gun was also not located in the feild where his painting supplies had been left. There was a boy in town who was obsessed with cowboys and he bullied van Gogh. The very day van Gogh was shot, the boy and his family fled in the night back to their home in the city. They were visiting for the summer and left weeks before they told people they had been planning to go home. Van Gogh insisted to others he was the one who did it, no one else, so no one but him could be blamed. Despite being bullied that summer by the boy, he wanted to protect him as he laid dying. Van Gogh had always been adamantly opposed to suicide due to his Christian beliefs and upbringing (he even tried to become a pastor at one point).

comments.text: Having a brother who suffers manic depression, I am familiar with ups and downs of a person's moods. I was kinda sad to watch this vid start with the 'ear'. My brother certainly did have bright moods as a little kiddo and teen. I would like to have known a bit of Van Gogh's, up moods. I can very much imagine his struggles ... since Iam older sister to a sibling who has to be attentive and mindful to when the 'grey' shrouds him- and is able to manage himself. comments.text: An interesting theory is that Van Gogh was taking Foxglove (modern-day digoxin) for heart problems. One of the signs of toxicity is the person experiencing yellow halos in vision called xanthospia. Though if he was experiencing toxicity to cause this it should have been fatal. It is also evident because the Portrait of Doctor Gachet (the doctor who was treating him at the asylum) showed the doctor holding a Foxglove flower.

My favorite painters are Picasso (his abstract work), Van Gogh (I love impressionist work), and Monet (not always the images persay but because he does them in pixels- that technique is amazing and super hard to do and achieve perfection the way he does) so yes, I love them and all three of their styles I use in my own artwork. 

Abstract with a little impressionist style with a little pixel style all mixed into one. 

Michael Angelo‚Äôs work is amazing as well!! I mean the 16th chapel is probably one of THE most beautiful works ever produced!! 

Just gotta say I love most artists that aren‚Äôt modern artists. Modern artwork is fucking trash, garbage, scum that shouldn‚Äôt be called art!!! It‚Äôs the most ridiculous shit ever put forth and called art and it shits on us real artists that use talent and skill to produce work worthy to hang or shelve in people‚Äôs homes. 

Example of shit modern art- a fucking brown paper bag. There was a gallery opening in New York I believe, anyhow that night after closing the janitor lady was cleaning up. There was a crumbled brown paper bag on the floor and thinking it was trash (like it should have been considered), picked it up and threw it away with the rest of the trash. The next morning everyone get to the gallery and see the ‚ÄúART PIECE‚Äù is missing and find out it was the crumbled up brown paper bag that was thrown away. 

A crumbled brown paper bag isn‚Äôt fucking art, it‚Äôs garbage! They‚Äôve had a dirty nasty ass old shoe as ‚Äúart‚Äù in the modern world. The list goes on and on and on. It‚Äôs garbage bullshit. Just saying.

replies.author: @88feji
replies.text:
I don't think Theo Van Gogh was a good brother at all ... in fact I believe Theo was the one who stopped Vincent from achieving success during his lifetime as a painter.

People should ask why is it that Theo, as one of the most successful art dealer of his time, only managed to sell 1 single painting of his brother even though Vincent painted a mind boggling roughly 900 paintings ??!?

Is that even possible ??

Do remember that Theo was instrumental in popularising Monet's paintings by holding solo shows for him and vigorously promoted him to his company and to buyers at a time when Monet was still relatively an unknown. Theo's solo shows for Monet was a big driving force for Monet gaining popularity very quickly.

Truth is that Theo either failed to appreciate how good his own brother's paintings were (and therefore never seriously promoted Vincent's paintings) or he simply was afraid to be outshone by Vincent in the eyes of their parents if Vincent became famous.

I just finds it impossible to accept that a successful art dealer fails to sell more than 1 painting out of 900 paintings done by Vincent.

In fact, it was Theo's wife who managed to popularise Vincent's paintings after Theo died.

BUT Theo's wife was not even professionally trained as an art dealer !!

If an amateur can popularise Vincent's paintings within a short period of time, how is it that a successful professional art dealer, Theo Van Gogh, with all the right skills and connections fail to sell beyong 1 painting for Vincent ?

Can you imagine how depressed and deeply tortured Vincent must have felt to have painted 900 artworks and only selling 1 ?

In fact, in Vincent's letters to Theo, he anxiously asked Theo why his paintings were not selling at all and he almost bordered on accusing Theo for not trying hard enough to market his paintings. Theo's reply was that his paintings were not brightly colored enough .. And thats when Vincent took Theo's advice and began to change his color palette and produced some of the most brightly colored , visually vibrant paintings ever painted. Even that change in style never resulted in any sales. Vincent 's art style was every bit as vibrant and whimsically masterful as Monet.

The thing that saddens me the most is that its the brother (Theo) that Vincent trusts the most who failed to promote Vincent's paintings to result in sales and success like he did for Monet. And its an even bigger insult that the media through the ages have painted a picture of Theo being a loyal supporter of Vincent's art... no, thats the biggest bullshit of historical proportion.

Theo never tried to promote Vincent's art, if he did, with his influence as a successful art dealer, he would have sold far more than just 1 single painting.

I hope more people will read this comment and start challenge the mainstream narrative on the 2 brother's relationship... because the truth should be told. I had kept my thoughts to myself hoping to see some documentaries asking the same questions but no one, no documentaries has come out to point out the glaring plot holes of the official narrative .. Let this comment be the start of it..

This is the most likely scenario. Van Gogh was actually against suicide. Very against it. And the only reason why suicide is the accepted reason is because some idiot concluded that and published it in his book and his theory spread like wild fire. Vincent wasn't shot in the chest. It was the lower abdomen. If it was suicide, why shoot there? And why go back to his room? The place where he was shot, was where he was painting. Why was his stuff gone and why couldn't anyone find the gun?
It annoys me that people repeat the same thing some guy theorized in a book that spread like crazy. Especially when there's other theories that came out before his and after Van Gogh's death none of which mentions suicide. Poor guy was misunderstood in life and especially in death.

replies.author: @ForeverLaxx
replies.text:
Because they're often "ahead of their time", or rather, they aren't producing works that their current climate wants to see. You see it more often in music these days than physical art, where the public is obsessed with "Top 40" pop songs or some other thing, and if a group tries to go outside of that when they're on tour they just get screamed at until they do the song you hear on the radio a million times.

Take the Beatles, for example. They were trying to get beyond that "British Boy Band" image and do more experimental songs, but every time they were on tour the crowd would just demand they do "Twist and Shout" constantly. For artists who want to grow, this is soul-crushing. The music industry today takes advantage of this and it's why you see so many pop/rap groups cycle through every 5 years with maybe 3-5 "hit" songs for each one.

The public wants what they're used to already getting. Rich people have shit taste. Artistic communities tend to ridicule people doing something no one has seen before. It's a tale as old as time. That said, taping a banana to a wall still isn't art.

replies.author: @metrizans
replies.text: I read the comments, and I realized I might possibly upset someone with what I said, so I do want to clarify. I love David Lynch a ton. His work has incredible and has inspired me, and has also inspired a lot of my favorite media. I personally suffer from depression. It's gotten worse since the pandemic, and honestly, I do appreciate these clips being catalogued. It gave me some insight. I've been doing a lot of work on my mental health this year. I'm tired of feeling stuck, feeling unable to make anything, and as I'm currently in my thirties, I'm really hoping to make... something, this decade. Thx David Lynch, and also, thx OP for posting this.

comments.author: @avedic
comments.text:
In my experience, when i look back on the times i was most happy, i was immensely creatively productive. And when i was most depressed, I'd go for months or even years without making anything. But...when i do find my way out of that darkness, the combination of novel clarity and the memory of intense suffering...thats where meaning is forged.

At least that's what i remind myself. To be perfectly honest, i was incredibly creatively productive up until i turned 30 or so. Then i went for years doing nothing. My late 30s saw some light leak back in, and i had a flurry of creativity. But i turn 42 next month, and it genuinely scares me how fast time is flying by and how dopamine deficient i feel. I want nothing more than to live the artist's life every single day. But im often expending ALL my energy to just feel ok and cocoon myself away from any pain. I'm more numb than ever. But David is SUCH an inspiration, and a reminder that life is finite and every day counts. He created art every day of his life. I need that...but I'm terrified I've lost it forever. ü•∫

comments.author: @hypercynic
comments.text:
As someone who has suffered with major depression my entire life (genuinely, my mom died when I was 5 and it killed my soul) it's all too real. When you are that level of depressed, it seems pointless to create for a future that you don't even want to take place in, or exist in. The only periods of time where I've managed to force myself to create were periods of manic depression, where it feels like the only way to get out of depression is to constantly stay busy because you know that energy is VERY fleeting. You get maybe a month, so you need to make it worthwhile. 

The hardest part is forcing yourself to keep going, even when you don't want to, even though you know that working on things provides at least a small amount of joy, it just feels like hell when you're already trying to escape that darkness inside your head. What I always found helpful was making sure you do things that are funny or upbeat as well as make the moody, melancholic, depressive stuff. When you're down, work on the music that elicits the emotions you WANT to feel, it makes it easier to feel motivated by that. It then makes it easier to want to work on the depressing things because you've alleviated some of that, so you can truly quantify the feelings you have in those moments. I find it's much easier to conceptualize and interpret those negative emotions in retrospect, rather than in the moment. 

The true struggle is just keeping momentum. I've never managed to solve this problem yet and sure, medication or therapy might help, but any medications I've been on just numbed my brain and my emotions, in a very scary way. Dehumanizing I'd call it. Therapy has always been nonsense too. Getting 10 different diagnoses from 10 different people doesn't exactly feel like adequate science is even being performed there. It's one person projecting their own bullshit onto you and getting paid to do it. I also am Canadian and mental health care isn't supported here, so even though I'm permanently mentally disabled and can't work because of it, they still refuse to pay for more than 2 sessions per YEAR with a therapist. So even if I wanted to get back into therapy, it'd be completely pointless.


I have had autistic people tell me that I am very likely autistic though and that's why they haven't diagnosed me properly, because I hide most of my autistic tendencies due to a lifetime of being made fun of for all the weird things I do. So who knows. I'm gonna talk to my doctor next month about it and take whatever test there is for that. Maybe I've just been partially undiagnosed my entire life and it'd explain basically every single issue I've had forever with one concise diagnosis, rather than 4 simultaneous ones.

comments.author: @bfkc111
comments.text:
"Duhpresshun" is after all mostly just narcissism and lack of imagination. I don't mean that they are "sad" because they have a bad imagination, but that they are in a way too self-satisfied and smug to simply do something more in the way of a hobby (which thereby enriches imagination). And it is also deeply disrespectful of people's real problems, by simply branding them as crazy, physically different and "broken", and part of a cult of sorts (the members of which often do lots of propaganda). Also, no problem gets solved, go figure...
And it is also a kind of luxury, because it implies you don't have enough need or pressure to actually solve your problems instead, or there are no real, factual problems of particular magnitude.
And on top of it: it is normal, or definitely should be regarded as normal to hate, or have disdain for, life, anyway. At least as totally rational and basically sane. Because it is not possible to make a good argument for life being all fun and fluff. That is pure idiocy and massive ignorance, even in most of the best cases (because life has certain structures, especially of age, and there are of course limiations). This view causes hypocritical cruelty, because life after all is absolutely "good", even if you do your best to best to make it unimaginable torture... E.g. in asylums or prison. Or everyone just being d***s to each other. Because after all, that "mental health" babble is partly a substitue to distract from and downplay the general lack of morality, and pretend to be "good" and "wholesome" for a little while. Usually with zero content and meaning.
And the "solution" is after all supposed to be nothing else than a robotic, and almost completely indifferent functioning , with the occasional slimy, cheesy navel gazing.

So it's better to read a book or play a game or go running, or solve a real problem, or ask for personal support - if you can find any non-hypocrite who isn't just talking buzzwords one minute and messing with you the next...

comments.text: I think artists are often people who feel very deeply, and tend to have big ups and downs. For this reason, an artist could be on a high, and creating a lot of great work, and then be down in the pit of despair a couple months later. People make the mistake of pointing to artists who killed themselves or suffered from depression as proof that you must be miserable to make great art, but they don‚Äôt realize that those artists were not miserable when in their most vibrant periods of creativity; on the contrary, those periods were their happiest. You must be able to understand suffering, without making a permanent residence in it.

replies.author: @revolvingGlasshouse
replies.text: I'm convinced all great artists and innovators throughout history could be categorized as "Highly Sensitive Person."  At surface level this sounds like a banal stating of the obvious, but it's a scientifically legitimate category of people whose nervous systems are wired in such a way that they literally feel more intensely.  I encourage any creative people here experiencing mental health struggles (especially now that our guy is gone, RIP) to look into the book by Elaine Aron, who coined the term - it is seriously healing and life changing to put a name to it and learn how to work with it.  Hope this helps someone out there.

comments.text: This is an excuse or just misleading. To say that great arts in the world are created by those who suffer most in their lives simply don't mean they suffer physically, physiologically while or during creating an art. Its not at all the physical pain but the emotional pain. When you have a lot of sufferings or bad experiences, failures, heartbreaks, you tend to be much more creative because you become honest and sincere about yourself, about life, about the world. No great art can be created if youre not honest. Great arts are so different with good, mediocre pieces of art. Its easy to create a good art, but its not easy to create a great art. Charles Bukowski quit writing for a decade because he felt he hadnt have enough experiences in life yet. He told his agent he would quit writing even after telling him that a publisher would take care of all his works. He drank the hell a lot. For 10 years. He became a bum. He lived wth lepers and prostitutes on the streets. AFter living like a bum, he wrote. Then became one of the most influential writers in the history of American Literature.

comments.text:
I personally second his take. Suffering artist is NOT the best artist.
From 2016 to 2019 I was super productive on DeviantArt and worked so much on my fanfics and passion projects... ever since I lost my dad on December 2019 and I had to endure the pandemic that made 2020-2023 pass so fast, I have never felt this miserable in my life... and in turn I'm steadily becoming a workaholic who is giving up on my artistic ambitions with how awful the entertainment industry is turning and all the AI stuff. I'm still drawing, doing commissions and working on some personal project... but at an EXTREMELY lower rate. Because I'm sad. That love, that hope, that drive... it has been very damaged by my loss and how abysmal the 2020s have been thusfar. A strong "What's the point?" all around. I hope I'll eventually see the light at the end of the tunnel.

comments.text:
Lynch himself had an idyllic childhood and adolescence. "Middle America as it's supposed to be", he says. His family moved around a lot, but he made friends easily and was popular in school. Not the kind of guy you would expect would make the stuff he does. But he says that "Because I grew up in a perfect world, other things were in contrast." Interesting. 

The point is, however, he was not some tormented, suffering soul when he grew up. And he has been practiciing Transcendental Meditation for a long time, which has really helped him too. So he is definitely not a suffering artist.

comments.author: @squamish4244
comments.text:
I don't like the "You must know great sadness to know great joy" idea we have about reality. First, it's an _idea,_ not a cosmic law. It's an observation some people make, but others just hear it and assume it's true. But I've had a lot of misery in my life, for a long time, and I don't see the upside of it. Not feeling the joy. Meanwhile, I know people who have not had misery or suffering, and they're happy people. _Because_ they haven't suffered, in part.

Sure, if you've suffered, you may appreciate joy more. And what other people think is a big deal, won't be for you. Of course. But, maybe you still won't be happy. Maybe you'll just keep suffering.

"If you've suffered a lot in your life and want others to suffer as you did to "learn a lesson", you did not, in fact, learn a lesson."

comments.author: @user-uo8mx3cv5k
comments.text: This is the thing a lot of people need to understand about "tortured artists". Going through all the negative things in life is important because it widens your emotional understanding. But when you're going through it, the ugly truth is it's hard to really do anything. People often romanticize depression, and while any genuine experience, including depression can fuel art, it's really when we rise above and make peace with our suffering where we could truly create. A lot of art were bred from negative emotions, but most of them were made when the artist were reflecting upon it, not drowning in it, made in those moments where they can breathe in the surface for a while.

replies.author: @jwillied1326
replies.text: I mostly agree, but I wouldn't say that's why suffering is important. There is no greater reason why it's important, it just is. And if a person chooses to learn from it or make the best out of the situation that is a conscious decision they must make. But a lot of people, artists or not, suffer and do not find ways to heal and overcome their struggles. I mean, if we're to believe some of these famous artists and musicians killed themselves then that's a very good example of what I'm talking about. Honestly, if somebody can live their life without falling deep into that darkness, that's better than being able to create because of suffering. Regardless of the quality of the art.

replies.author: @lawsonbill1255
replies.text: Usually the artists who create despite suffering greatly also, many seem not to understand, couldn‚Äôt do that if they were depressed. Was Beethoven or Van Gough really depressed? They were uncompromising. The world and their external circumstances stood in their way, and they simply refused to give in. People really think a guy who worked constantly was depressed. Some type of mania for sure, but genius is a mania. Their two examples I gave, Beethoven and Van Gough, genuinely had horrible lives. People forget that. Their lives just sucked and they reacted to it just like anyone else would. The kind of effect the external world can have on one‚Äôs internal state is something that people simply don‚Äôt like to admit because they do not believe there to be anything higher than Man. Imagine painting those paintings and nobody caring, imagine being the greatest composer in history and never touching a woman, having a bad childhood, going deaf, having issues with people skills

comments.author: @ddewittfulton
comments.text: He is talking about transcendental meditation, or alluding to it.  If you are an artist, if you are a creative person,  something like TM can be extremely useful in helping you carve out a space in your life to be productive.  While there are specific circumstance wherein talk therapy and pharmacology can be of live-saving value, for day-to-day "blues", anhedonia, gnawing relentless low-to-mid level depression, TM can provide sustained relief. No guru. No method. No philosophy.  Just clarity.  It does not solve problems but it can create that "breathing room" for the artist to flourish.

comments.author: @mindysommers
comments.text: I don't agree with Mr. Lynch at all. I don't think I have seen such a misguided swath of misguided blather in my life. I have been really and truly depressed, one and off my whole life, and crawled out of bed to create, it was a breath of life, the tiny little piece of light in a huge blot of darkness and death of want, of soul, of hope. I literally crawled across the floor to create. One can create, and sometimes their best work, when depressed. I know what it's like not to get out of bed for weeks, no self care, not answering the phone or speaking a syllable. Those are the times my art kept me alive and gave me the air to breathe. It didn't mean I wasn't still deeply non-functional. It means that what is true for one arrogant director is not true for everyone.

comments.text:
I think the connection between suffering minds and talent is misinformed and indirectly related.

I think those gifted with the talent or brain are wired (neurologically or through different nervous system) in such a way where they may be more susceptible to being more depressed or go through things both chemically or/and  psychologically than the average human mind.

It‚Äôs not so much depression/suffering = fine or standout art, as much as it is that brains/minds/people hard-wired differently may go through different things biologically, neurotically, and-or psychologically than the average person can comprehend.

The reason why we‚Äôre attracted to people that perceive things differently is because they churn out ideas or art pieces that average people can‚Äôt. 

It‚Äôs not necessarily ‚Äúbetter‚Äù in any objective way as much as it does just ‚Äústand out‚Äù amongst everyone else‚Äô works. Those are the works and ideas and things we like talking about, stuff that just stands out of the norm. Because we don‚Äôt use our free time to think about things we all already know so we‚Äôll as much as we do talk about things we do not fully comprehend or understand.
