A free man

The clock runs, it runs till it hits six.
When I put on the mask, just to mix.
And indulge in those smiles of plastic,
I keep the mask, till it burns inside my skin.

When morning becomes afternoon, I try to pull out the mask.
When the smiles are faded, and everything starts to feel worthless again.
Still, I try, cause the mask suffocates me,
That's not bad but it's not enough to crush me like a flask.

And when afternoon, becomes night.
I will be a free man, free from any restrictions.
And the need to resist pain.
Then I'll sway, in the bloods and smiles.
And all of those messages, engraved on my brain.

comments.author: @goodToBeLost
comments.text:
Wordsworth said that Poetry has its origin in emotion recollected in tranquillity and I agree.

I think one wants to truly create when one wants to express something. Depression robs you of the willingness to express. You feel like everything is pointless when depressed.  
Depression can be a part of suffering however I believe there's more to suffering than that. Suffering also comes with moments of deep realisation of self and the world around. Suffering also gives rise to an intense desire to free oneself from it - and to express the wealth of emotions one has been feeling as part of it. That can inspire one to express and create sincerely and fearlessly. 
There can be some real value in suffering. But I don't think it's a necessity to create. 

Good video!

comments.author: @Vesperitis
comments.text:
As a creative person who's going through serious anxiety problems, Lynch speaks the absolute truth. 

When you're depressed or anxious like me, you're not thinking about creativity. You're in survival mode. You're holding yourself together so that you won't fall apart. 

And worst of all, trying to be creative during this period creates a negative feedback loop. You try to create but your anxiety is distracting you, and the more you try to create, the more you see what you create SUCKS, and that makes you even MORE anxious, because you start asking yourself "Why do I suck? Have I always sucked? Why aren't I strong enough to push through this?"

replies.author: @smartwolf9045
replies.text:
So accurate. 
I'm in this situation right now. You actually made me think, thank you.
I'm not an "artist" but I'm a software engineer and I have projects I want to build (personnally and in the company I work in)
 I generally tend to push myself to keep creating when I'm low. However, something made me say to myself lately "how about you take a break from coding when you feel really low".

I actually believe that's what I'll do more. Why? Because like you just said, it can be problematic to work at 5% of your abilities.

Last day at work I wanted to explain a technical problem about a thing I worked in, and I just couldn't explain it, I had a little panick attack in front of my colleagues (they were just 2) because I couldnt concentrate and make sense. That was so cringy. I was like "...and...euuuuh....no...euuuh..." for several minutes. I said "ok let me do it again" and I ended up explaining it ok.

But I felt like crap.

I really believe if I just had take a full break the day before, and if I just accepted on the morning "I'll make a very resumed explanation of this problem for now", it would have been great.

"I'll only practice this thing I love which is programming when I feel I'm not in too much a depressive state. Else, it will make me love this thing I'm passionated about less, and I'll associate my performance with my performance in depressed mode "


However, I feel like I still can learn even when feeling depressed. 

It's being creative that is hard

replies.author: @Atlas65
replies.text:
They had hunger and fire burning inside them... James Hetfield is suffering from depression more then ever. I don't think it is the depression that makes us or them creative. Maybe it is the struggle.

An example, the times I would go through depression. I didn't have will to do anything. I didn't really care about anything. And I don't think I hardly have any songs from depression. Maybe some songs that have emerge while I am coming out of it. But most of my songs came from struggle, or heart brake, which is kind of a struggle.  When you truly feel depressed you don't see any point in anything, so struggle and heartbrake don't matter to you. 
I feel that many people mix depression with being unhappy with where they are in life or how they wish they had this and that, the perfect hot girlfriend or the perfect job, with good income etc (But maybe you don't). You can have all of that. But when it comes over you, none of that matters. - How James Hetfield talks now really expresses to me like is dealing with depression. Like what he said on his concerts about suicide recently. That sounds much more heavy to me then some teenage angst, anger and resentment particularly towards his parents. Like in Dyers Eve; "Dear mother dear father, you clipped these wings before I learn to fly" a depressed person wouldn't have the enthusiasm to write something like that. He wouldn't simply care enough to make it matter to him. It needs to burn inside of you to make you want to express such a thing, Or like in Blackened where he expresses the terrible threat of nuclear war, rhymes perfectly with the era as you ofcourse are aware of. But those are things that were truly concerning at the time. Truly dark times. But I bet you that those that were concerned about these things are the ones that did care  - By the way I agree with one thing. Yes, you're right the strive is what made those songs so great, which is not there anymore. But depression wouldn't give them that fire that requires to make these songs.

Ok I'm going to stop now. I feel like I am rambling a bit.

comments.author: @jimnewcombe7584
comments.text: This an obvious catalogue, a pudding of banalities. They aren't insights. Anybody could recognize these statements as true, insofar as they carry a lightweight obvious truth - other aspects could be contradicted. There's a difference between diagnosed with "depression" and whatever was going on in Van Gogh or Beethoven: there's massive defiant celebration in their work, and they both got out of bed to urgently acknowledge it. Whatever was "wrong" with them (and Beethoven had a multitude of physical ailments) they weren't given to paralysis or self-pity, and would presumably have detested any notion of modern psychotherapy - nor would they have wanted their art to be perceived as merely autobiographical or "self-expression".

comments.author: @weirdguy4948
comments.text: I was bouncing between being depressed and being neurotic for the majority of my early years, childhood included. It was only until college that I had a spiritual journey of self realization and awareness, and that is exactly when I started doing art. Painting, writing, journaling. And all of it was about pain and suffering, but finally through unclouded eyes; without ego, without that automatic fast brake-less car that was my head driving me towards agony. My happiest moments came from writing about my deepest pains. I think suffering is definitely an artistic factor because of its intensity; because it forces us to consider the worth of life. But one can only create once they are somewhat outside of that headspace, once they can see everything relative to it. The shiniest emotions are only so bright when they are contrasted to the darkest moments. Once i understood the nature of my suffering I could present it in its full glory, and it made me happy.

replies.text: Yep. My mom had manic depression through my upbringing till about the time I graduated high school before I saw her lifting herself out of it. Shortly after I was born she had her first schizophrenic episode. It took a long time for her to see happiness. I have memories of her being very depressed, having episodes, always laying in bed, gained a lot of weight, having to take medications. She was a very pretty lady before it all. She finally lifted herself out of it all, with the support from my dad who by the way never left through it all, and she's the happiest I've ever seen her in my whole life today and gained her youthful look back, lost a ton of weight, hasn't had an episode since like 2014-2016. No one can make you get out of that state of mind, it comes from yourself.

comments.author: @EduardoIsSmiling
comments.text:
Why people like to talk with so much property about things they don't really fucking know? Suffering and the way you deal with it is relative to each individual. One person might be extremely depressed, to the point of wanting to stop their life, but be functional and appear extremely functional, while others are just "sad" and they stop their productivity by half. David talks like he know how each person acts, how depression or suffering happens in every person, and how each artist deal and view art, almost like he doesn't know that each individual can be infinitely different in almost all situations.

I'm diagnosed with PTSD, severe depression, anxiety and autism, and the way i deal with art is to be always creating the max i can, with the most expression of how i'm feeling i can. And a lot of the time i'm creating without feeling "good" about. On the contrary, i feel tired,angry,depressed, but a lot of times i create things not because i just want to create things or to feel pleasure(there is moments that i do this too), but i create it more like a consequence of my own suffering. A lot of times art to me is like a vomit, but even then, i try to meet a certain criteria of quality, just so i can emulate my feelings like i feel them.
*Don't let people invalidate your feelings, emotions or the way you act based on how they assumed you are supposed to act in specific situations, they are just following their own experience or the general consensus of society*

comments.author: @josegarza7719
comments.text:
I have major/clinical depression. Treatment resistant depression as it‚Äôs called. I took pills and therapy and I felt no difference. I don‚Äôt know if I actually applied most of the cbt techniques as I was lazy. I stopped alcohol as it was eternal bliss for me but it was harming my life(7 years sober today) I quit excessive caffeine (quit coffee), tobacco as well. I stretch everyday, I workout everyday thanks to some of the principles in David Goggins book. I‚Äôve changed. I still feel tired after sleeping a good solid 8 hours even 10-11. That‚Äôs how I know my depression is still there but life‚Äôs way more manageable now. 
I make music every day on my daw. Another lesson from Mark Manson in his book Subtle art etc.
Don‚Äôt wait for motivation to come. Simply do an action, and inspiration turns into motivation and the process repeats. So by simply getting on my computer and creating or learning something about music production or whatever it is you love to do you will get inspired even on shitty days.

replies.author: @gideonros2705
replies.text: I'm going to risk it and introduce to you a strange idea I picked up from a philosopher Peter Wilberg. Unknown as a writer. In his essays he spoke that depression is a spiritual crisis by which the deeper knowing of self laying deep in the body is trying to call the person, to call him out of his prison which is his mind. Depression is an attempt by the body to lead the conscious awareness away from the head into the body specially to the belly where the center of gravity lies. The point is that depression has a message for you and until you choose that message and become it you will never be the person you want to be because being is a form of inner listening. By simple deep and aware belly breathing and observing the body you can develop this inner listening or knowledge. Hope it made some sense.

replies.author: @chrkrngl
replies.text: I can really relate. That feeling of being tired. The feeling of not being able to do anything. And then suddenly I "just" "simply" do something and it kinda works! It's not even pain as a rule (while I do sometimes cry when getting something done, cleaning my aparment - so there definitely are emotional barriers, which give away the emotion when encountered or passed by), or just sadness or some "I don't want to." It is very hard to grasp, and therefore I often feel or felt guilty. I found a quote that personally really helped me, at least to understand it: "Every act of self-discipline is an act that builds self-esteem." (Miriam Adahan) or self-discipline = self-love.

I was even taking my anger off on my family but im in the right sense of mind now to say to myself "they dont deserve my anger im just going to keep it to myself'I figured out what was making me mad.
anyway the next day I did not want to do ANYTHING. I still did because I have a schedule i stick to. I was making my food but i felt like I wasnt real. Depersonalization is what its called. I may never figure out the cure but I can manage it now. Hopefully you figure out your issues on your journey too.

comments.author: @Christus_Surrexit
comments.text:
Depression is like swimming in the deep ocean with lead boots on your feet. Simply staying above the water is a life-or-death struggle, it takes all your energy to do the bare minimum. Anything more would take superhuman effort to even get started. All the while, you see people leisurely swimming along, having fun, riding jet-skis and motorboats, if they're really lucky. How do they do it? Why don't they have lead boots on their feet, like I do?
Medication gave ma a life-vest but I can still feel the boots weighing me down. And as time goes by, the life-vest doesn't work so well, so I add another one. This can't be good for me but the alternative is drowning...
How do I take these boots off? I don't even remember how they got there in the first place... I'm tired, this isn't fun anymore.... I wish I would swim away and enjoy the water but I can't... I'm stuck here and I don't know how long it'll be before I'll be free again...

replies.author: @alanwest6949
replies.text:
I was there. Even friendship can be depressing, see the depression the boat makes on the water, the friendships can‚Äôt feel their depression but it‚Äôs still there.

Now I can walk on water. Looking back, I think my mistake was forming expectations. I held on to my expectations even though each day I woke up, I knew the truth. I‚Äôd be elevated by the false expectation and pulled back down by truth. I guess this happened all day long. Back then I didn‚Äôt know expectations are pretty much useless. I guess I had hundreds or thousands of them I‚Äôd created in conflict with truth.

Now I use faith and develop a desire for things instead.

replies.author: @chitunachituna8273
replies.text: Your description is so on point! After years of therapy and somatic exercises to rewire my brain to a less stressed and depressed state, after decades of struggle and the overwhelming feeling of a kind of a vague inability to deal with life, I experienced for the first time in my life short periods of swimming without the lead boots. And suddenly, I understood why people around me navigate so easily and enthusiastically through life. Well... it really WAS easy without the lead boots on. The problem is that they are invisible to others. And it is such an exhausting piece of work to get rid of them for good

replies.author: @burari123
replies.text: ‚Äã@@chitunachituna8273how do you use the somatic exercises to help with depression?  I'm so tired of feeling this way, I want to try new things

replies.author: @chitunachituna8273
replies.text: @@burari123 I somehow understood  over the years with the help of a therapy that luckily included little somatic exercises and my own research that most of my suffering was related to a chronically high stress level which was rooted in the experience of long term stress during my childhood. This actually results in a differently wired nervous system and a chronically high cortisol level. Altogether circumstances that fed or even manifested the depression. The things that helped most to lower that cortisol level had been a change of diet (clean food, fresh vegetables, protein, little bit of carbs preferably with fiber like brown rice or potatoes, and most important zero sugar, no additives) and trying to exercice at least 5 min daily on low stress somatic exercises. If you reduce cortisol, avoid inflammatory food and exercise daily gentle rewiring of your nervous system you get out of the "frozen" state and thoughts and feelings clear up. And of course trauma therapy. At least it worked for me. It's a process but its total worth it. ü©∑ Hope it also works for you

replies.author: @burari123
replies.text: @chitunachituna8273¬† Thank you very much! I also had a very stressful childhood, and as I grew up, i felt there was always something worrying me in the background of my mind, not letting me relax

comments.text: What's the point of this video? Depression is not the same for every person and it's not the same feelings that make everyone  create. Usually it's strong feelings and these feelings can be different. I wrote poetry when my heart was bursting with love and wrote poetry when my heart was bursting with pain. And I wrote about love and pain. On days when I feel "normal" I don't write anything because there is nothing to write about. Creativity is also an outlet for people's agony, depression, struggle, etc. Of course there is no need to romanticize depression but I also don't see the need for Lynch to generalize everyone's experience and make claims such. as "if you're truly depressed you can't get out of bed" as if high-functioning depression doesn't exist and that if you're depressed you can't create.

comments.text:
I respect David Lynch, but absolutely disagree, albeit I have lived both truths. 
A quote from The Third Man ‚Äî Rome saw 5,000 years of war and suffering and invented the romanticism era, the renaissance, etc, Switzerland saw 5,000 years of peace and democracy and invented to cuckoo clock.
Tarkovsky ‚ÄúArt is born of an ill-designed world.‚Äù

You may be torpid through it, or not.. but having lived through a lot ‚Äî You have a lot to tell, it‚Äôs just difficult.. but to stick w the og quote: rome wasn‚Äôt built in a day, clich√© but like ~ ultimately if you‚Äôve gone through much more in life, you have the first hand account. This is only helpful to art and like medical research. Just not the person necessarily.
I know we celebrate the victorious the most, but almost most good cinema is concerned with human suffering. 
Obviously the one who made it didn‚Äôt need to suffer.
But then, it is basically abstract art. 
Emotional verismilitude is likely to be noticeably absent.

replies.author: @Atlas65
replies.text:
I absolutely agree with him. And yes I agree with you to some extend. Suffering, yes, can create art. But suffering and depression is not the same. I for example have written alot of great songs (my greatest songs) arising from suffering. But around twenty 26 years old I got introduced to a terrible depression and anxiety because of excessive drinking for many years (and some other traumas most likely), and I couldn't hardly get out of bed, so the desire for creating anything completely disappeared.  Like Lynch described, it wash impossible for me to create because I wash simply just struggling to want to be on this earth. Before this I used to romanticise the struggling depressed artist. But after that experience. Especially when I was getting out of it, as I was stop drinking. That glorification completely went away.. Around the same time I first saw this lecture from Lynch, back in 2013. Where he talked about these things which are being discuss here in the comment section. And it helped me so much to understand this relationship with art and where creativity comes from.

Btw, It is more to it, then just this clip. He talks more about transcendental meditation and how you can tap into these things with out being depressed. Expending your consciousness etc. I recommend that you find the longer version of this talk.

replies.author: @WJYN7435
replies.text:
Clinical depression is more of a spectrum: if you're at an extreme, can't get out of bed, are lethargic etc . Then it penalizes creativity.

But truth is that emotional sensitivity is key for art. Art is all about emotions. 
At least that's one it is in music, i'm not as knowledgable in other types of arts.
Jazz, romantic era, impressionism, bossa nova, etc. 
It's not about being depressed, but i'd say it's about a certain type of melancholy.
Saudade is a portuguese world that describes well this phenomenon:  "an emotional state of melancholic or profoundly nostalgic longing for a beloved yet absent something or someone".
Both "sad" and "happy" to put it in simple words.

Lastly, I think human nature have natural appeal for tragedy (and sadness) since the beginning of times. The most memorable and heart shattering art pieces are usually tragic: It's a carricatural thing to observe, but bad endings and tragedy are appealing (romeo and juliet, titanic, lala land, casablanca 1942, once upon a time in the west etc).

Overall, from negative feelings and "sadness" can arise beauty.

comments.author: @randybugger3006
comments.text:
holyshitholyshitholyshitholyshitholyshitholyshitholyshitholyshit... I'm in this video. HOLY SHIT.

I never would have thought that what was essentially just a way for me to engage David Lynch in a bit of conversation (the topic of the evening was Transcendental Meditation and it's effects on neurologic function and art) would get used in a video about David's views on depression. It amazes me that a large portion of this video consists of David's response to my question (something along the lines of "What do you say to people, regarding the calming effects of TM, who find their creative muse in stress and conflict?"). 
My question was not the one that, apparently, impressed David the most that night. That was a question about TM's focus on making yourself happier and not the world at large. However, David's response to my question ("...the chicks dig it...") did get the biggest laugh of the night. Even bigger than the story about Dennis Hopper auditioning for the part of Frank Booth.
The talk was given at the local University to a capacity crowd. I had David autograph a circular saw blade because Twin Peaks. My friend had him autograph a phrenology bust. David signed his name on the phrenology bust over the area of the brain that is active during TM.

Thank you to the creator of this video for showing me, very unexpectedly, my own 20-something face, on a globally accessible platform, being softly chided by David Lynch for being a drama queen. My day is 10,000 x better now.

Yes, I didn't want that line to be missread as "therapy is pointless", when he actually just found his own solution (transcendental meditation). 
The point was more that he had a reason for going in the first place, and with a method that helped him overcome that struggle he went on with life. The fact that that method for him wasn't therapy is kind of not relevant.

replies.author: @Lanooski
replies.text: @@cryo115 there's definitely something to be said about many approaches to wellness, and while you could probably chalk up some of them to placebo or as you said cults of personality, i think the broader issue is perhaps overcommodifying them rather than the core goal of finding something that works for you. in any case, creativity and art are irrefutably therapeutic, and i'm always in favor of maximizing people's ability to pursue them.

replies.author: @randybugger3006
replies.text: ‚Äã@@gmowoman I disagreed with him when he said it then, and to some extent I still do. I think there's a genuineness to dark art made while the artist is in a dark (figuratively) place that dark art made by artists inhabiting the light doesn't have. I disagree that Van Gogh could have painted the things he did if it wasn't so painful to be Van Gogh. If Stephen Bernstein hadnt been miserable would we have gotten No No Man? If Sylvia Plath had been a cheerful, airy sort of girl with lots of friends and an active social life would she have instead written poems about the cuteness of puppies? Would Leonard Cohen have written the songs he did if he'd been as perky as a dose of Prozac?

replies.author: @poolcu3
replies.text:
‚Äã@@randybugger3006  i believe it's possible to tap into those darker aspects of life that make dark art so engaging without actively struggling or being depressed. i agree that people who make and are attracted to dark art in a deeper way have experienced some kind of pain that's probably represented in the art, but it's very possible to draw from previous experiences and plain old empathy to create that art without entering the mental spaces that had a hand in its creation. that art will be different than if it was made when the artist was in pain, but people change, and what is dark without understanding light? 
maybe the point of the whole discussion is whether or not we should value mental health vs artistic achievement. and maybe it might mean we simply overvalue art - not saying we should all devalue it because "it isn't productive" or some bullshit.

replies.author: @bigscheesy4982
replies.text: @@randybugger3006 i think the point he's making is not that darkness and negativity are wrong and non contributors to art, but they really pale in comparison to the contrast given by the spectrum of emotions and the ups and downs. It really is sad to see artists who look at the greats and think that suffering is the source of the art, instead of a part of a larger thing called being human. I agree with him for the most part, my two cents are don't get in the way of living and creating how you want because you think that you need to constantly be suffering to create.

replies.author: @gmowoman
replies.text: @@randybugger3006 Dark art is beautiful, and it is definitely informed by dark experiences and emotions, but the process of making it requires a mental clarity that anxiety and depression does not allow. People who make art understand this. If you feel like shit 80% of the time, you only have 20% left to spend making art based on how shitty you feel. Also, there is nothing inherently lacking in artistic depth about positive or cheerful art. There are as many varied positive emotions as negative ones, often overlapping in beautiful ways. but david lynch is definitely right about needing to be happy or have clarity to make good art.

@@KaipitainKai I was in college studying art when David gave this talk at the University of Oregon. My first suggestion would be to contact the UofO and see if they have a copy in their archives. I'm sure the videographer that night was either an employee or student of the UofO. The DVDs were made available to attendees of the talk. I lost my copy during a move though.

If you can't get anywhere with that I have the name and address of someone who still has an original copy of the DVD. For reasons of not wanting to dox my friend, you'll have to provide a secure way to contact you if you want this particular info.

comments.author: @cryoblaster8371
comments.text:
This was called hydrotherapy. In the show the goal was to cure the patients homosexual tendencies.

In real life, hydrotherapy was used as a form of mental and physical medicine. The idea was that the water will fill any cracks and imperfections in the body and flush out illness or wounds (because water is pure and healthy is the natural state of the human body)  in the form of puff, inducing a crisis.

In the 19th and 20th century, hydrotherapy had became a semi popular way to treat mental illness and alcoholism and was even recommended by doctors and therapists. (Should be noted it didn't often look like this)
This did incoude homosexuality which was considered a psychological disorder

replies.author: @niemniej3441
replies.text:
Actually it is not true.
Psychiatric hospitals can hold you against your will, and force you to receive the treatment. They can bind, and restrain you, using force and/or drugs.
But whatever they do, patient has to be fed, according to his diet, even if it is not for a medical reasons, but diet of a choice.
Patient must be kept in sanitary conditions and be able to deffecate whenever he needs.
Also patient has to be provided with warm and safe place to rest.
Other than that, psychiatric patients comfort is irrelevant, in regards to laws.
I'm not at all stating that its good.
But sadlly this is how it works.
On the other hand some patients are actually scary to deal with.
My fiance once told me about a guy, who screamed almost constantly for couple of weeks, because of how his brain was messed up. When drugs finally began to work, he could be released from solitary, first night he got jumped by other patients who couldn't sleep.

replies.author: @KawaiiPrincess_Love
replies.text: Sadly, that doesn't bother many of the people who ran (or run) asylums like that. There was one in I bevelieve it was Michigan, but don't quote me on that, where a man with severe psychosis who had a mental breakdown in his room was locked into the shower room. According to the other patients he was screaming and really fighting to not have to go into the shower, but they locked up every patient when it was their turn to shower. Anyway, he was locked in there and, according to the spokespeople from the asylum (who, of course, forgot to mention the lock) "after two hours of not seeing him, [they] were starting to wonder." They found him in the shower, collapsed on the ground and barely alive. He had suffered terrible burns and was basically being boiled alive (the water temperature and if the water is on or off is completely up to the staff, who, according to the other patients, liked to either punish or just torture the inmates) To this day, the official report says that he probably broke down due to his medication or his psychosis and that neither injuries, scratches, bruises nor burnmarks appeared to be on the man's corpse. comments.author: @BBCNews
comments.text:
The Bethlem Royal Hospital in south London is the world's oldest psychiatric institution, treating patients for nearly eight centuries.
Previously known as Bedlam, over the years the hospital has acquired a huge and significant collection of art and artefacts, much of it by patients.¬† BBC News was given access to the new space to see how art can play a role in mental health and met one former patient whose work is included in the exhibition.

comments.text: The biggest detriment media has done to people with bi-polar and perceptions about them is to repeatedly convince people that ALL bi-polar people must be medicated in order to manage. As with any other disorder of the mind or body, individuals can have differing levels or categories within larger groupings, and must find what works for them as an individual and as a whole treatment, not a quick fix.

comments.author: @PlatinhoBR
comments.text:
It does not promote awareness, but ignorance. 
People get to know the name of a disorder, and somehow are sure that they know what it is just because some actor did it in a movie, be it schizofrenia, bipolarity or ocd. 
It also promotes prescription abuse, since anyone has some weird psychiatric symptom/tendency and may now identify himself with some actor and claim a mental illness. 
Also promotes self-pitty because instead of solving your problem, you label it, take a pill and complain.
